article_title: Ang 25 Pinakamabuting Maikling Kathang Pilipino ng 1943
text:
(The 25 Best Pilipino Short Stories of 1943). Published 1944. Editor, Lupong Tagasuri sa Maikling Katha. Manila Sinbun-sya, Philippine Publications. Reprinted, with an introduction by Buenaventura S. Medina Jr, Manila: De La Salle University Press, 1992.

This is the first collection of the best short stories written by Filipinos. The Manila Sinbun-sya, the cultural arm of the Japanese government in the Philippines, conducted a literary contest to choose the best stories written in Pilipino and published in various magazines. The project was part of the attempt to eradicate Western culture. A panel of evaluators composed of Jose Esperanza Cruz, A. C. Fabian, Arsenio R. Afan, Antonio BL. Rosales, Clodualdo del Mundo, F. B. Icasiano, Buenaventura G. Medina, and Teodorico C. Santos, was set up. They were guided by two principles: the content of the work must reflect the spirit of the Japanese New Order or at least not be contrary to it; and the form or technique must exhibit artistry and craftsmanship. Each of the panelists drew up his list of the top 25 stories. Those stories which had the most number of inclusions made it to the top 10. Six stories were submitted to the government panel, consisting of Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Lope K. Santos and Julian Cruz Balmaseda, who selected the first four. The choice of the top three was left to the evaluators.

“Lupang Tinubuan” (Native Land) by NarcisoG.Reyes, was chosen as the best for its “clean and noble theme” of love and country, family and kin, and the land of one’s birth and affections; as well as for its lively and sensuous portrayal of local life. “Uhaw ang Tigang na Lupa” (Thirsty Is the Arid Land) by Liwayway Arceo is a love story, selected for its fresh and stylistic narrative approach and its triumph over cloying sentimentalism. “Lunsod, Nayon, at Dagat-Dagatan” (City, Countryside, and Seashore) by N. V. M.Gonzalez won third prize for its naturalism in movement and structure, its gentle progression, and its innovative restatement of the truism that life goes on for all despite social turmoil.

The anthology includes the interesting discussions from the first group of evaluators regarding their choice of winners, as well as the comments of the government panel on the worthiness or unworthiness of the six top-ranked stories submitted to them by the evaluators. Two differing perspectives emerged. The younger panel valued subtlety, restraint, and indirection, whereas the older panel hewed to more traditional qualities in “good” literature: rhetorical style, sentimentalism, and didacticism. For instance, Macario Pineda’s “Suyuan sa Tubigan” (Courtship at the Rice Fields) was praised by evaluator Fabian for its restraint and use of local color, but was dismissed by the panel as mere ethnography.

The clash between tradition and modernism helped shape the direction of writing among Tagalog fictionists in the decades that followed. Young writers came of age in the craft of fiction with this recognition by the experts. Many of them would go on to become fictionists, novelists, editors, and journalists after the war: Pineda, Arceo, Serafin Guinigundo, Brigido Batungbakal, Gloria Villaraza Guzman, and N. V. M. Gonzalez, to name a few.   Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

text:
(50 Golden Stories by 50 Great Storytellers). Published 1939. Editor, Pedrito Reyes. Manila: Ramon Roces Publications. Reprinted, Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press, 1998. Two volumes.

With 50 short stories, it is the most comprehensive compilation of Tagalog short stories published before the outbreak of World War II. Many of the authors included in the anthology were already well-established writers that had been published in Liwayway, Mabuhay, Muling Pagsilang, Taliba, and other magazines and newspapers. The other writers were members of Ilaw at Panitik, an organization of Tagalog writers whose aim was to strengthen Tagalog language and literature.

Nearly all of the stories deal with the theme of love. In “Ulirang Pag-ibig” (Model Love), Roman goes to the city to finish school but is instead corrupted by the hedonism there. It takes the love of Ninay, with her belief that the simple rural and agrarian life is enough for both of them, to reform him. In “Malupit na Kabihasnan” (Cruel Civilization) by Alberto Segismundo Cruz, Pad-leng, an Igorot, goes down to Manila to be educated, assuming the name Raul del Monte and taking a lowlander for a wife. He becomes educated and famous, but he turns back on his Igorot identity and breaks the heart of Puranti, an Igorota and his first love.

Filial love is depicted in Nieves Baens del Rosario’s “Ang Mangingisda” (The Fisherman), about Sencio, a fisherman who was lost at sea after a great storm. He eventually returns to his family only to discover that his wife, Luisa, is now happily married to Pitong. In Lope K. Santos’s “Ang Asawa Ay Asawa” (A Wife Is a Wife), Lolita hates Damaso, her father, for having abandoned her and her mother but realizes that her father’s act was a sign of loyalty to Yayang, his one and true wife.

Although love pervades most of the stories, social inequities are also tackled. Adriano P. Laudico’s “Hikbi sa Karimlan” (Cry in the Dark) depicts the hardships experienced by landless families who took part in the homestead program. In Antonio B. L. Rosales’s “Kristal na Tubig” (Crystal Water), Tasio, who is struck by tuberculosis, must decide whether to remain optimistic about his daughter’s prospects or to succumb to pessimism.

The other writers in the anthology include then already established Tagalog writers Julian Cruz Balmaseda, Iñigo Ed. Regalado, Severino Reyes, Deogracias Rosario; then popular writers Fausto Galauran, Jose Domingo Karasig, Carmen Herrera, Susana de Guzman; and future National Artists in literature Amado V. Hernandez and Lazaro Francisco.

Critics, like Alejandro G. Abadilla and Clodualdo del Mundo, who espouse realist and modern aesthetics may dismiss the stories. Originally written for and published in popular magazines, most of the stories uphold conservative values, like love of family, community, and faith, and deploy the techniques of popular literature like surprise endings and plot twists. Thus, the anthology is important in providing readers and critics today a mirror of the taste of the reading public before World War II.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda

text:
Published 1964. Author, Edith L. Tiempo. Manila: Alberto S. Florentino. Reprinted, Manila: New Day Publishers, 1992.

Four of the eight stories in this collection of short stories received Palanca and Philippines Free Press awards. Tiempo probes into moral issues, the polemics of good and evil, and suggests that there is a human existential purpose in situations that require the graceful weathering of ironies and absurdities. Solitude overwhelms her characters, and they are doomed to loneliness, loss of identity, and wandering. Tiempo uses symbol and suggestion to create a hushed mood in her fiction. Her language is descriptive but unburdened with scrupulous detailing.

In “The Hound,” a town turns to a beggar-woman in the aftermath of war and seeks her mysterious power to cure and to resurrect the dead, while a local politician struggles with the Sisyphean task of restoring the social order. In “The Chambers of the Sea,” a man learns to accept life’s responsibilities when he observes sea creatures going about their task with almost humanlike tenderness. Ultimately, he realizes that all painful wanderings must end with the finding of the self. “The Black Monkey” exposes the irony of escape, as a woman, convalescing in the mountains and removed from the violence of flatland war, discovers the fatal power of a gun when she is provoked by a monkey invading her hideout. In “Abide, Joshua,” the title story, the practical demands and the cruelties of time threaten a family’s ancestral home, but it is lovingly recalled and remains in the memory of a seamstress. Human pride and generosity endure in the discovery that it is not human possessions nor the attachment to the perishable material of life that matters, but the loving and vivid recollections, during the harshest seasons, of past pleasure or pain.

Tiempo appropriates Western thematics to the local setting, through the influential literary and moral echoes of writers such as Francis Thompson and, more importantly, T. S. Eliot and W. H. Auden. As a modern fictionist, Edith L. Tiempo successfully integrates the formal method with psychological realism, to pursue dimensions of consciousness in Philippine fiction in English that are seldom probed, especially in ordinary, middle-class characters and settings.  Written by Danilo Francisco M. Reyes

article_title: Ako'y Isang Tinig: Katipunan ng Mga Piling Maikling Katha at Sanaysay
text:
(One Voice Am I: A Compilation of Selected Short Works and Essays). Published 1952. Author, Genoveva Edroza-Matute. With an introduction by Teodoro A. Agoncillo. Manila: Inang Wika Pub. Reprinted, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1996.

One of the earliest single-author collections of short stories in Tagalog, the book was a landmark in the history of Tagalog literature. Hitherto, Tagalog short stories were perishable commodities, with a shelf life as long as that of the issues of the magazine in which they were published. Matute’s book guaranteed her a more lasting place in libraries and eventually entry into the school curriculum. More important, her stories exhibit the qualities that Agoncillo, in his introduction, had found missing from the works of the fictionists of his day: subtlety, restraint, and craftsmanship. Thus, they are exemplars of the artistry that the Tagalog short story could achieve.

Included are Matute’s frequently anthologized works, whose subject matter is childhood or children: “Walong Taong Gulang” (Age Eight), “Kuwento ni Mabuti” (Story of Mabuti), and “Tata More” (Papa More). The stories are riveting for their carefully staged process toward a revelation of tragedy, which undercuts the surface innocence of the stories. In “Kuwento ni Mabuti,” Fe’s much-loved teacher talks of her child but never once mentions the father’s name. Thus, only through subtle clues deliberately planted by the author does the reader, along with Fe, come to realize that the teacher was a kept woman unable to mourn the death of her lover openly.

In several stories set against World War II and its troubled aftermath, Matute presents a dysfunctional society: roles traditionally assigned to the father are taken over by their children, who are thus forced to end their childhood. In “Bughaw Pa sa Likod ng Ulap” (The Sky behind the Cloud Is Blue Yet), Edo and Iding scavenge scrap materials to survive as their father fights the Japanese. In “Bangkang Papel” (Paper Boat), the innocence of children is shattered, as the boy protagonist realizes that his father has been killed in an encounter with government soldiers. “Kapatid” (Sibling) dramatizes the effect on children of their discovery that they have been born out of wedlock.

The theme of love between a man and a woman is found in a number of Matute’s stories. In “Puti ang Kulay ng Pananalig” (White Is the Color of Faith), a woman lives under the illusion that her sweetheart will eventually come back to her. “Nagtataka si Totoy” (Totoy Wonders) uses an observant boy to filter the complexities of a relationship. The epistolary “Sulatan” (Writing Exchange) details the slow unfolding of love between a man and a woman.

“Nang Lumatag ang Dilim” (When the Darkness Spread) revolves around an old man’s disillusionment with life. Unable to provide for the family, he cringes in shame each time his daughter hands him her earnings from her work as a prostitute.

The nine essays in the collection show the same remarkable restraint, firm grasp of point of view, fluid handling of narrative structure, refusal to preach or state a moral, and the intricate interplay of serious ideas and vivid impressions. The techniques of fiction are used to delineate topical matters in a historically specific milieu. A vivid recreation of postwar Manila is “Yaon ang mga Ginintuang Araw ng Buy and Sell” (Those Were the Golden Days of Buy and Sell), and the right of writers to stage a strike is explored in “Manunulat Man Ay Makakaisip Ding Magwelga” (Even a Writer Can Think of Joining a Strike). In one essay, the reader gets to know the late Manuel L. Quezon without the writer naming him. Finally, “Ako’y Isang Tinig” (One Voice Am I) is an affirmation of the persona’s faith in life, despite cataclysmic events like war, and personal tragedies like death.

With this book, Matute succeeds not only in giving voice to children and women in her fiction; she also proclaims her role as a chronicler of history, as artist, and as teacher.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(ALI*BANG+BANG and Other Stories). Published 1994. Author, Rolando Tolentino. With an introduction by Efren Abueg. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This set of 13 narratives is a portrait of Philippine society that is bleak and seemingly hopeless, written in various modes ranging from the classic bildungsroman to metafiction.

“Alibangbang,” the opening and titular story, sets the tone for the rest of the collection with a grim though magical picture of the turbulent countryside. The story, which is the longest in the book, follows an old couple and their daughter Ali, whose already destitute lives are upended—and eventually snuffed—by military troops. Led by one code-named Kapre, the troops arrive in the town of Papaya in search of aswang who they claim are terrorizing the area. Real-life events bleed into the fiction by way of newspaper headlines, and folkloric elements and codes are cues for the real battle that is being waged in the countryside.

What follows “Alibangbang” is an assortment of shorter but equally grim narratives: “Ipa” (Husk) is a classic bildungsroman premised around a politically charged phenomenon; “Palabok” (Prawn Noodles) is a tale of marital discord couched in a cooking recipe; “Sa Kanto ng Annapolis at Aurora” (At the Corner of Annapolis and Aurora) is a story about the city in six “versions,” including a blank one; and “Asperges” is an account of a political killing, interspersed with Bible verses and quotes from Christian evangelical pamphlets.

The characters in these stories are disenfranchised and downtrodden, caught in the most desperate points of their lives. This familiar cast includes a teacher in “Kumusta Ka, Bb. Ameurfina Santos?” (How Are You, Miss Ameurfina Santos?); a suffering mother in “Ina ng Laging Saklolo” (Mother of Perpetual Help); street urchins in “Monumento” (Monument); an enigmatic woman in “Litrato” (Photograph); and a vengeful, long-suffering daughter in “Kwatro Kantos” (Four Corners).

Although (state-sponsored) violence permeates the stories and lives, there is some reprieve from it, whether in the narrative turn of events or authorial treatment. Tolentino ends even the most desolate of story lines with hopeful twists, no matter if it only occurs in the imagination. After the summary decimation of her village and family, Ali in “Alibangbang” is suddenly alive again, laughing alongside the moon, the villagers, and even the resurrected salvage victims dumped in a nearby gorge.
She is seen running and running, before she lifts off the ground, restoring the riches of the plundered countryside and wiping out the destructive logging company and military camp. “Asperges” ends with the blood of the slain activist flowing to the tamarind seeds fallen from his backpack. Reprieve also comes in the form of less triumphant escape, whether it is suicide in “Just Do It!,” a bus to an unnamed destination in “Ina ng Laging Saklolo,” cold-blooded murder in “Kwatro Kantos,” or a job overseas in “Kumusta Ka, Bb. Ameurfina Santos?”

Tolentino’s fiction probes the inextricable, systemic link between the self and society. While the incisive, even explicit social commentary lends power to the narratives, the construction and development of Tolentino’s characters provide them with a deep psychological dimension; and dark humor punctuates the telling of their plights. In his introduction, Efren Abueg identifies Tolentino as foremost in a then new generation of young writers who were continuing the militant tradition of Filipino literature that began in the 1960s.  Written by Glenn Diaz

While the incisive, even explicit social commentary lends power to the narratives, the construction and development of Tolentino’s characters provide them with a deep psychological dimension; and dark humor punctuates the telling of their plights. In his introduction, Efren Abueg identifies Tolentino as foremost in a then new generation of young writers who were continuing the militant tradition of Filipino literature that began in the 1960s.  Written by Glenn Diaz

article_title: The Apollo Centennial: Nostalgias, Predicaments and Celebrations
text:
THE APOLLO CENTENNIAL: NOSTALGIAS, PREDICAMENTS AND CELEBRATIONS Published 1980. Author, Gregorio C. Brillantes. Manila: National Book Store. Catholic Mass Media Award of Merit for Best Book, 1981. Included, with four new stories, in On a Clear Day in November, Shortly before the Millennium: Stories for a Quarter Century. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 2000.

Written in the tumultuous decades of the 1960s and the 1970s, the stories in The Apollo Centennial are charged with the same energy, anger, contemplation, and tragedy that gripped Philippine society at the time. A sense of loss and desperation pervades the stories, often followed by equally desperate attempts to overcome it.

Many of the stories situate themselves directly within the sociopolitical conflicts of the time. “A Taste for the Fine Wine of Bourgeoisie” details the parties of the Bautistas from 1960 to 1975. These parties are described objectively and meticulously, a style that reflects the relative isolation and detachment of the Bautistas from the unrest growing around them. A similar party takes place in “Help,” where the story of a love affair is sandwiched between a cornucopia of philosophical, scientific, and pseudo-scientific discussions about society. “The Mayor of San Felipe” is a profile of the authoritarian mayor Frankie Mangrobang, whose simultaneous “modernization” and oppression of San Felipe echo the work of a historical dictator who shares his initials. Meanwhile, “Janis Joplin, the Revolution, and the Melancholy Widow of Diego Silang Street” tells of a journalist’s desperate attempt to stay centrist amid violence and revolution.

Other stories are more philosophical in nature, though not any less critical. The nature of time is a dominant theme in “The Cries of Children on an April Afternoon in the Year 1957.” In this story, time takes on a mercurial, transitory, and ineluctable quality, oscillating between a languid April afternoon full of carefree cries of the children, and short, silent, unobtrusive scenes of said children’s futures, filled with pain and disillusionment. Time is again central in the title story, though in this case it is immutable: in the year 2069, the children of a still underdeveloped, still guerrilla-ridden rural Tarlac come to the city to celebrate the centennial of the American moon landing.

“The Quintuplets” is another futuristic story, though time is no longer the central issue here. In this story a doctor hurries to save dying quintuplets in a future of widespread birth control and infertility. Then there is the tragicomedy “Excerpts from the Autobiography of a Middle-aged Ghost Writer with Insomnia,” which explores a brief literary giant’s fall from grace and his subsequent (and successful) selling out. Written in a more traditional realist mode, “Journey to the Edge of the Sea” delves into a World War II veteran’s second war against his wife’s infidelity. Finally, “The Fires of the Sun, the Crystalline Sky, the Dark Ocean, and Some Women and/or Girls, including Napoleon Espiritu’s First Granddaughter” tells of the disruption in a middle-aged man’s life when he sees his past lover in the face of his daughter’s friend.

These 10 stories were later reprinted in On a Clear Day in November, Shortly before the Millennium: Stories for a Quarter Century, 2000, along with four new works. These new pieces are generally more comedic. In “Stranger in an Asian City,” Juan Salvador travels to a foreign junta-ruled city that reminds him so much of Manila. “A Mission for Heroes” pokes fun at historical revisionism with its own top-secret “dining-table book,” Project Maharlika. “The Flood in Tarlac” explores the contradictions of property right and inequality among peasants and hacenderos. Finally, the title story takes a turn to the magical real, when the spirits of the dead return to earth for a scheduled visit.

Brillantes poses various philosophical and social questions in commensurately various forms. Some works follow a more traditional realist route culminating in a Joycean epiphany, while others are set in distant but bleakly familiar futures. Others still rely heavily on fragmentation or some other technique, so that form and content work symbiotically and are impossible to consider separately.  Written by Dominic Sy

article_title: Bagets: Anthology of Young Adult Fiction
text:
(Kids: Anthology of Young Adult Fiction). Published 2006. Editors, Carla M. Pacis and Eugene Y. Evasco. With introductions by the editors and a foreword by Mae Astrid Tobias. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The 16 short stories in this collection are divided evenly between those in Filipino and those in English. They cover the typical concerns of growing up, including such sensitive topics as abuse, social standing, and sexuality.

Young love and courtship are the stuff of “Ligaw na Piraso ng Jigsaw Puzzle” (A Missing Piece of the Jigsaw) by Ana Celina M. dela Peña, “Peanut Butter Kisses” by Raissa Claire Rivera, “Angel” by Lin Acacio-Flores, and “Sweet and Tender Hooligans” by Mae Astrid Tobias. “Girl Meets Girl” by Agay C. Llanera has a young girl in an all-girls’ school developing a crush on a schoolmate.

Issues with body image are central to the stories “There Was This Really Fat Girl” by Carla M. Pacis, “Cinderella and the Night of the Prom” by Rachelle Tesoro, and “My Brown, Bony Knees” by Heidi Emily Eusebio-Abad. “Trese” (Thirteen) by Christine S. Bellen and “Multo” (Ghost) by Susie Baclagan-Borrero are about coming to terms with bigger responsibilities. Two more stories in the collection are about overcoming inhibitions. In “Stainless” by Eugene Y. Evasco, a boy who loves cars overcomes his resentment of his father’s beloved vehicle—a stainless steel owner-type jeep. In “Kuwatro Oras” (Four Hours) by Alice Mallari, a girl overcomes her fear of death to attend a friend’s funeral.

In “Boogers Are Stalactites” by Perpi Alipon-Tiongson, a girl considers her relationship with her mother as she discusses poles and magnets with a teacher. In “Half F-stop” by Mae Astrid Tobias, a young, aspiring photographer exhausts every means, even questionable ones, to win a position in the school newspaper.

Some stories deal unflinchingly with more troubling themes: “Ang mga Pasaway” (The Rascals) by Renato C. Vibiesca dramatizes a boy’s struggle with drug use and his need to belong; “Panunuluyan” (Accommodation) by Henri Rose R. Cimatu depicts how a bright and virtuous young girl arrives at a difficult decision when she discovers that she is pregnant.

Although written primarily for a young adult readership, the stories will appeal to mature readers, too. The writers treat the narrative situations with a light hand while realistically conveying the gravity with which their young characters view their situations—a comfort for young readers looking to find their own stories within its pages.  Written by Katrina del Rosario

article_title: Bahandi I: 46 Ka Pili nga Mga Sugilanon sa Ilongo
text:
(Gems 1: 46 Selected Stories in Ilonggo). Published 1970. Compiler and editor, Juanito C. Marcella. With an introduction by Lucila Hosillos. Manila: Lyceum Press Inc.

The short stories anthologized in this book were previously published in Hiligaynon magazine between 1960 and 1970. There are stories with simple, unilinear plots meant to narrate a series of adventures or to impart a moral, as well as stories that depict the immediate social realities of the Ilonggo. Some have experimental features, such as the interior monologue or the recurrent motif. The influence of O. Henry is found in the stories that end with an ironic twist, such as Lilia S. Balisnomo’s “Ang Kahon” (The Box), which is about a bus ride from the city to a town. During this ride, the narrator’s attention is caught by a pretty woman who carries a box and handles it very carefully. In the end, he discovers that the box contains her dead baby. Local color is used to advantage in this story, as the behavior and dialogue among the passengers, driver, and conductor in the bus enliven the story. Poetic justice is combined with the ironic twist in many of the stories. In “Dogpayt” (Dogfight) by Raymundo S. Defante Jr, a dog that is trained for dogfights is also clandestinely taught to steal. In one dogfight, it is bitten by a rabid dog. Thus, the owner loses his means of living, which he has trained to steal his neighbor’s chicken. There is also the traditional theme of the contrast between the city and the barrio.
In a love story, “Sa Taga-Bukid Nagpakasal si Mam” (To a Farmfolk Was Ma’am Married) by Bernardo M. Barcebal, the city is shown to be superior to the barrio for the advantages that it offers, although the virtues of a farmer are also upheld, for he is hardworking and respectful.

Some stories belong to the tradition of social realism, for these call attention to social-class inequality, the abuses of landlords on their tenants, corruption in government, and the sufferings of the urban poor like scavengers. The stories of Marcella, Hosillos, Isabelo Sobrevega, Ernesto F. Javellana, Leothiny S. Clavel, Ismaelita Floro-Luza, and Ali F. Bedaño are also included in another anthology, Rosario Cruz-Lucero’s Sugilanon, 1991, which contains translations in Filipino.

This anthology has been valuable to students of Philippine vernacular literature, for it was the first book that put together Ilonggo short stories written within the span of a decade.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Balangaw sa Tingadlaw: Tinipon nga Mga Malip-ot nga Sugilanon
text:
(Rainbow in Summer: Collected Short Stories). Published 2008. Author, Quin B. Baterna. Editor and translator, John Iremil E. Teodoro. Iloilo City: University of San Agustin Publishing House.

Balangaw sa Tingadlaw is one of the few single-author collections of short stories in Hiligaynon. The 18 stories in the collection were previously published in Hiligaynon magazine from 1961 to 1964. Three of the stories were translated into English by John Iremil Teodoro.

Following the tradition of romanticism and realism in Hiligaynon fiction in 1946-70, Baterna’s stories, like “Handum sang Naglimot” (A Forgetful’s Dream) and “Agud Sila Magkalipay” (For Them to Celebrate), center on love themes that bear traces of the didactic and melodramatic early Hilligaynon novels, sarsuwela, and korido (Hosillos 1992, 231).

A cursory look at some women characters would yield a number of types like the steadfast Leonora in “Handum sang Naglimot” (A Forgetful’s Dream), Ditas in “Handum kag Handum” (Aspirations and Aspirations), and Rosa in “Sa Tagsa ka Tinuga” (In Every Person), on the one hand, and the unfaithful Julie in “Sa Katapusan sang Drama” (At the End of the Drama), Susana in “Kapat-uran” (Certainty), and Soledad in “Kauhaw sa Unod” (Hunger for Flesh), on the other.

Yet one also finds women characters that are more than mere types, characters who try to break free from their confinement. Lola Sanang in “Matahum si Lola Sanang” (Lola Sanang Is Beautiful) loves a man young enough to be her grandchild. Myrna in “Balangaw sa Tingadlaw” (Rainbow in Summer) is married to a paralytic and seeks freedom from a sexless marriage through a brief affair with a man in Baguio City. Flor in “Ngaa May Luha ang Kagab-ihon” (Why Are There Tears in the Night) has agreed to marry a man to fulfill a promise she made to her dying father, but she attempts to defy the male pride of her opportunistic groom-to-be by offering herself to the man she loves before her wedding.

Though obviously calling for feminist readings, the stories can also be viewed from a number of critical lenses since their themes are as varied as their characters.  Written by Eliodora Dimzon, with notes from John E. Barrios

 

Sources

Hosillos, Lucila V. 1992. Hiligaynon Literature: Texts and Contexts. Quezon City: Aqualand Enterprises.

Locsin-Nava, Ma. Cecilia. 2001. History and Society in the Novels of Ramon Muzones. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

text:
Published 2002. Author, Mes de Guzman. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The 11 short stories in this collection were written between the late 1980s and 2000. It is characterized by a heavy use of satire to depict the Filipino’s sense of alienation in an urban and capitalist society. In “Samtoy” (a contraction of the Ilocano phrase sao mi ditoy, or “our language here”), a student named Boyet is bullied by a gang that targets Ilocanos. “May Baboy na Di Matuhog sa Litsunan” (There Is a Pig That Can’t Be Skewered at the Roast) details the absurd injustices experienced by the employees of a restaurant specializing in lechon (roast pig). “Kuwadro Kuwarto” (Square Room) is about the growing emotional distance an overseas worker experiences with his family, especially his children, during years of working abroad. In “Digital Buryong” (Digital Haywire), the interconnected stories and shifting points of view of a jeepney driver, a radio DJ, and a student mirror the inner hysteria induced by the claustrophobic conditions of the city. “Angkel Anghel” (Uncle Angel) is the story of the narrator’s bachelor uncle who is above the family’s petty squabbles over money. In “Reklamador” (Complainer), an office employee in a factory numbly carries on with his job as his fellow workers go on strike.

There is a different kind of alienation in author de Guzman’s rural setting. The book’s title story “Barriotic Punk” revolves around Jong, Mikol, and Bettu, a group of high school students living in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya, who are into punk rock music and culture. Being immersed in a foreign culture, Jong, Mikol, and Bettu live a carefree life, far away from the troubles that plague their town and province.

Violence, both psychological and physical, pervades many of the stories, and de Guzman magnifies this by focusing on the plight of the oppressed. In “Isang Mahaba’t Mapayapang Paglalakbay” (A Long and Peaceful Journey), a congressman’s assassination is told from the perspectives of the townspeople, the journalists, and the assassin. In “Sagwan” (Oar), a boatman witnesses the growing militarization of his barrio, which is caught between the Philippine military and the New People’s Army. “Plebo” follows the transformation of cadet Delphin from an individual to a product of the Philippine Military Academy.

The collection’s standout story is “DaULTRaINTErMEGALAKTIkPinOyHerO” (The Ultra Inter Mega Galactic Pinoy Hero). In a parody of the quintessential Filipino action movie, it throws together all the clichés of the genre to hilarious effect. There are scenes of implausible physical feats, gory massacres, the leading lady as sex symbol, careless editing slips, incredible juxtapositions of details—all served up with jarring inconsistencies of logic.

This collection shows Filipino society in a state of deterioration and nihilism but proposes an alternative view of a Philippines struggling with post-martial law democracy and globalized capitalism.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda

article_title: The Best of Philippine Speculative Fiction 2005-2010
text:
Published 2013. Editors, Dean Francis Alfar and Nikki Alfar. With a preface by Dean Francis Alfar and an introduction by Nikki Alfar. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

What would the Philippines look like a few decades or even centuries from now? What if Philippine society were populated by ghosts, kapre (black, hairy giant with a large cigar), tikbalang (witch with a horse’s neck, head, and hoofs), and diwata (spirits)? What if a worldwide apocalypse reached our shores? What if no barrier separated the supernatural and the everyday? These are just some of the hypotheses visited by the 42 stories in this collection. “Speculative” refers to what might be and to what if.

The stories “The Singer’s Man,” “Feasting,” and “Bearing Fruit” have a fairy-tale quality, yet they deal with present problems and situations. In “Feasting” by Joshua Lim So, Makaon leaves his village of Balay so that he can send home meat not only for his family but also for the villagers. The gruesome ending seems to parallel the fates of Filipino overseas contract workers.

Several stories are in the mode of hard science fiction. “An Introduction to the Luminescent,” “Sky Gypsies,” and “A Retrospective on Diseases for Sale,” and “Keeping Time” show that Filipino writers can credibly weave scientific and futuristic elements into their stories. In “A Retrospective on Diseases for Sale” by Charles Tan, an Internet company starts selling diseases to people who use them to get ahead in life, get out of commitments, or get away from their present lifestyles. Written as an investigative piece, this story relied on the terrorist threat of genetically engineered viruses to depict a possible dystopian future.

Then, there are those stories which blend reality with the magical or the absurd, like “Pedro Diyego’s Homecoming,” “Six from Downtown,” and “Mang Marcing and the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.” In Dean Alfar’s “Six from Downtown,” the reader tours a city that very much looks like any Philippine city, but with sirena (mermaid) being sold at the wet market, tailed men performing in strip clubs, and teachers being swept away by inverted whirlwinds. These occurrences are narrated as if they were ordinary. The book also contains ghost stories (“Revenge of the Tiktaks” and “The Flicker”) and superhero stories (“The Secret Origin of Spin-man” and “The League of Champions”).

The story that best sums up this volume is Yvette Tan’s “Sidhi” (Intensity). Set in a not-so-distant future, the story has supernatural creatures and humans living side by side. The city of Manila celebrates the feast of a newly minted saint; drugs and booze and sex are in abundance; prophecies and blessings are more curses than boons. It shows that speculative fiction is not about the future, the supernatural, or the slow march of science but about us as we are right now.

Closing the collection is Rica Bolipata-Santos’s “Just Man,” which reimagines the quandary of Jesus’s human father, Joseph, who must resist the temptation to consummate a marriage to a beautiful young woman. The story brings out the point of speculative fiction: that no matter the setting or the circumstances, human nature ultimately prevails.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article.value: Published 2013. Editors, Dean Francis Alfar and Nikki Alfar. With a preface by Dean Francis Alfar and an introduction by Nikki Alfar. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

What would the Philippines look like a few decades or even centuries from now? article_title: The Best Philippine Short Stories of the Twentieth Century
text:
Published 2000. Editor, Isagani R. Cruz. With an introduction and biographical and critical notes for each story by the editor. Manila: Tahanan Books.

As Isagani Cruz mentions in his introduction, it is difficult to come up with an anthology of Filipino short stories in English without excluding stories that might be more representative than some of those in the anthology. Even so, most of the 50 short stories included are by recipients of local or international literary awards, such as the Palanca and the Southeast Asian Writers Awards. Included are canonical works by Paz Marquez Benitez, Paz Latorena, Manuel Arguilla, Nick Joaquin, Estrella Alfon, and Jose Y. Dalisay. Also included are often overlooked stories of the country’s major writers: “Pattern” by Carmen Guerrero Nakpil, “Ark” by Resil Mojares, and “Portents” by Jessica Zafra. There are also writers and stories that have been seemingly neglected in the academe: “Five Snapshots” by Lina Flor, “Yours Faithfully” by Lydia Villanueva Arguilla, “The Boarding House” by D. Paolo Dizon, and “Lover Boy” by Lilia Pablo Amansec.

The best way to appreciate the construction of this anthology and the stories themselves is to read them in the order that they appear in the book, which is chronological. This allows the reader to see not only the era in which each story is located but also the evolution of the English language as used by the Filipino writers. For example, Arguilla’s “How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife” and Charlson Ong’s “How My Cousin Manuel Brought Home a Wife” are about families upended by the sudden appearance of another woman in their lives. In Arguilla’s story, the treatment is so subtle that readers may miss its sinister implications. Ong’s story, on the other hand, is satirical, and is a more pointed criticism of the narrative situation and what it implies.

As Cruz points out in the biographical notes, the reason for these differences goes beyond simple generational gap and, thus, technique. Bienvenido Santos’s “The Day the Dancers Came” and Jose Dalisay’s “Oldtimer” both tell of the plight of Filipinos living in the United States, but the authors treat the subject matter differently: Santos presents a linear narrative, whereas Dalisay makes use of time lapses. Santos’s language seems more formal with long, descriptive sentences, and Spanish words to localize the characters. Dalisay’s is snappier, with crisp dialogue, shorter sentences, and Tagalog words instead of Spanish.

There are only two stories from Mindanao writers, a fact which the editor laments. Ibrahim Jubaira’s “Blue Blood of the Big Astana” and Mig Alvarez Enriquez’s “The White Horse of Alih” both depict Muslim characters and their alienation from the rest of Philippine society. In Jubaira’s story, a servant narrates the rise and fall of the entire Muslim aristocracy; Enriquez’s story depicts the escalating conflict between Muslims and Christians.

Despite their diversity in themes and language use, one common thread running through most of these stories is social protest as theme. Many stories are set in rural areas, where abuses are shown to be perpetrated not only by the government and the landed but also by social structures. This anthology shows how the recurring theme of social protest established itself as a literary tradition, which emerging fictionists, writing in any language in the Philippines, continue to draw on.   Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
(Prisoner and Other Works). Published 1992. Author, Wilfredo Pa. Virtusio. With an introduction by Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Metro Manila: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Ten of the 18 short stories in the book were written between 1965 and 1972; the other eight were written between 1988 and 1992. The first 10 stories evince Virtusio’s preoccupation with themes of poverty and dehumanization caused by an oppressive pseudo-feudal and pseudo-capitalist system, and can be categorized as social realism. In “Paraiso” (Paradise), a group of slum dwellers fight to keep their shanties from being destroyed by capitalists. In “Ambo,” the title character’s petitions for a livable wage end in tragedy. The prison system becomes a microcosm of an ailing Filipino society in “Si Tanda” (Old Man), where an old Visayan prisoner is in jail for defending his land from usurpers; in “Ina” (Mother), where a mother sees her son getting involved in gang activities in prison; and in “Bilanggo” (Prisoner), where, in the midst of the dehumanization of prison life, Mang Selo holds on to the hope of becoming a free man and returning to the land that he defended.

Virtusio’s stories more than criticize the oppressive pseudo-feudal and pseudo-capitalist system; they advocate progressive change. In “Maria, ang Iyong Anak” (Mary, Your Child), he retells the Sorrows of Mary in the context of the life of a mother and her activist son during the height of student activism in the late 1960s and early 1970s. “Si Loleng Marya Kapra, mga Araw at Gabi at ang Bukang-Liwayway sa Kanyang Buhay” (Loleng Marya Kapra, Days and Nights and the Dawn of Her Life) tells of Loleng Marya Kapra’s heartache over her American lover, and her redemption through the love of an activist. Both stories show Virtusio’s commitment to revolutionary literature.

Virtusio’s post-martial law stories would see a change in style and topic but not in his political commitment. He would continue to highlight the struggles of the poor and the marginalized in stories like “Isang Kabanata sa Mahaba Pang Buhay ng Isang Ordinaryong Pilipino” (A Chapter in the Still Long Life of an Ordinary Filipino) and “Ang Kuwento ni Lenina” (The Story of Lenina). The plight of overseas contract workers in the grip of the exploitative global capitalist system is depicted in “Voice Tape,” in which a transcription of a voice recording reveals the psychological toll of migrant work; and in “Sa Tawag ng Pangangailangan” (By Necessity), which tells of how Nato, an overseas contractual worker, nearly exploits the family of his friend because of the money he has earned.

Although Virtusio tries to reaffirm the need for social change in the post-martial law era, he grapples with the failings of the armed movement in some of his stories. In “Maskot” (Mascot), the EDSA Revolt is reimagined as a rally by children led by a group of mascots. In the middle of the rally, the children are taught the Marxist view of Philippine history, but the rally ends in peace and not in revolution. In “Silang mga Naiwan” (Those Who Were Left Behind), a group of former activists meet and reevaluate their past. In the collection’s final story, “Kasama” (Comrade), one of the comrades commits a crime against a farmer.

Virtusio’s collection is a notable example of literature as a political and social expression for change, which is direly needed in an unjust society.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda

article_title: Bituen ti Rosales ken Dadduma Pay a Sarita
text:
(Star of Rosales and Other Stories). Published 1969. Author, Juan S.P. Hidalgo Jr. Quezon City: Ilokano Publishing House.

This is a collection of 20 Ilocano short stories, all of which were published in Bannawag from 1960 to 1968. Evident in these stories is Hidalgo’s device of fusing mythical, Biblical symbolism with the devices and conventions of folk narrative. Yet the storytelling is not in the traditional mold but is cast in a modern temperament; Hidalgo is one of the important writers who modernized the Ilocano short story.

In “Proserpina” and “Ti Daga, ti Tudo, ken ti Init” (The Land, the Rain, and the Heat), natural phenomena and objects allude to sexual awakening in young adults. Naughty wit is achieved in “Aphrodite,” when folk images having sexual overtones—such as shark, honey, eggplant, and coconut—are woven into a romance story. The mythic symbolism heightens the psychological delineation and emotional pitch in “Dagiti Panniki ti Montalban” (The Bats of Montalban). Social criticism in “Taraon Dagiti Didiosen” (Whom the Gods Protect) is rendered in a surrealist style.

“Awanen ti kas Kenka a Nabukelen” (No One Has Ever Been Created Like You) is the story of a writer who would give up his love for the daughter of a politician who is identified with the corrupt elite he criticizes in his writings. The title story, “Bituen ti Rosales,” is the story of a man who dies for his ideals.  Written by Herminio Beltran Jr

article_title: Born in the Year 1900 and Other Stories
text:
Published 1997. Author, Aida L. Rivera (Ford). Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Born in the Year 1900 and Other Stories is made up of 13 stories written between 1949 and 1994, and two translations. Five comprise her earlier collection, Now and at the Hour, 1957: “The Madonna Face,” “Young Liberator,” “Love in the Cornhusks,” “The Chieftest Mourner,” and the title story. Thus, there are eight new stories in this collection: “Born in the Year 1900,” “There’s a War Out There!,” “A Window in the War,” “Hacienda Mercedes,” “Adula,” “The Village Called Talim,” “My Sangrela,” and “At Midnight.”

The stories are arranged according to their geographical and chronological settings and are heavily autobiographical. Rivera-Ford’s mother, Lourdes Samson Consunji-Rivera, is source and inspiration for the first story and the last. “Born in the Year 1900” is set mainly in Bataan during the years of the American occupation. It traces the history of the Consunji and Tongko clans, Rivera-Ford’s maternal ancestors. The narrator adopts the persona of Lourdes Consunji and recounts family life, marriage to Judge Pablo Rivera, and an encounter with an escaping president Manuel Quezon in Bacolod. This piece won the Gawad CCP in 1991 for the essay. The last story, “At Midnight,” is an unconventional dramatic dialogue of an old woman in delirium, calling out to long-dead relatives. Although the old woman is unnamed in the story, Rivera-Ford, in her preface, identifies her as her mother Lourdes Consunji, who passed away in 1999.

Besides the war-related story in the first collection, two more such stories are “There’s a War Out There!,” set in Bacolod in the days just before the landing of Japanese imperial forces and told from the point of view of a home guard volunteer and the town treasurer; and “A Window in the War,” a story of manners as young ladies flirt and vie for the attentions of American POWs.

Two stories are set in the 1950s and 1960s: “Hacienda Mercedes” is set in Central Luzon during the tumultuous years of the Huk movement. A young landowner reflects on his life even as he and his family elude rebels sent to kill them. “Adula” is set in Davao; the narrator Ver, a schoolteacher, is torn between admiration for and jealousy of her friend Adula, a liberated half-Bagobo flight attendant.

Completing the collection are two more works: “The Village Called Talim,” consisting of four monologues revolving around an incident with a drunken husband on the verge of running amok; and “My Sangrela,” Ford’s autobiographical recollection of her life as a pioneer and homesteader in Maragusan, Compostela Valley.

“At Midnight” comes with the author’s own translation in Filipino, “Hatinggabi Na”; and “The Village Called Talim,” with a Cebuano translation, “Sa Usa Ka Balangay nga Ginganlang Talim” by Don Pagusara.

After 33 years’ silence since her first book in 1957, Rivera-Ford reemerges with this new collection, expanding her repertoire.  Written by Dominique Cimafranca

text:
Published 1960. Author, Bienvenido N. Santos. With an introduction by Leonard Casper. Manila: Benipayo Press, 1960, 1976; Makati City: Bookmark Inc, 1991.

This collection of 23 short stories includes some which were written earlier than those in Santos’s collection You Lovely People, 1955. In this collection, Santos goes back to Sulucan, a place in Tondo where he grew up. Sulucan is depicted as both beautiful and ugly. In “A Visit to Sulucan,” the protagonist returns after staying away for years from the “dust and heat and noise” that is Sulucan, and proclaims, “I love the place.” However, he learns that his childhood friend Ambo, “a sensitive lad and passionate,” has landed in prison for a crime, a sign of Sulucan’s corrupting influence.

Sulucan is actually Antonio Rivera Street, but the word sulucan, which literally means “at the corner,” captures perfectly the lives of the people there. These are lives on the margins of society. The stories are peopled by sad schoolteachers, dying priests, valiant farmers, students, and salespersons. The gallery of characters all lived in the country from the pre-World War II years to the days of the Japanese occupation.

The homecoming motif is found in many of the stories. “And Men Decay,” the opening story, has the son coming home to find his father still alive; the last story, “A Visit to Sulucan,” has the protagonist return to find his father dead and his friend in jail. In “The Priest,” Father Bellarmino returns to his boyhood town to find both death and the little joys he once enjoyed in his youth. One of the teacher stories is “Theme: Courage” in which a class’s contempt for a seemingly stern teacher turns to admiration, as the students realize that he is a man who “would rather be misunderstood than admit defeat.” In the title story, Santos explores the subject of infidelity and its consequent guilt. The life of the protagonist, who slept with the wife of his friend then away in the war, is symbolized by the termite-infested cabinet that stores his friend’s letters and poems; it appears sturdy and beautiful on the outside but is hollow and rotting inside.

The Santos technique of tempering sentiment with irony is evident in this collection of stories.  Written by Danton Remoto

The life of the protagonist, who slept with the wife of his friend then away in the war, is symbolized by the termite-infested cabinet that stores his friend’s letters and poems; it appears sturdy and beautiful on the outside but is hollow and rotting inside.
The Santos technique of tempering sentiment with irony is evident in this collection of stories.  Written by Danton Remoto

text:
(Outburst: Short Fiction, 1954-1964). Published 1993. Author, Efren R. Abueg. With an introduction by Isagani R. Cruz and appendices by the author, Patricia Melendrez-Cruz, and Loline Antillon. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

Most of the 21 short stories in this, Abueg’s first collection, shows the development of his writing, from a beginner’s plot-driven narrative with melodramatic overtones, to the seasoned writer’s experimentation with modernist modes like surrealism and metafiction.

In “Laruan sa Kamay ng Bata” (Toy in a Child’s Hand), Piryong and Nonoy unearth a vintage bomb and want to extract its gunpowder so they can show off some fancy fireworks to their playmates. In “Ipinagbiling Kamusmusan” (Sold Childhood), Poldo, being the eldest child, simply wants to lighten his widowed mother’s financial burdens but is forced into servitude to cover the expenses for his father’s funeral. In “Mabangis na Lungsod” (Savage City), the double oppression suffered by street children is depicted through Adong, who is robbed of the alms that he has worked to receive.

A number of the stories feature the child-parent dilemma. In “Daigdig sa Aplaya” (World at the Coast), Mang Berto insists on staying in his hovel along the shore after his wife, Aling Ilyang, dies, whereas his children want him to move with them to the city, where they wish to lay their mother to rest. In “Si Mang Kardo” (Mang Kardo), an elderly foreman Kardo and the young Nene are in love, over the objections of Nene’s parents. “Ang Paghihiwalay” (The Separation) tells about Tandang Aro and Aling Sela’s suspicions regarding the relationship of their granddaughter, Irene, and her officemate Mr Randal. These themes are merged in “Sa Bagong Paraiso” (In the New Paradise), which is about childhood friends Ariel and Cleofe, who grow up together in the country, fall in love against their parents’ wishes, and run away to the city when Cleofe becomes pregnant.

“Ang Ama, ang Anak at ang Kwento” (The Father, the Child and the Story) bears the beginnings of metafiction: Mina asks her father, Angel, to read her a fairy tale, but Angel refuses because he is busy reading about fiction writing. Angel’s decision, which brings forth grave consequences, shows how texts affect “real” life and vice versa. Thus, the story reminds us that texts may have the power to either create or destroy life.

The book includes an appendix, with two critical essays: “Sa Bagong Paraiso: Pagbasang Arketipal-Sikolohikal” (In the New Paradise: Archetypal-Psychological Reading), by Patricia Melendrez-Cruz, and “Kabalintunaan: Pangunahing Paksa ng Buhay at Sining sa mga Piling Kuwento ni Efren Abueg” (Paradox: Primary Subject of Life and Art in Selected Stories of Efren Abueg) by Loline Antillon. A third essay, “ERA: Anak ni Genoveva Edroza (O Kung Paano Isinilang ang Isang Manunulat)” (ERA: Child of Genoveva Edroza [Or How a Writer Was Born]), is Abueg’s personal account of his beginnings as a writer and a tribute to his major literary influence, Genoveva Edroza-Matute.

Six of the stories in the collection won prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: “Ang Buhay ng Ating Panahon” (Life in Our Times), honorable mention, 1974; “Ang Kamatayan ni Tiyo Samuel” (The Death of Uncle Samuel), first prize, 1967; “Dugo sa Ulo ni Corbo” (Blood on Corbo’s Head), third prize, 1964; “Sa Bagong Paraiso,” third prize, 1963; “Mabangis na Lungsod” (Savage City), third prize, 1961; and “Mapanglaw ang Mukha ng Buwan” (Gloomy Is the Moon’s Face), third prize, 1959.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

article_title: The Butcher, the Baker, the Candlestick Maker
text:
Published 1962. Author, Gilda Cordero-Fernando. With an introduction by N. V. M. Gonzalez. Manila: Benipayo Press.

The 13 stories in this collection are grouped by Gonzalez, in his introduction, into three: stories about suburban families, children stories, and stories with a cause.

The author’s two strong points are characterization that is revelatory and confessional, and telling description. These are devices that the short story genre highlights well. For example, in “People of the War,” Lina “of a nervous temperament, continually wove macrame bags in readiness for the day when we would be fleeing the bombs. She had … wide inner garment of unbleached cotton, with numerous secret pockets.” Especially endearing is the comic detail. In “The Level of Each Day’s Need,” Flora, a suburban housewife, is characterized: “In her bedroom was a box that contained her clothes in various stages of alteration—a dress in the process of being converted into a chemise; a chemise in the process of being converted into an apron; an apron awaiting the ponderous decision of whether to become a scarf or a kitchen rag.”

These characters come from a variety of situations, and the points of view are built from a variety of angles. Victoria is going through a trying adolescence in the brave war years in “People of the War,” a story often included in anthologies. In “Sunburn,” Rodrigo M. Magnum, a Filipino in America, carries a smug swagger that pains his compatriots. The tribulations of public school teachers in the 1950s in “The Visitation of the Gods” may very well be the same frustrations being felt by contemporary teachers, who would like to keep their idealism, as well as their students’, intact.

The suburbia stories are not only about the wives and their husbands but also about the lives in the tenements across the high walls, such as in “Magnanimity.” The love stories are set, quite lightly, against backgrounds of the war; but in “A Love Story,” the setting is a museum in America. The encounter is between two adolescent Filipino expatriates, considered oddities like the exhibits in the museum. The American dream is mercilessly plunked down into a native well in “The Race Up to Heaven.” A sustained abhorrence, and a fascination, for high fashion and gaudy suburban architecture make for whole stories in “High Fashion” and “A Fear of Heights.”

In this collection, Cordero-Fernando works out woman’s sympathies, outgrown prejudices, confusions, and questions as a woman of the middle class.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

article_title: Cadena de Amor and Other Short Stories
text:
Published 2004. Author, Wilfrido Nolledo. With an introduction by Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Manila: UST Publishing House.

A posthumous collection of 16 of Nolledo’s short stories, Cadena de Amor and Other Short Stories includes the classic “Rice Wine” and lesser-known pieces like “Harana” (Serenade) and “Purists, Hold Your Apocalypse.” In his introduction, Bienvenido L. Lumbera notes the recurring presence of “the alienated hero whose defense against a hostile universe was aloneness and isolation, his gestures of love hardly understood even by those who loved him.” This could well be said of the lovers in these stories—furious and foolish, full of hope but ultimately beyond hope.

The most prominent of the crises that the characters must face are the social and psychic traumas of war, especially World War II. “Rice Wine,” Nolledo’s masterpiece, details a father’s and a daughter’s struggles through postwar disillusionment and economic difficulties: the former clinging desperately to his memories of the revolution, the latter prostituting herself secretly so that they can survive. “Canticle for Dark Lovers” depicts the dysfunctional love affair between a veteran and a widow. “Adios, Ossimandas” explores the contradictions in the lives of young soldiers—their heroism and inexperience, their need for love and their march toward death. “A Lily in the Sea” explores the vanity of a woman, Alma, and the violence and eventual disillusionment of war. “Diwata, Where She Walked,” set in Manila during the time of the Cambodian civil war, deals with the life of Diwata and her half-Kampuchean son.

Class division is another theme in Nolledo’s stories. In both “Since You Do Not Sell Gardenias” and “Amor de la Calle,” the female narrators live in closed, sophisticated, “intellectual” worlds of the elite, until the men they fall for smash their pretentions. “Kayumanggi, Mon Amour” tells the story of a public-transport driver being hunted down for a debt, while “Harana” dramatizes the star-crossed love of the fisherman’s son and the hacendero’s daughter.

The title story, “Cadena de Amor,” is another of Nolledo’s masterpieces. It revolves around the attempt of two doctors to save Gayo Labrador, one of the last Spaniards in the Philippines. The motif of a dying Spaniard and the theme of a vanishing Hispanic past appear again in the author’s greatest work, the novel But for the Lovers, 1970.

The other stories in this collection include “In Caress of Beloved Faces,” a virtuoso portrait of a wedding night; “Don’t Sing Love Songs, You’ll Wake My Mother,” a first-person account of some journalists’ night of debauchery; “The Last Caucus,” a critique of Philippine politics in the 1960s via a humorous retelling of Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar; “Maria Conception,” a story of first love, brief, erratic, and violent; and “Purists, Hold Your Apocalypse,” a comedy about the negotiations among a cinematographer, a producer-director, and a semi-delirious bedridden star over an inane script.

While Nolledo’s works cover a wide range of subjects, it is his use of language above all that is his legacy. The sensuous, dreamlike musicality of his prose dominates many of these works. Where the words and phrases seem almost chaotic, they are in actuality—like the plots and the characters—spinning and swirling and spiraling around an invisible point, pulsing at the center.

Written at different times and at different stages of life, the stories collectively make for an interesting study of the development of Nolledo’s style. The poetic heights of “Rice Wine” and “Cadena de Amor” contrast sharply with the milder, simpler style of “Since You Do Not Sell Gardenias” or “Home to Celia.”

Every story in this collection is well crafted and shows a level of ingenuity that remains to be matched in Philippine literature in English. Numbering among the most inventive and original stylists of Philippine literature, Nolledo inspired a generation of writers to explore and innovate. With this book, Nolledo should continue to do the same.  Written by Dominic Sy

text:
(Masks). Published 1931. Author, Enrique Kalaw Laygo. With a prologue by Rafael Palma. Manila: General Printing Offices. Reprinted, Manila: Nueva Era Press, 1949, 1953. English translation, Masks, by Alfredo S. Veloso, Manila: Asvel Publishing, 1957.

Caretas is a collection of short stories by Enrique Kalaw Laygo, which were published earlier in local magazines and newspapers, such as El Debate, La Vanguardia, El Ciudadano, Excelsior, La Defensa, and the Philippines Free Press. The book edition includes 11 new stories, two of which are prizewinners. Besides the title story, the other stories are “Cuesta Arriba” (Uphill), “El Candidato” (The Candidate), “El Idolo con Pies de Barro” (An Idol with Feet of Clay), “La Razon de la Fuga” (The Reason for Flight), “El Abismo” (The Abyss), “El Miedo” (Fear), and “Traidor!” (Traitor).

According to Palma’s prologue, Laygo’s penetrating psychological analysis of his characters is the hallmark of his stories. The characters, modeled after real-life Filipinos, were his fellow citizens lost and beleaguered by a new way of life, brought about by a Philippines in transition. Some stories show how education and travels abroad have strengthened, deformed, or influenced the character of the heroes both male and female, caught in the tension between past and present, forced to choose between conflicting varieties of morality.

Laygo’s stories are generally sentimental and moralizing in tone; his language and style, easy and natural. Set in the rural areas, his stories are also rich in local color. Through flashbacks, readers from time to time find themselves amid a rustic scenery of nipa huts, where the gently blowing breeze and the chirping of the birds harmonize into a soothing song.

The anthology is a valuable literary documentary of Philippine society of the 1920s and 1930s. However, modern readers can easily relate to most of the experiences in Caretas, for the characters suffer the same doubts and share the same needs, sentiments, and passions as modern humankind. Written by Edgardo Tiamson

 

Source

Mariñas, Luis. 1974. Literatura Filipina en Castellano. Madrid: Editorial Nacional.

article_title: Children of the Ash-Covered Loam and Other Stories
text:
Published 1954. Author, N. V. M.Gonzalez. With an introduction by Francisco Arcellana and illustrations by Malang. Manila: Benipayo Press. Reprinted, Makati City: Bookmark Inc, 1992.

The seven stories in the collection exhibit the disciplined hand of the artist, particularly the neat structure and the emotional restraint that are the trademarks of Gonzalez. Two of the stories are initiation stories. “Children of the Ash-Covered Loam” is about the awakening of a child to life when he sees “with his own eyes how life emerged from this dark womb of the land.” “Lupo and the River” is about the initiation of another child into death when he sees the corpse of Lupo, toward whom he has mixed feelings of fear and admiration. “A Warm Hand” portrays how an unnoticed servant, Elay, finally attracts attention when she honestly insists that an unidentified warm hand has touched her cheeks. Like Elay, the young wife in “The Sea Beyond,” whose husband dies aboard a ship, suffers from the indifference of the people around her. Two stories, “The Morning Star” and “The Blue Skull and the Dark Palms,” have main characters who possess uncomplaining love for their beloved, both absent: one is not around when she is suffering from the pain of childbirth, whereas the other is dead. “Where’s My Baby Now?” portrays a mother who forsakes her domestic chores to pursue a public life.

The stories in the collection portray, according to Arcellana, the “clash between city and the farm, the impact of the sophisticate upon the primitive, the collision between reality and the unreal city.” Arcellana notes further Gonzalez’s skillful handling of his material, his “sense of structure,” his subtlety, and his prose—“clear and clean and straight and direct and hard and pure.”  Written by David Jonathan Bayot

text:
Published 2010. Author, Ernesto Lariosa. Translator, Hope Sabanpan-Yu. Cebu: University of San Carlos Press.

This book collects 10 of Ernesto Lariosa’s short stories. A thread binding many of Lariosa’s stories is man’s complete and utter disregard for nature.

In “Bugti” (The Exchange), originally published in Bisaya in 1997, former friends Ruben and Samuel take two very different paths when a cement plant is built on property unscrupulously purchased from the residents of the town and pollutes the area with its chemical run-offs. This brings about complications that lead to Ruben shooting his old friend in an argument.

The theme of encroachment on nature in the name of progress is seen in “Ang Baybayon ni Simon” (Simon’s Shore). Simon, a young fisherman from the rural town of Salagduong, leaves for higher education in Cebu City. He is aghast at how dirty, noisy, and crime-ridden the metropolis is, but he also experiences the kindness of strangers. He returns to his hometown and is reunited with a long-lost love.

The Christian-Muslim conflict is explored in “Ang Multo” (A Haunting), which involves a love triangle, a bag with a bomb, arrests, and an unhappy resolution to the love triangle.

In “Kon Di Na Manugpa ang mga Langgam” (When Birds No Longer Come to Roost) is the most symbolic of the stories in Crack Shot. The topic of political abuse and corruption is interwoven with the issue of ecology. The mayor has had the town’s mangrove trees cut down, the migratory birds do not return, and misfortune hounds the municipality.

The title story “Hingigo” (Crack Shot) shows a similar concern with the abuse of nature. A town mayor thoughtlessly encourages the killing of birds by sponsoring a slingshot contest. The participants are blinded by the contest prizes promised by the mayor.

The stories in Crack Shot show how Lariosa treats the degradation of nature both as an ethical and social matter. It is this added complexity that sets Lariosa apart from many of his contemporaries.  Written by Charles Dominic Sanchez

He is aghast at how dirty, noisy, and crime-ridden the metropolis is, but he also experiences the kindness of strangers. He returns to his hometown and is reunited with a long-lost love.
The Christian-Muslim conflict is explored in “Ang Multo” (A Haunting), which involves a love triangle, a bag with a bomb, arrests, and an unhappy resolution to the love triangle.

In “Kon Di Na Manugpa ang mga Langgam” (When Birds No Longer Come to Roost) is the most symbolic of the stories in Crack Shot. The topic of political abuse and corruption is interwoven with the issue of ecology. The mayor has had the town’s mangrove trees cut down, the migratory birds do not return, and misfortune hounds the municipality.

The title story “Hingigo” (Crack Shot) shows a similar concern with the abuse of nature. A town mayor thoughtlessly encourages the killing of birds by sponsoring a slingshot contest. The participants are blinded by the contest prizes promised by the mayor.

The stories in Crack Shot show how Lariosa treats the degradation of nature both as an ethical and social matter. It is this added complexity that sets Lariosa apart from many of his contemporaries.  Written by Charles Dominic Sanchez

CUBAO 1980 AT IBA PANG KATHA: UNANG SIGAW NG GAY LIBERATION MOVEMENT SA PILIPINAS

(Cubao 1980 and Other Works: First Cry of the Gay Liberation Movement in the Philippines). Published 1992. Author, Tony Perez. With an introduction by Nicanor G. Tiongson. Mandaluyong: Cacho Hermanos.

 

CUBAO PAGKAGAT NG DILIM: MGA KUWENTONG KABABALAGHAN

(Cubao after Dark: Stories of Mystery). Author, Tony Perez. Published 1993. Mandaluyong: Cacho Hermanos.

 

CUBAO MIDNIGHT EXPRESS: MGA PUSONG NADISKARIL SA MAHABANG RILES NG PAG-IBIG

(Cubao Midnight Express: Hearts Dislodged from the Rails of Love). Published 1994. Author, Tony Perez. With an introduction by Benilda S. Santos. Mandaluyong: Cacho Hermanos.

 

EROS, THANATOS, CUBAO: MGA PILING KATHA

(Eros, Thanatos, Cubao: Selected Works). Published 1994. Author, Tony Perez. Mandaluyong: Cacho Hermanos.

 

CUBAO-KALAW KALAW-CUBAO: MGA PREMYADONG KATHA

(Cubao-Kalaw Kalaw-Cubao: Prizewinning Works). Published 1995. Author, Tony Perez. Wtih an introduction by Jessica Zafra. Mandaluyong: Cacho Hermanos.

Eros, Thanatos, Cubao won the Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award, 1994. “Bata Sinaksak, Isinilid sa Baul” won in the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, grand prize for the novel, 1984.

A multi-genre series, Cubao is an extensive exploration and elucidation of the psychology of space and its various expressions and manifestations—namely, through sexual/body politics (Cubao 1980), urban lore and folk mythology (Cubao Pagkagat ng Dilim), “modern” anxieties and emergent interpersonal relationships (Cubao Midnight Express), the dual nature of the subject (Eros, Thanatos), and the quotidian (Cubao-Kalaw).

Cubao 1980 at Iba Pang Katha: Unang Sigaw ng Gay Liberation Movement sa Pilipinas is a collection of short stories, poems, letters, plays, and a novella, the titular Cubao 1980. These introduce the struggles and concerns of gay men, particularly those living in the city, with Cubao as a microcosm. The novella follows high school boys Tom and Butch as they navigate the streets and seedy nightlife of 1980s Cubao. Their sexual awakening and turn to prostitution at the hands of the parlorista (gay beauticians) of the district form a picture of how gay men were perceived back then, as maligned and detestable creatures. The book establishes the many themes that Perez exhausts in his subsequent collections; for instance, the use of a supernatural creature and the insistence of the subject’s dual nature can already be gleaned in the short story “Taong-Lobo” (“The Werewolf”), a portrait of how a straight-acting closeted gay man sheds off all his inhibitions and “preys on” other men for sexual gratification when night falls.

In the short story collection Cubao Pagkagat ng Dilim: Mga Kuwentong Kababalaghan, the notion of a city underworld and its otherworldly denizens is further expounded. Using creatures from folklore and other supernatural entities, the book is divided into three sections. In the first section, the creatures retain their mythological function by coexisting with and occupying the characters’ material world: in the story “Ang Maligno” (The Sentinel), a lady boarder is nightly visited by a supernatural entity who guards at the foot of her window. The stories in the second section make the human characters stand in for the creatures themselves and vice versa, thus playing on their duality. The sisters in “Ang mga Manananggal” (The Self-Segmenting Ghouls) are models of chastity during the day, but they participate in orgiastic rites at night. In the third section, the creatures double as representation and metaphor: in “Ang mga Lamanlupa” (Underground Spirits), for example, the dentistry student’s alienation and anxiety amid the never-ending grind of the city appear in the form of unexplained events in their city block—pipes suddenly bursting, garbage strewn all over the street in the morning—coinciding with the construction of the Aurora underpass; the ones causing the mishaps apparently are the displaced lamanlupa (underworld creatures) whose home was the construction site.

“Modern” anxiety and estrangement in fleeting interpersonal relationships abundant in a city setting are a major theme in Cubao Midnight Express: Mga Pusong Nadiskaril sa Mahabang Riles ng Pag-ibig. As the title suggests, the short stories focus on the different types of love and lovers that seem to emerge and flourish in an urban milieu: a teenage boy who has a special bond with his penis (“Kaisplit” [Shared]), a murderous rapist who reenacts the murder of his first love (“Pamamanhikan” [Courtship]), four macho gays who play a board game that turn them into princesses while a call boy waits for the winner (“Katalo” [Opponent]), two employees who fall for each other in the course of playing a long game of “secret Santa” (“Basted” [Busted]).

The city’s psyche is mapped out more overtly in Eros, Thanatos, Cubao: Mga Piling Katha, which may be taken as two books published in one volume back-to-back. The characters in the Eros half are driven by their life instinct; the ones in Thanatos, by their death drive. But while there is this apparent demarcation, all the stories accentuate both modalities in accordance to the classical Freudian principle that Perez clearly used as his framework. Both titled “Ang Pasko Ay Sumapit” (Christmas Is Here), two stories share the plot of a sexually molested young girl (in Eros) and young boy (in Thanatos) now living out their adult lives in Cubao. On Christmas Eve, they engage in routine sex, a clear consequence of their disturbed childhood. Len-Len, whose entire house is decorated in pink and stocked with toys for little girls, lets in her family’s former driver, houseboy, and gardener. David, a germophobe and suffering from obsessive compulsive disorder, lets in three strange young men, their feet full of grime. The former case ends on a tender note; the latter, brutal.

Cubao-Kalaw Kalaw-Cubao: Mga Premyadong Katha consists of poems, one-act plays, and the novel Bata, Sinaksak, Sinilid sa Baul (Child, Stabbed, Hidden Away in a Trunk), its title echoing a gristly tabloid headline. Weaving through dreams, religious iconography, and psychological concepts, the novel tells the story of three friends and their long dead relatives who were involved in a murder case decades ago: Ike, a seminarian, whose father is a pedophile; Ceasar, whose brother is abducted and killed by Ike’s father; and Benny, the adopted son of the policeman who is trying to solve the series of child murders. The novel comes with a supplement, “Mga Tala ni Bienvenido Dancel” (Bienvenido Dancel’s Notes), in which the protagonist Benny lists things to buy, reminders, jokes, and his own musings of the origin of the name “Cubao.”

In these books, Cubao is a fictive space, existing as a composite of the characters’ unconscious. Perez’s psychological approach therefore provides a contrast to the stark realism proposed by earlier fiction thematizing the city, such as Edgardo M. Reyes’s Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (In the Claws of Lights), 1967-68, and Andres Cristobal Cruz’s Tundo Man May Langit Din (Tondo Has a Heaven Too), 1959.

The following one-act plays included in the series won prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: Sacraments of the Dead, first prize, 1981, and The Wayside Café, third prize, 1982.  Written by Carlo Pacolor Garcia

article_title: Cuentos de Juana: Narraciones Malayas de las Islas Filipinas
text:
(Juana’s Tales: Malay Narratives from the Philippine Islands). Published 1943. Author, Adelina Gurrea. Madrid: Imprenta de Prensa Española. Reprinted, Madrid, 1943; 1955. Expanded edition, with an introduction by Beatriz Alvarez Tardio. Manila: Instituto Cervantes, 2009. “El Lunuk del Remanso Verde” is translated into English in Writing Athwart: Adelina Gurrea’s Life and Works / La Escritura Entrecruzada de Adelina Gurrea. Author, Beatriz Alvarez Tardio. Editor, Marra PL. Lanot. Quezon City, 2009.

Cuentos de Juana is a series of short stories about mythological creatures, told by Juana, a maidservant, through the author-narrator, who is her seven-year-old charge. It is set in a Negros sugar plantation in 1901.

In the first tale, “La Doncella Que Vivio Tres Vidas” (The Young Maiden Who Lived Three Lives), a tamao, or supernatural being, takes the 16-year-old housemaid Pinang captive in his palace within a tamarind tree. Bucio the cook, Pinang’s mother, and Felipe, who is a servant in love with Pinang, attempt to rescue the girl with an incantation but to no avail. Three days later, Bucio cuts the tree trunk with an ax, and Pinang emerges but remains in a state of permanent bewilderment.

In “El Vaquero del Calatcat” (The Cowherd of Calatcat), Blas is the cowherd who dreams of marrying Doric. He raises a calf, Hada, which he plans to give as dowry to Doric’s parents. But Roque, a neighbor, stones and cripples Hada, which he has caught eating his rice crops. Vowing to take revenge on Roque, Blas transforms into a tic-tic, a self-segmenting ghoul. Roque’s family suffers from a series of misfortunes and deaths. When his one remaining son dies, Roque sets out to kill the tic-tic. He pours salt over the lower half of its body, preventing it from reconnecting with its upper half.

“La Leyenda del Camá-Camá” (The Legend of the Camá-Camá) is about how a boy became the first camá-camá, a small and mischievous creature. Ino-Dactu is a 10-year-old prince who sails for Jolo to rescue his parents from the Moros (Muslims). With the help of the heron Mahamut, a host of other animals, and his cousin Hamabul, he defeats the Moros and rescues his mother, although his father has died in captivity. Peace returns to their island. When Ino-Dactu’s mother dies, Mahamut uses her magic pearl to turn him into a heron, as he wishes. He transforms instead into a half-man and half-bird—the first camá-camá.

In “Mala Suerte” (Bad Luck), Jacinto is a native orphan who has been raised by the wealthy plantation-owning Gaiztegui family. The master’s extreme cruelty toward his workers would cause some of them to join the pulajanes, mountain rebels headed by Papa Isio. One night the pulajanes abduct the Gaiztegui men, and Jacinto is sent to ransom them. Several times on his way, he encounters the bagat, a shape-shifter that leads travelers astray. Jacinto never finds his abducted masters and himself disappears.

The final story of the book, “El Lunuk del Remanso Verde” (The Lunuk of the Green Haven), is also about a tamao. The story follows the Arruezos, a Spanish family that settles in Negros. Despite the overseer’s warnings, the master orders a giant lunuk (banyan) tree cut because it stunts the sugarcane growing around it. The tamao living inside the tree retaliates and kills the Spanish masters from one generation to the next.

The book is more than a collection of folkloric tales about supernatural beings. Rather, these are short stories with complex structures and symbolism carrying multilayered meanings. Moreover, it captures the culture of the people of Negros and, ultimately, that of the Filipino people who, despite having been colonized longer than they have been free, live by an indigenous worldview that bears their sense of cosmic justice and social order.  Written by Diego Abad
