article_title: Dagiti Kapintasan a Sarita iti Iluko
text:
(The Best Ilocano Short Stories). Published 1969. Editor, Gregorio C. Laconsay. Manila: GUMIL-Filipinas.

The book is a compilation of 30 prizewinning entries to the Bannawag short story contest in 1961-68. It contains a short introduction to “literature Ilokana” by Hermogenes F. Belen, and a list of judges preceding the texts of every year’s apit or harvest, referring to the stories. The stories were written by A. Sanchez Encarnacion, Pelagio A. Alcantara, Fredelito L. Lazo, John Nolar, Manuel S. Diaz, Benjamin F. Aurelio, Jose A. Bragado, Abraham Pasion, Gregorio G. Bermudez, Jose S. Singson, Meliton G. Brillantes, Crispina J. B. Bragado, Prescillano N. Bermudez, Samuel F. Corpuz, Mauro F. Guico, and Bienvenido C. Cabras.

The compilation marks the high level of development the modern Ilocano short story has taken since the early days of the maudlin, rhetorical, and lachrymose stories influenced by European metrical romances and romantic novels. Such romantico-religious tendencies may still have their imprint on the stories of A. Sanchez Encarnacion and Benjamin F. Aurelio, but the stories of Samuel Corpuz and Mauro F. Guico already point to a maturity of craft and outlook.  Written by Herminio Beltran Jr

article_title: Damdamin ni Corazon at Iba Pang Mga Kuwento
text:
(Corazon’s Feelings and Other Stories). Published 1997. Author, Gloria Villaraza Guzman. With an introduction by the author. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The stories in this collection were written between the 1940s and the 1990s. Most of the stories are about the experiences of women in various conditions: little girls living in an orphanage surrounded by thick walls in “Ang mga Ninya” (The Little Girls); a mother with mood swings akin to those of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde in “Manika” (Doll); the obsessively thrifty housewife in “Huling Karangyaan” (Last Extravagance); and a philanderer’s long-suffering wife in “Ito Pa Rin ang Dating Daigdig” (This Is Still the Old World).

Three short stories, written during World War II when she was still in her teens, display the young writer’s keen intelligence and the ability to create memorable moments. “Unang Tala” (First Star) centers on a character’s longing to see her brother, who has joined the fight against the Japanese. She finally accepts the permanence of her loss when she searches in vain for a star on a moonless night. “Ngumingiting Kabughawan” (A Smiling Blue) depicts Seni’s anger and barely hidden hatred of her father, who has been remiss in his duty. With a mother almost incapacitated by personal problems and with younger siblings dependent on Seni, a teenager, she feels resentful and oppressed. She gradually realizes, after talking to a close friend, that instead of self-pity and anger, she should try to understand an erring father and find it in her heart never to lose her love for him. In “Nakatakda ang mga Panahon” (The Seasons Are Appointed), a grandmother avoids a life of boredom and monotony by vicariously enjoying her granddaughter’s varied experiences.

It is, however, in “Damdamin ni Corazon” (Corazon’s Feelings), written in 1952, that Guzman goes against the usual characterization of women as being passive, totally devoted to their families, and willing to efface their identities in the service of other people. Corazon initially seems to fit the stereotype. An orphan, she has found refuge in a family. She is so grateful that she behaves more like a servant than a foster sister to the couple, Ramon and Anita. Don Miguel, Ramon’s uncle, who has come for a visit from Hawaii, finds Corazon’s excessive loyalty to be unhealthy. He offers her a position to manage his household in Hawaii. When she accepts the offer, Anita lets her go. Ramon becomes resentful and dispirited, and finally admits that it is Corazon he has been in love with all these years. Corazon admits that her subservience is a displacement of her love for Ramon.

Other stories similarly portray women who go against the grain. “Napapawi ng Panahon” (Erased by Time) is a story of three sisters, two of whom have children, while the third, childless and married to a drunkard, has an affair with her young boarder. The passage of time wipes away all traces of betrayal and disillusionment, as the husband accepts the wife’s daughter by the other man. “Munting Imahen” (A Little Image) details an office romance involving Lea, an employee who is never afraid to speak her mind, and the division chief, whose ire she has incurred. In “Sumisilip Na ang Ligaya” (Joy Is Peeping In), a fun-loving, adventurous, and vain 60-year-old woman brazenly bucks society’s expectations of an aging woman’s proper behavior.

Two stories about Filipino women abroad prove the scope and range of Gloria Villaraza’s power as a storyteller. “Iba Pa Rin ang Aming Bayan” (Our Place Is Still Different) tells of the initial culture shock that an uprooted Filipina experiences, and the transformation of second-generation Filipinos into “brown Americans.” “Dolorosa” examines the plight of a 36-year-old female overseas worker who is executed for killing her rapist.

article.value: (Corazon’s Feelings and Other Stories). Published 1997. Author, Gloria Villaraza Guzman. With an introduction by the author. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The stories in this collection were written between the 1940s and the 1990s. Most of the stories are about the experiences of women in various conditions: little girls living in an orphanage surrounded by thick walls in “Ang mga Ninya” (The Little Girls); a mother with mood swings akin to those of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde in “Manika” (Doll); the obsessively thrifty housewife in “Huling Karangyaan” (Last Extravagance); and a philanderer’s long-suffering wife in “Ito Pa Rin ang Dating Daigdig” (This Is Still the Old World).

Three short stories, written during World War II when she was still in her teens, display the young writer’s keen intelligence and the ability to create memorable moments. “Unang Tala” (First Star) centers on a character’s longing to see her brother, who has joined the fight against the Japanese. She finally accepts the permanence of her loss when she searches in vain for a star on a moonless night. “Ngumingiting Kabughawan” (A Smiling Blue) depicts Seni’s anger and barely hidden hatred of her father, who has been remiss in his duty. With a mother almost incapacitated by personal problems and with younger siblings dependent on Seni, a teenager, she feels resentful and oppressed. She gradually realizes, after talking to a close friend, that instead of self-pity and anger, she should try to understand an erring father and find it in her heart never to lose her love for him. In “Nakatakda ang mga Panahon” (The Seasons Are Appointed), a grandmother avoids a life of boredom and monotony by vicariously enjoying her granddaughter’s varied experiences.

It is, however, in “Damdamin ni Corazon” (Corazon’s Feelings), written in 1952, that Guzman goes against the usual characterization of women as being passive, totally devoted to their families, and willing to efface their identities in the service of other people. Corazon initially seems to fit the stereotype. An orphan, she has found refuge in a family. She is so grateful that she behaves more like a servant than a foster sister to the couple, Ramon and Anita. article_title: Deogracias A. Rosario: Ang Sining ng Maikling Kuwento
text:
(Deogracias A. Rosario: The Art of the Short Story). Published 1995. Author, Deogracias A. Rosario. Collected and with a critique by Romeo G. Dizon. Quezon City: University of the Philippines College of Arts and Letters.

A posthumous collection of 13 short stories by Deogracias A. Rosario, considered the “Father of the Tagalog Short Story,” the book shows the beginnings of the short story in Tagalog and follows Rosario’s writing career, which lasted from 1914 to 1936.

The first six stories, written between 1914 and 1926, show the romantic and sentimental moorings of Rosario’s short stories. “Dahil sa Pag-ibig” (Because of Love) depicts the tragic love affair between Federico Rodil, a violinist, and Nena Tekson, a soprano who goes to Boston on a scholarship; similarly, “Sa Taginting ng Jazz” (The Chime of Jazz) depicts the obsessive and self-destructive love that Pepito Sanchez, a jazz pianist, feels for the practical and ambitious Rita, a vaudeville actress. Ideal love triumphs against all of society’s vices in “Ang Dalawang Larawan sa May-ari ng Puso Ko” (The Two Images of the One Who Owns My Heart), in which Mario, a painter, rediscovers Beatriz, his first and true love, after being away in Rome; and in “Ang Babaing Nakadominong Itim” (The Woman in the Black Dress), where a mysterious woman guides Walfrido, a philandering husband, back to virtue and to his suffering wife and children.

The later seven stories, written between 1928 and 1936, still have love as their theme, but their scope includes critiques of Philippine society and American colonialism. In “Greta Garbo,” Rosario uses the character of Monina Vargas, who has modeled her looks and her life after Greta Garbo’s, to show the pernicious effects of fully embracing a modern way of life. “Walang Panginoon” (There Is No Lord) is the story of the struggles of Marcos, a farmer, to fight the oppressive landlord Don Teong. In “Aloha,” love transcends racial divides as Dan Merton, a white American, marries Noemi, a Kanaka or native Hawaiian, despite parental opposition.

Although some of his stories may be considered too didactic or sentimental today, Rosario introduced psychological depth in his characterization and used innovative techniques that highlight the social and cultural change brought about by American colonialism. The collection is thus an important testament to the early history of the Tagalog short story and Rosario’s contribution to its development.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda

text:
Published 2000. Author, Paz Latorena. Editor, Eva V. Kalaw. With an introduction by the author and a foreword by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

This is a collection of 35 short stories, published between 1927 and 1943, with one story undated, by one of the first Filipino women writers of fiction in English. Kalaw’s introduction notes that the stories’ female protagonists are married women who overcome the difficulties of marriage by their steadfastness. She observes that the faithful wife or mother is rewarded and the “erring” wife or mother, punished. Her other categories are the “woman as martyr” and the “woman as wife and mother.”

The stories themselves, however, exceed Kalaw’s commentary. Latorena avoids making pat judgments, choosing instead to let the reader enter the protagonist’s consciousness. In “Her Punishment?” a financially successful Magdalena returns after 20 years to her impoverished daughter, who rebuffs her. Magdalena wonders if this might be her punishment for her dereliction of duty as a mother, but the interrogative in the title and Magdalena’s back story leave the matter open.

Many of the stories probe the relations between the sexes, in particular, the misunderstandings, innocent or even well-meaning in origin but nonetheless devastating in their effect, between men and women in love. In “Desire,” which seems to epitomize the stories with this theme, the protagonist is pained to discover that the man she thought would love her “for herself” and not for her body confesses that it is her body, after all, that he desires. In “Her Hopeless Quest,” Malaya rejects Dr Arturo when she discovers that what appears to be his selfless concern for children is mere scientific curiosity. In a variation of this theme, Federico in “The Star” breaks up with Pacita to spare her the pain that he is certain he will inflict on her, he having loved and left “lesser stars” before.

A number of Latorena’s protagonists pit career with marriage, or ambition with love, and Latorena leaves the verdict open. In “Happiness,” a juxtaposition is made between Conchita’s artistic achievements and the sight of her old flame Federico, with his wife and child. In “For the Soul Is Dead,” the contrast made is between Rosita, who has stayed single, and Natalia, who gave up her music for marriage and family.

Perhaps influenced by her teacher Paz Marquez Benitez’s “Dead Stars,” Latorena returns time and again to the theme of the missed opportunity and the pang of belated realization. In “Prelude to Night,” Ester and Arturo, who is now married to Rosita and involved in politics, realize their mutual attraction too late.

Latorena is best known for “The Small Key,” “Sunset,” and “Desire,” the only stories of hers that had been anthologized with some frequency before the publication of this collection and which are still arguably her best work. The collection allows readers certain discoveries into the craft of Latorena which reading single stories precludes. One sees, for example, that Latorena periodically returns to certain plot situations and even recycles passages. Thus, “Two Gifts” is “The Small Key” revisited and given an O. Henryesque twist. “Plight” is a streamlined version of “The Way of Man” and an homage to Sherwood Anderson’s story “Hands,” from which it borrows a sentence.

Of special interest to scholars is that the collection includes the original published versions of “The Small Key” and “Sunset,” which differ from the versions that are found in anthologies and textbooks.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: A Different Voice: Fiction by Young Filipino Writers
text:
Published 2007. Editor, Vicente Garcia Groyon. With an introduction by the editor. Manila: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House.

Although published during the 50th anniversary of Philippine PEN, which had last published an anthology of Philippine fiction in 1962, the book is not intended to continue from that collection. Per its introduction, “What the anthology hopes to present instead is a composite image of contemporary Philippine fiction in English, and suggest what the future of Philippine fiction in English could be.”

“A Reply to a Query” by Douglas Candano borrows the form of a report to unfold a teenager’s transformation into a crone, the details sourced from tales of the engkanto (supernatural creature) and folktales from other cultures. “The Last Days of Magic” by Ian Rosales Casocot is a parable set in the magical town of Daguet, which admonishes readers not to lose the passionate pursuit of art. “A Ghost Story” by Francezwa C. Kwe tells the story through the sightings and tales of ghosts that lurk in the ancestral home of a family destroyed by World War II. “FLAMES” by Angelo R. Lacuesta reveals an adolescent girl’s attempt to define and understand relationships through the FLAMES game as she witnesses the disintegration of her parents’ marriage. Gabriela Lee’s “Hunger” likens a woman’s carnal desires to the nightly hunt of an aswang. “The Dues to the Unbound” by Pocholo Goitia is set in a distant future where human beings cheat death by having their organs replaced. In Carljoe Javier’s “The Master of the Fragfest,” a video gamer must adjust his solitary lifestyle to take care of his younger sister.

Some stories present the economic and social quandaries of overseas Filipino workers. “Burgundy” by Dennis Andrew S. Aguinaldo follows a driver’s struggle to recover the money he lost to a predatory placement agency. In Maria L. Fres-Felix’s “Boys in the Platinum Palace,” two men, who were separated by class in the Philippines, are equally second-class citizens as physical therapists in the United States. In Lakambini Sitoy’s “Sisters,” the desire for a better life leads one sister to find a foreign spouse through the Internet.

Love, loss, and lust are the themes of a few stories. Francis Paolo Quina’s “Hang Ups” is a metafictional piece that dares the reader to taste the pleasures of the flesh, but not without questioning one’s gender orientation. U. Z. Eliserio’s “Nostos” deals with the complications of Platonic and romantic relationships. In Bj A. Patiño’s “A Death in the Opposite House,” a teenage boy awakens to sexual desire, as he observes his attractive young neighbor, whose mother he strikes a friendship with. In Lourdes Parawan’s “Train,” the goings and comings of the MRT capture the physical and emotional distance between two writers.

Darker realities are depicted in other stories. In Paolo Enrico S. Melendez’s “His Brother’s Keeper,” an angry man takes justice into his own hands. Joshua Lim So’s “Radio Days” takes readers to the terrors of the martial law period. In Jonathan Jimena Siason’s “Going Guinness,” a Muslim boy hopes to make a name for himself by breaking a Guinness world record.

The personal, political, and economic struggles of Filipino women are depicted in Ava Vivian Gonzales’s “Out of This World,” where a woman pretends that an alien has taken over her husband’s body, thus excusing his cold and inappropriate behavior; in Timothy Montes’s “The Housemaid,” where a teenage girl working as a maid to pay her father’s debt discovers what else her services are worth; and in Anna Felicia C. Sanchez’s “Inventories,” where a woman comes to terms with her daughter’s death by immersing herself in anime.

The book showcases the work of writers who have been formally trained in university creative writing programs and workshops here and abroad. The voices are those of an educated and urbanized middle class, but the topics and the variety of techniques they use add to the growing range of Philippine fiction in English. Whether tragic, fantastic, economic, or erotic, these stories urge readers to rethink such situations.  Written by Angela L. Velasco

article_title: The Distance to Andromeda and Other Stories
text:
Published 1960. Author, Gregorio Brillantes. With an introduction by N. V. M. Gonzalez. Manila: Benipayo Press. Reprinted, Manila: National Book Store, 1980; Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 2000.

The short stories in this collection raise questions about “those senseless accidents of pain,” as the author puts in his story “Faith, Love, Time and Doctor Lazaro.” In Brillantes’s own commentary, the distances are those “between human beings and between them and God, their ultimate destiny”; but always they end with an affirmation of “life as movement toward a destination, life as pilgrimage.”

Brillantes’s characters live as strangers in the midst of a familiar crowd of relatives and friends, unable to communicate with one another. Except for Ben’s family in the title story, the family in the stories is usually portrayed not as an entity but as a mere aggregate of either indifferent or conflicting forces. Despite attempts to reach out, the characters drift away from one another. “The Exiles” shows the growing alienation between family members and from other members of a society which they find themselves trapped in. The old man escapes through dreams of the old country; his daughter, through romance; his son, through the priesthood. In “Faith, Love, Time and Doctor Lazaro,” the doctor ironically fails to sympathize with his own patients, having been made numb by rote, and catches a glimpse of the sensitivity he has lost, and will not ever recover, in his son.

But always there is a moment of illumination for them, whether it be a “glimmer … lost instantly,” as in “Faith, Love, Time and Doctor Lazaro” or a more definite revelation, as bright as a “shooting star,” as tangible as “the unseen presence of One who loves him infinitely and tenderly,” as in “The Distance to Andromeda.” In the title story, 13-year-old Ben leaves the cinema with a sense of the universe’s vastness and his own insignificance, but feels also God’s protection. A similar experience is recounted in “Sunday,” when the boy Juan visits the town to listen to a speech delivered in a language he cannot understand, only to realize that what ultimately matters requires no words.

Because the stories do not contain a plot in the traditional sense, their evocative power is created by a lyrical style, symbolism, and the Joycean epiphany. These are stories in which nothing seems to happen, as some students of literature might complain. Their meaning, however, is to be found in the form; that is, the way the seemingly random details are unified by narrative and poetic technique and by the psychological coherence of the characters.  Written by David Jonathan Bayot and Jonathan Chua

 

Source

Bernad, Miguel, SJ. 1961. Bamboo and the Greenwood Tree: Essays on Filipino Literature in English. Manila: Bookmark.

article_title: Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, 1980-1989: Antolohiya ng Mga Nagwaging Akda, Dekada 80; Maikling Kuwento
text:
(Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, 1980-1989: Anthology of Winning Works, The 1980s; Short Story). Published 1990. Pasig: Carlos Palanca Foundation.

An anthology of 34 short stories in Filipino that won the annual Palanca Awards in the 1980s, the book is an important source for an understanding of the development of literary styles and thematic preoccupations of this chapter in Philippine literary history.

The stories revolve around some key issues, such as poverty and exploitation, which breed desperate individuals who may be driven to violence. In Benjamin Pascual’s “Di Mo Masilip ang Langit” (You Can’t Get a Glimpse of Heaven), a mason is jailed for burning down the hospital whose staff left his wife unattended while she was in labor.

Psychological realism is the mode in which criminals are portrayed with compassion by the authors. In Al S. Mendoza’s “Ang Tornilyo sa Utak ni Rufo Sabater” (The Screw in Rufo Sabater’s Brain), an auto mechanic who becomes mentally unhinged by the dehumanizing conditions at work stabs his employer and is shot to death in turn. In Lualhati Bautista’s “Buwan, Buwan, Hulugan Mo Ako ng Sundang” (Moon, Moon, Drop Me a Dagger), Angela is released from the mental hospital after 10 years, only to be locked up again for murdering her husband. “Tatlong Kuwento ng Buhay ni Julian Candelabra” (Three Stories about Julian Candelabra’s Life) depicts the titular character’s failed but earnest attempts at living honorably despite poverty, which drives him to commit theft, adultery, and finally murder.

The oppressive condition of overseas contract workers is the material for Fanny Garcia’s “Arrivederci.” Other stories critique capitalism. Cyrus Borja’s “Sugat sa Dagat” (A Wound in the Sea) exposes the deadly operations of a company engaged in dynamite fishing. In Noel D. Salonga’s “Minero” (Miner), some residents of a community give their lands over for a company to mine but are abandoned when the demand for coal drops, and they become prey to an illegal contractor.

article_title: Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: An Anthology of Winning Works, the 1980s; Short Story
text:
Published 2000. Pasig: Carlos Palanca Foundation Inc.

The stories in this anthology, winners at the annual Palanca Awards, are a stark reminder of the troubled 1980s and represent a continuation of a persistent theme in Philippine fiction—social unrest and struggle. The decade saw the height and decline of martial law, the EDSA Revolt of 1986, and the various problems left behind by the Marcos dictatorship.

The stories can be divided between the pre-EDSA and post-EDSA years. The pre-EDSA winning stories are concerned with the social problems brought about by military rule. The winners of 1981 may be said to comprise the strongest set of stories in this anthology. “In Hog Heaven” by Jessie Garcia (first prize) is about the unusual friendship between a young man trying to find his own path in life and a blind girl living with her alcoholic father. They reside in a condemned building in Manila, and the story rapidly becomes both a record of Manila’s decline as a city and a criticism of social inequality. The story makes skillful use of contrasts, especially when beautiful language is used to describe ugliness. “The Party-Hopper” by Luning Bonifacio-Ira (second prize) follows a newly dead woman as she tries very hard to get her partying friends to see her or to talk about her. The story’s surrealism is balanced by its depiction of the hypocrisy not only of the upper classes but also of the woman’s ghost herself as she cares more about the parties that she is missing and not the fact that she is inconveniently dead. “In These Hallowed Halls” by Jesus Cruz (third prize) details the life of Jim Castro, a young professor thrown into campus politics owing to the possible expulsion of a student. The story depicts the corruption of a system that is supposed to be a haven for intellectuals and higher thought. Jim Castro is so caught up in his history lectures that he nearly misses a chance to engage in real events unfolding right before him.

Gregorio Brillantes’s “Stranger in an Asian City” (third prize, 1984), perhaps best captures the spirit of the times. This was a time when nearly all the nations in Asia were under the yoke of dictatorships. Thus, a simple conference in another Asian country gets a Filipino representative into trouble. Brillantes’s story shows its readers that, in this regard, there are no differences at all between the Philippines and any other place in Asia. In contrast, his “The Flood in Tarlac,” which won the first prize in 1987, dramatizes the long-running problem of abused and exploited farmers in the haciendas of Central Luzon.

The 1980s saw the rise of Jose Y. Dalisay as one of the country’s brightest literary stars. In this decade alone, he received five Palanca awards for the short story: three first prizes for “Heartland,” 1982, “Oldtimer,” 1983, and “Merlie,” 1986; and two second prizes for “The Other Side,” 1986, and “The Body,” 1987. While all these stories showcase Dalisay’s well-polished prose, they dwell on different themes: alienation from one’s own country, the rise of insurgency in the rural areas, and the widening gap between the poor and the rich in the cities.

Two other writers would emerge in the latter part of the decade. Eli Ang Barroso would win three prizes for “A Nobel Prize for Jorge Luis Borges,” second prize, 1985; “The Bird Lover of City Hall,” third prize, 1987; and “Our Lady of the Arts and Letters” first prize, 1988. The other writer is Charlson Ong, who would write about the identity struggles of the Filipino-Chinese community and would be rewarded by three third prizes: “Men of the East,” 1985; “Another Country,” 1987; and “Owl,” 1989.

To this day, the Palanca remains the country’s most prestigious literary prize as it keeps its doors open to the writers of the past, as well as celebrates the arrival of the writers of the future. While often seen as a bastion of middle-class literary snobbery, the winning entries belie such a view as they continue speaking about the many struggles that our nation and our society face in an ever-changing world.

A companion book in Filipino is Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, 1980-1989: Antolohiya ng mga Nagwaging Akda, Dekada 80; Maikling Kuwento (Don Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature, 1989-1989: Anthology of Winning Works, The 1980s; Short Story), 1990.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: Feast and Famine: Stories of Negros
text:
Published 2003. Author, Rosario Cruz-Lucero. With an afterword by Linda Kintanar-Alburo. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for fiction, 2004.

The stories in this collection of five stories capture Negrense life, history, culture, cuisine, myths, customs, and stark class contradictions in effortlessly postmodern fashion.

The friar in “The Death of Fray Salvador Montano, Conquistador of Negros” struggles with temptation, superstition, a dwindling congregation, censorship, bird droppings falling from the ceiling beams, masturbation, the pressure of having to produce a dictionary, forgetfulness, and even aphasia. Estrella, the village babaylan and epic chanter, is his nemesis but also his confidant and consultant—the stars to his mountain. The tension that exists between them is spiritual as well as sexual. She is another one of the many temptations he fends off in his quest to be as strong as the long and hard bell tower erected by his predecessor Fray Duertas (alluded to in all the other stories). His lifelong struggle against temptation ends in his deathbed, in the arms of Estrella, and with the realization that the temptation he fought off all his life is both Yawa and Yahweh.

Three narratives make up “Doreen’s Story.” Real-life food critic Doreen Fernandez sits in a restaurant with the story’s narrator and recounts over sandwich and iced tea the story of Anabella of Silay (the second and main narrative). The telling of this second narrative is also interrupted by discussions of the narrator-writer with a real-life literary scholar about the accuracy of the details of the story. The main character itself is named after the eponymous protagonist of a short story written by a reclusive Negrense woman writer Magdalena Jalandoni. Anabella, an heiress, is a Miss Emily-like figure, with a whip-wielding father and a hysterical soprano mother. Doreen plays epic chanter in this story, but the reader is reminded, just at the right moment, that this is also just a cleverly crafted piece of artifice. The story is therefore a fine example of metafiction.

“The Oracle of the One-Eyed Coconut” begins with the assassination of Mayor Pedro Soler the Fourth. As the story unfolds, we hear the accounts of the mayor’s wife, the priest, and the hacienda manager, and we learn about the scoundrel that was the mayor. “Oracle” has the flavor of Rashomon where each account is like a piece of the puzzle, but it offers the possibility of puzzle solved. While Captain Baby Baltazar, who investigates the assassination, misreads all of the clues, Estrellita, the village soothsayer, healer and composo singer, sees all of the truth.

“Good Husbands and Obedient Wives” depicts the hypocrisy of pious folk and the duplicities of Negros hacendero life and of married life in general. As Divina goes back home to Negros and gets in touch with her high-school friends Rene and Lita, she is at first taken by the neatness of Lita’s life. Rene, the good husband and good provider, is always encouraging of his wife; Lita, the obedient wife, dutifully cooks her husband’s favorite dishes and cross-stitches drawer upon drawer of cocktail napkins. Lita’s continual avowals of her happiness and of Rene’s goodness mask a hideous lie.

“The Composo of Hacienda Buyung” consists of six composo, each telling a story that is interrelated to the rest. It begins with what appears to be a story of spurned love and a missing treasure, but as composo and counter-composo are sung, a picture of Negros life emerges, including its less savory aspects: “salvaging” or summary executions, corrupt politicians, foreign aid that intensifies poverty. Alongside the eccentrics who live in the “big house” are the common folk who create myths and sing composo—including the ones the reader is reading—about those eccentrics. The mysteries, conflicting versions, and unanswered questions are cleverly settled in the last three paragraphs, giving readers a satisfying sense of closure.

Feast and Famine is a remarkable collection that treats the precarious relationship between orality and writing. These stories—like no other in Philippine literature written in English—celebrate and replicate the power of telling stories and creating legends.

“The Death of Fray Salvador Montano, Conquistador of Negros” and “Doreen’s Story” received first prizes at the Palanca Awards in 2001 and 2003, respectively. “Good Husbands and Obedient Wives” and “The Oracle of the One-Eyed Coconut” received first prizes at the Philippines Free Press Literary Awards in 2002 and 2004, respectively.  Written by Maria Teresa P. Tinio

article_title: Flores de Mayo: Tatlong Piling Kwento
text:
(Flowers of May: Three Chosen Stories). Published 2003. Author, Cua Ching Tam. Translator, Joaquin Sy. Manila: Kaisa Para Sa Kaunlaran Inc.

In this collection of short stories, Tam explores an issue central to the Filipino-Chinese experience and identity. The Chinese living in the “island of coconuts and bananas” are confronted by the question of loyalty. Where should the Chinese spend the rest of their lives: in a province in China where their ancestors had come from or in their adopted country, the Philippines, where they have been raised for decades? The three stories are told in first-person point of view, with a narrator who is well-educated, has a deep understanding of Philippine culture and tradition, and is involved in society.

When the Chinese boy in “Flores de Mayo” (Flowers of May) witnesses the Flores de Mayo procession, his father tells him that it is not part of his culture. From there on the boy is aware of his difference. Nevertheless, he makes an effort to be part of the local tradition by blending in with the community and eventually becoming an hermano mayor (literally, “elder brother”), or the host of the festival. The problem of alienation is resolved when, as a father with two sons, he joins the community in the yearly tradition. He sheds his insecurity of being the only Chinese in the village and disproves perceptions of his lack of inclination for the arts, history, and culture.

“Dalawang Henerasyon” (Two Generations), set in the context of the tensions between China and the Philippines over the Spratly Islands, follows a Chinese adolescent living in the Philippines. He receives basic military training. The boy is made to choose between his native China and his adopted Philippines.

In “Ang Landas” (The Path), an ethnic Chinese who has been living in the Philippines for over three decades remembers a tragic incident: his best friend, a fellow ethnic Chinese making a living by selling goods in his small grocery, was robbed and brutally killed by a Filipino. Over time, the man loses friends and colleagues to violence, eventually causing him to consider returning to China. In the end, however, the protagonist recognizes his strong connection with his adopted country and decides to stay in the Philippines.

While the stories depict colonial oppression, discrimination, social division, and alienation experienced by Chinese Filipinos, the actions of Tam’s characters symbolize the conscious choice of the Chinese community to integrate itself with Philippine society. With their trust in and loyalty to the Philippines challenged by tradition, personal circumstance, and their stature in society, the characters ultimately emerge as Chinese Filipinos united with their country and their countryfolk.  Written by Jeffrey Yap

article_title: Ang Gakit ni Noebong ug Ubang Mga Sugilanon
text:
(The Raft of Noebong and Other Stories). Published 2008. Author, Saturnino P. Apoyon. With a preface by the author. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

This is a collection of 13 Cebuano stories about Mindanao, with a sympathetic understanding of the lives of its characters: the Bagobo and Tiruray of the hinterlands, the Badjao sea gypsies, barrio folk and city folk whose morality is challenged by armed conflicts, clashes between Christian and indigenous belief systems, industrialization, and poverty. The stories are set in a place called Daba-Daba (Davao City’s former name) and its neighboring places, and in periods both past and present.

In the first two stories, Apoyon uses the human instinct for survival to trigger a plot that quickly becomes a study of the human psyche. In “Mga Gutom” (The Hungry Ones), Mundo hunts down a dog for its meat after he is displaced from his job by the town’s newly elected administration. In “Dili Alang Kang David ang Baboy Ihalas” (The Wild Boar Is Not for David), a simple search for food becomes a battle for supremacy when David, a determined novice hunter, attempts to wrest a wild boar from a python’s grip.

The stories “Ang Jihad ni Hadji Aribani” (The Jihad of Hadji Aribani), “Ang Sakit ni Mystika Brillante” (The Disease of Mystika Brillante), and “Ang Dagon ni Atorni Agaton” (The Amulet of Attorney Agaton) feature characters whose moral integrity, or lack thereof, is either tested or corrupted by their own primal urges. In “Ang Tinagoan ni Pocholo” (The Hidden Treasure of Pocholo), a man tries to hide the disfiguring repercussion of his infidelity. In “Ang Anak sa Wakwak” (The Daughter of the Wakwak), the narrator falls in love with a woman despite the rumors that her mother is a mythical monster.

Crime and other forms of lawlessness are the subjects of the succeeding stories. In “Gumikan sa Iyang Baroganan” (Upon His Grounding Principles), a poor man trying to provide for his newborn triplets becomes instrumental in solving a case of robbery. In “Timawi” (The Poor), members of a street gang assault a Badjao musician who has come to the city to make a living. In “Baldo ug ang Manok ni Tasyo” (Baldo and Tasyo’s Chicken), an erstwhile principled man steals his neighbor’s chicken in a desperate attempt to feed his children. “Ang Magtiayon sa Bakilid” (The Couple in the Valley) shows an ordinary couple whose lives are disrupted by the arrival of armed insurgents. “Si Bandoyong ug ang Kataposang Lasang” (Bandoyong and the Last Forest) tells the story of Bandoyong who heroically defends his property from land-grabbers. Bandoyong’s resolve to protect his ancestors’ land lives on in his son.

In the title story “Ang Gakit ni Noebong” (The Raft of Noebong), the protagonist builds a raft to prepare for a great flood that his neighbors, most of whom are Christian converts, merely dismiss. Saturnino Apoyon is one of the first writers to depict in Cebuano fiction the complex realities of settlers and indigenous peoples in Mindanao. His stories are written in a vivid and highly metaphorical language that attempts to capture a worldview unique to Mindanao’s indigenous communities. Apoyon employs his knowledge in philosophy, politics, and history in describing the seemingly humdrum existence of his characters whose fates are altered by the clash of cultures and the consequences of modernity.  Written by Hazel Meghan Hamile and John Bengan

article_title: The Golden Loom: Palanca Prize Winners for Children
text:
Published 1997. Makati City: Tahanan Books for Young Readers.

This anthology consists of 10 stories that won prizes in the children’s story category of the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature from 1991 to 1996. Ten artists provide illustrations for the stories.

Four stories are about the importance of one’s roots and heritage. In Carla M. Pacis’s “Dreamweavers,” 1994, the inhabitants of an Itneg village lose the ability to dream when they lose their only dreamweaver. In Marivi Soliven Blanco’s “Chun,” 1992, a Chinese boy, shunned by his Filipino peers, wins and ultimately rejects their begrudging admiration. In Angelo Lacuesta’s “Pandesal Saves the Day,” 1995, an insecure girl named Pandesal is given a chance to prove herself to her far more privileged classmates after a school trip goes awry. In Maria Elena Paterno’s “The Blanket,” 1991, a young Igorot girl about to leave home for the big city listens to the stories of her mother and grandmother as they weave her a farewell blanket.

Two stories are about friendship. Ino M. Manalo’s “Little Bird, Little Fish, and the Two Elephants,” 1993, tells the story of a friendship formed between two children and two elephants, all of them far away from home. And Lakambini Sitoy’s “Pure Magic,” 1996, is about a girl named Mirava who collects magic spells—precious little doodads and tokens—to save her friend from a grievous illness.

The other stories are filled with fantasy and the supernatural. In Lacuesta’s “The Daughters of the Wind,” 1996, a young typhoon with all the potential for destruction and chaos chooses a gentler path. In Leoncio Deriada’s “The Man Who Hated Birds,” 1994, all the birds of a forest exact their revenge on a man who has been cruel to them. In Luna B. Diaz de Rivera’s “The Gem,” 1996, a girl receives divine help when she loses a precious family heirloom by the river. And in Twink Macaraig’s “What Is Serendipity,” 1994, a little girl searches for the meaning of “serendipity” in everyday things, believing it would bring her mother great happiness.

The stories display careful handling of potentially difficult themes while retaining a sense of childlike wonderment that would appeal to younger readers.  Written by Katrina del Rosario

article_title: Good Character and Bad Character: The Manobo Storytelling Audience as Society's Jurors
text:
Published 1993. Author, Hazel J. Wrigglesworth and Pengenda Mengsenggilid. Special monograph issue, Philippine Journal of Linguistics, no 34. Manila: Linguistic Society of the Philippines.

The book is a collection of six stories told by the raconteuse Mengsenggilid, and recorded by Wrigglesworth during formal Manobo storytelling performances. Presented in both the original Manobo and English translation, the narratives, which were handed down from generation to generation, are also parables to aid in resolving custom-law cases of the Ilianen Manobo.

The first tale, “Bad Character (Girl) and Good Character (Girl),” consists of four episodes: first, the younger Mepiya Bawa (Good Character [Girl]) invites her sister Meraat Bawa (Bad Character [Girl]) to go out to do various chores with her but Meraat Bawa always refuses. Mepiya Bawa, therefore, always sets out alone.

Mepiya Bawa meets other characters who return her good behavior with kindness and generosity. Jealous of her sister’s good fortune, Meraat Bawa sets out to do the same tasks. She meets the same characters, but, because of her greed, rudeness, and selfishness, she fails in the tasks that her sister before her has successfully performed.

Of equal importance to this storytelling are the responses of the audience, whose comments, exclamations, and interjections are their own contribution to the total effect of the stories being told. Their reactions are transcribed. For example, the audience replies, “Mepiya ma!” (Now that’s really good [a good way to act]!), in praise of Mepiya Bawa’s decision not to pick bananas in a field without asking the owner first; “Ne, inteng kew ki Meraat Bawa!” (Now, all of you, look at Meraat Bawa [and what she’s doing]!), to draw attention to Meraat Bawa’s poor judgment in not washing her net properly; and “Ne be!” (Keep going!), to encourage the storyteller to continue, in their anticipation of the next events, especially during peak points in the plot. These responses transform the audience into jurors who reinforce Manobo values and culture as they judge the acts, either good or bad, committed by the story’s characters.

The other stories are “Wide-back,” a tale of two heroes who punish a hunchbacked villain for constantly stealing their catch of fishes; “Child of a Hermit,” which introduces a clever boy who replaces the chief of a kingdom by outwitting him in a series of impossible tasks; “The Monkey and the Terigtig-Bird” (tarictic hornbill), in which the feathered protagonist finds a way to escape the predatory monkey; “Tulalang,” which narrates the betrothal of the Manobo epic hero Tulalang to a princess, according to Manobo custom law; and “The Hermit,” a humorous tale about a giant couple who seize an aged man whom they mistake for a child.

Content footnotes provide historical, cultural, and semantic information. Each story is classified according to Aarne and Thompson’s classification of tale types. The book’s introduction also provides ample information about the raconteuse. Significant are the discussions on her extensive narrative repertoire and her skill at employing a variety of rhetorical devices. Dramatic irony and tense shifts, for example, are cleverly used to encourage audience participation throughout an entire night.

Thus, the book not only preserves an important part of Philippine oral literature but also invites the reader to sit and partake in the storytelling, which is an essential part of Manobo community life.   Written by Om Narayan Velasco

text:
Published 2001. Author, Loreto Paras-Sulit. Editor, Edna Zapanta Manlapaz. With an introduction by the editor. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

Loreto Paras-Sulit was arguably the most prolific short story writer of her generation, but until the publication of this book she had not had a single-author collection to her name. This book gathers together 53 of her stories, the earliest dated 1926 and the latest, among those whose dates are known, 1946. Included are five undated stories hitherto available only in manuscript at the Ateneo Library of Women’s Writings. A bibliography lists the titles of other stories by Paras-Sulit that have yet to be recovered. The book also includes a chronology of Paras-Sulit’s life and an essay by Paras-Sulit titled “All about Me,” which briefly recounts her writing and private life.

The collection proper allows modern readers an overview of Paras-Sulit’s craft and preoccupations. Duality is a recurrent theme, dramatized in three of her most famous stories. The contrasting visions of life held by the brothers Fabian and Vidal in “Harvest” can only be reconciled in the art of Miss Francia. In “Balthazar,” the rivals Lourdes and Medina—the one serene, the other fervent, both beloved by the same man—are brought together by Eduardo’s enigmatic parting gift. In “The Bolo,” a crisis momentarily estranges one sister from another, one standing for idealism and the other, practicality.

Romantic love figures in most of the stories. In treating the subject, Paras-Sulit ranges from the melodramatic—resorting to surprise revelations, grand confrontations, and exclamatory dialogue—to the restrained. In “A Night’s Vigil,” Jose proves his devotion to Nany by saving the man that she desires, an act which ironically debars him from ever marrying her. The author uses the flashback-monologue device to heighten the drama. In “By His Own Way,” Roberto, a medical student, gets a girl pregnant but refuses to marry her, much to his father’s disappointment. In “The Flaw-Hunter,” a woman switches a fake diamond for a real one to help her bankrupt husband. The jeweler’s assistant turns out to be her ex-lover. Comparable to these stories are “In Other Tongue,” “Not Yet,” “White Lace,” “The Years Are Many,” and “When East Loved West.”

At the other end is “Interlude,” where love quietly blossoms amid harsh surroundings. A chance meeting with a woman washing her clothes effects a change in Martin, a construction worker. Paras-Sulit prevents the story from sinking into sentimentality by shifting the point of view, hitherto Martin’s, to an observer’s in the final paragraph.

The more comic aspects of love are treated in “Love and the Carabao,” “Cupid in Balloon Pants,” and “The Softening of Tandang Petra.” Defying neat classification are the other stories depicting sundry themes, such as truth-telling (“The Keeper”), forgiveness (“Eyes of the Man”), rivalry and jealousy (“The Call”), modernity versus tradition (“The Bridge”), illusion and reality (“Of a Far Country”). In these, Paras-Sulit is sensitive to the mixed motivations behind human actions and refrains from casting the first stone.

Some stories are occasional, like “His Prisoner” (for Rizal Day), about a jail warden from whose eyes Jose Rizal removes a boil; “Wings of Gabriel” (for Christmas), about a father’s discovery that he has a special child who sings every Christmas Eve; and “Eloi,” (for Easter), about a man who neglects his wife to listen to Jesus. Also included are high romances set in precolonial Philippines: “The Song of the Arrow,” which has elements of magic, and “Laarni—A Dream,” the story that made Paras-Sulit a household name in 1926. The postwar stories show a more morally complex universe. “She Shall Have Peace” asks whether forgiveness is possible after great atrocities; “The Woman Whom War Passed By” asks whether being physically safe during the war could be spiritually destructive.

Harvest and Other Stories shows not only an individual writer’s growing breadth and depth over a 20-year span but also that of the literary tradition to which she belonged.  Written by Jonathan Chua

article_title: Heartbreak and Magic: Stories of Fantasy and Horror
text:
Published 2011. Author, Ian Rosales Casocot. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This collection of stories examines loss and the many ways it can occur in one’s life. Most belong to the subgenre called “speculative”; they link such losses to that magical quality that defines humanity and thus speak about real human affairs. The magic or fantasy serves only as backdrop for the stories of heartbreak. Few of the characters actually undergo changes; they are either idealistic or dysfunctional. However, the flat characterization serves to enhance either a story’s comedic or its magical elements. In “Tragedy of Chickens,” the flatness of the characters adds to the humor as the story focuses on the vanishing of chickens.

In “The Flicker,” the collection’s only true horror story, the main character is a community that has long buried a dark secret, but now that secret is claiming its children. At first, the adults deny the possibility of a haunted house, but evidence soon mounts. As the corruption of the Ballesteros house soon spreads, parents begin taking desperate measures to ensure their safety. References to the Marcoses are perhaps the author’s attempt to show how this family’s corruption has seeped into the consciousness of a generation of Filipinos.

The last story, “The Sugilanon of Epefania’s Heartbreak,” placed second in the 2007 Fully Booked Neil Gaiman Philippine Graphic Fiction Awards. But the story that best sums up this collection is “The Last Days of Magic,” which placed third at the Palanca Awards for children’s short story in 2007. In it, Kulas’s incorruptibility amid squalid circumstances is the reason that he alone understands why magic has lost its place in the world. In this story, magic is the power of art: its colors, sounds, visions, and words.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife and Other Stories
text:
Published 1940. Author, Manuel E. Arguilla. With an introduction by A. V. H. Hartendorp. Manila: Philippine Book Guild, 1940, 1941, 1946, 1963. Reprinted, Manila: De La Salle University Press, 1998.

This collection of short stories won first prize in the 1940 Commonwealth Literary Contests. The stories can be divided under three headings: the Nagrebcan stories, the stories of love and marriage, and the protest stories. The Nagrebcan stories are rich in local color and deal with the life, problems, customs, and traditions of the rural folk. Well-known stories in this category include “Midsummer,” “A Son Is Born,” “Morning in Nagrebcan,” and the best-known of Arguilla’s stories, “How My Brother Leon Brought Home a Wife.” The stories of the second category explore the problems confronted by married couples or lovers. These include “Me, Alisangco,” “Though Young He Is Married,” and “The Maid, the Man, and the Wife.” The protest stories portray individual human problems within a social and economic context, and show the capitalist or feudal system to be essentially oppressive to the working or tenant class. Better-known stories in this category include “Caps and Lower Case,” “Rice,” and “The Socialists.”

Hartendorp, in his introduction, praises Arguilla’s masterly use of the English language, “almost as if it were a Philippine dialect.” The most remarkable aspect of this mastery, however, is his appropriation of not only this foreign language but also the conventions of the Western short story genre in order to record authentic Filipino experience, whether in a rural or urban setting. The movements and speech of the characters represent Filipino thought and feeling, and folklore and myth are seamlessly woven into the story material. Metaphors evoke the Filipino scene.

Perhaps the most enduring legacy of the collection is this line from the title story, one of the most oft-quoted lines from any Philippine short story: “the fragrance of her was like a morning when papayas are in bloom.”  Written by David Jonathan Bayot and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

These include “Me, Alisangco,” “Though Young He Is Married,” and “The Maid, the Man, and the Wife.” The protest stories portray individual human problems within a social and economic context, and show the capitalist or feudal system to be essentially oppressive to the working or tenant class. Better-known stories in this category include “Caps and Lower Case,” “Rice,” and “The Socialists.”

Hartendorp, in his introduction, praises Arguilla’s masterly use of the English language, “almost as if it were a Philippine dialect.” The most remarkable aspect of this mastery, however, is his appropriation of not only this foreign language but also the conventions of the Western short story genre in order to record authentic Filipino experience, whether in a rural or urban setting. The movements and speech of the characters represent Filipino thought and feeling, and folklore and myth are seamlessly woven into the story material. Metaphors evoke the Filipino scene.

Perhaps the most enduring legacy of the collection is this line from the title story, one of the most oft-quoted lines from any Philippine short story: “the fragrance of her was like a morning when papayas are in bloom.”  Written by David Jonathan Bayot and Rosario Cruz-Lucero

text:
Published 1983. Author, Nick Joaquin. Manila: Cacho Hermanos

Ten of the stories in this collection of 15 were individually published under the series Pop Stories for Groovy Kids in 1979 to commemorate the International Year of the Child. The stories are delightful retellings of fairy tales and folktales. Joaquin localizes and updates, turning Cinderella into Ela Uling and Snow White into Blanca Nieve. Joaquin also draws on Philippine folk and urban lore; thus one finds Bernardo Carpio, Maria Makiling, the aswang, and Balite Drive here. The stories do not merely retell familiar tales, however. Joaquin cleverly combines narrative lines of different tales and reinterprets traditional figures. Thus, the manananggal (self-segmenting ghoul) in “The Traveling Salesman and the Split Woman” is an angel cursed for falling in love with a mortal, her lower half being bound to earth and her upper half flying up to pursue “the life of the spirit.”

Unlike fairy tales, which are set in an indefinite time and place, Joaquin’s stories bear the fingerprints of the era, the 1970s in the Philippines, particularly Manila. Doy’s jeep, in “Traveling Salesman,” is called “Jeeprox,” after the slang word jeproks, meaning “cool” or “hip”; and Culas-Culasito’s parents, in “The Adventures of Culas-Culasito,” appear in a TV sitcom called Joanne and Marcial, a send-up of John and Marsha.

As stories originally intended for children, they carry life lessons, sometimes expressed aphoristically. Thus, in “Johnny Tiñoso and the Proud Beauty,” an adaptation of “Beauty and the Beast,” Bellita learns that not “only the lovable are to be loved.” In “Sarimanok versus Ibong Adarna,” Joaquin enters the psychology of the adolescent as he depicts the popularity contest between Elsie, who “owns” Ibong Adarna, and Nanette, who “owns” Sarimanok. The rivalry intensifies until the two girls encounter the real Sarimanok and Ibong Adarna.

Some of the stories, however, go beyond serving the usual dulce et utile to children and can even be disturbing. “Lilit Bulilit and the Babe-in-the-Womb” is a thinly veiled criticism of abortion: Lilit overhears adults arguing in its favor and so she sucks babies out of wombs with a straw. “The Happiest Boy in the World” can be read as a rich boy’s confrontation with social injustice, in which his family is complicit. “The Hamiling Mystery,” an adaptation of the Pied Piper story, is as much a satire on corrupt bureaucracy as it is a reflection on the vanity of human wishes.

The grit of real city life roughens the edges of even the most fanciful of the tales. Thus, the baby Blanca Nieva, in “The Mystery Sleeper of Balite Drive,” is found in a dump by seven brothers, children of illegal sidewalk vendors, and is raised in a shanty, with a pushcart for cradle. In some cases, the humor even borders on the risqué. “Gotita de Dragon” involves a mouse and a cockroach’s search for a virgin in Malate and Ermita so they can turn Gotita the dragon back into a lizard. A wolf in Project Four lends them his “virgin detector,” but the solution is found in a person of unexpected gender in an unexpected place.

In this book, Nick Joaquin is the tongue-in-cheek but no less perceptive writer for children and young adults. Though written for a particular generation of urban and urbane Filipinos, the stories remain entertaining and provocative today, when “groovy” and “pop” have long been passé. With the reprint of five of the stories in Gotita de Dragon and Other Stories, 2014, they promise to outlive the current slang for what is fashionable, whether “banging,” “awesome,” “rad,” or even the enduring “cool.”  Written by Jonathan Chua

text:
Published 2005. Author, Lakambini Sitoy. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

A collection of 16 stories, the book displays Lakambini Sitoy’s range. She writes on a variety of themes, handling sensitive topics like child abuse unflinchingly; and she writes in various genres, such as science fiction, magical realism, and noir.

There are stories for children and young adults. “Pure Magic” recounts the friendship between little Ellen and Mirava, a “junior witch” who points out to her all the magic around them. “The Night Monkeys” is a whimsically penned tale of a little girl named Bea and her nocturnal adventures with the “Night Monkeys,” embodiments of people’s dreams and aspirations. More serious is “The Bruise,” where a fourth grader, Sofia Pinili, experiences bullying and racism in an American public school.

In other stories, Sitoy explores relationships between women. In “Lyra,” an unlikely friendship blooms between Sam, a girl from the province, and Lyra. In “Denial, Denial,” Lara, a victim of abuse, is both fascinated by and resentful of her histrionic, self-absorbed roommate Cherie. In “The Sisterhood,” a law school freshman, Ruth Dizon, raised among many brothers, so yearns for sisterly love that she endures punishment to join a sorority.

Sex, drugs, rock and roll, and the mornings after are the stuff of “Heights,” “Intricate Forces,” and “Aresgada.” Sitoy also writes about the lives of older women. In “Injury Zone,” Miss Karen meets with a former boyfriend, now an insurance salesman, and avenges her teenage self for the times he demeaned her. “Touch” similarly has an older woman avenging herself on a man, this time her father. “The Vampire” takes place on the MRT, in which the vampire silently sweeps away one of the young children inside a train and abandons him at the station.

Two stories are dystopian. “Jungle Planet” is set in a future where neighborhoods are built on the ruins of other neighborhoods and little girls are found murdered under classroom floorboards. “Secret Notes on a Dead Star” is also set in a dismal future. What was once was Manila is now a divided city—the inner city replete with high-tech gadget; and the visible, outer city, left to rot.

Six of the 16 short stories included in the collection won prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: “Touch,” first prize, 1998; “Pure Magic,” first prize, children’s category, 1996; “The Night the Monkeys Came,” third place, children’s category, 2000; “Shut Up and Live,” second prize, 2005; “Lyra,” third prize, 2001; and “Secret Notes on a Dead Star,” second prize, 2000. “Jungle Planet” won second place in the short story category at the 2001 Philippine Graphic Literary Awards and was published, in a translation by Ghalia Einig, in the Spring 2002 issue of the French magazine Nouvelle Donne, and in the Winter 2002 issue of Manoa.  Written by Katrina del Rosario

text:
(Fist: Protest Literature 1970-1986; Short Story). Published 1987. Editors, Alfrredo Navarro Salanga, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, Reuel Molina Aguila, and Herminio S. Beltran Jr. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines Center for Literature.

This anthology of stories of protest in Filipino/Tagalog and in English is one in the three-part series called Kamao, which includes the poems, stories, and dramas written before, during, and after the declaration of martial law in 1972.

The 23 stories are divided into the three periods defined and explained in the introduction to the Kamao series: 1970-72, the years of the nationalist movement and rise of protest literature, marked at one end by the First Quarter Storm, and at the other by the declaration of martial law. Between 1972 and 1983, the Aquino assassination, protest continued even under strict supervision and suppression, mainly by taking forms of indirection and circumvention. Between 1983 and 1986, the fall of the Marcos regime and the start of the Aquino presidency, protest became open and vocal and most effective in the raising of the consciousness that led to the EDSA Revolt in 1986.

The stories of 1970-72 and 1972-83 range through the experiences that awakened the spirit of protest: logging by the rich and powerful, which made mountains look like the shaved heads of scabies-ridden children (Efren Abueg, “Daluyong sa Ilaya” [Giant Wave at Ilaya]); the formation and work of organizers who awakened peasants to their rights (Ave Perez Jacob, “Ang Pagdating ni Elias Plaridel” [The Coming of Elias Plaridel]); the politicization of urban students (Norma Miraflor, “Sulat mula sa Pritil” [Letter from Pritil]); the encounters in the provinces, quiet and otherwise, between the military, the people, and the “men in the hills” (Resil Mojares, “A Sickness in the Towns”); urban poverty (Estrella Alfon’s “The Red Wagon”); the awakening of some of the bourgeoisie (Gregorio Brillantes’s “A Taste for the Fine Whiskey of the Bourgeoisie”).

The 1983-86 stories reflect in turn the last years before the end of the Marcos regime: the taking and torture of political prisoners, hiding “underground” from authorities, rallies and confrontations in the streets, the aftermath for people on both sides of the political fence (Cesar Ruiz Aquino, “A Tale of Two Diaries”; Jose Y. Dalisay, “Amnesty”; Danilo Consumido, “Mga Lamat sa Moog” [Cracks in the Fortress]; Amadis Ma. Guerrero, “Red Roses for Rebo”).

The language ranges from lyrical Tagalog (Levy Balgos de la Cruz, “Paalam sa Buwan” [Farewell to the Moon]) to easy urban Filipino (Ricardo Lee, “Si Tatang, si Tandang Senyong, si Freddie at Iba Pang Tauhan ng Aking Kuwento” [Tatang, Freddie, Old Man Senyong and Other Charaters of My Story]), the crisply colloquial Tondo accent of Norma Miraflor (“Sulat mula sa Pritil”), and the new colloquialism of Jun Cruz Reyes (“Syeyring” [Sharing]).

The separate stories lay out the events of those years, the situations in which they encaged people, the feelings and reactions that resulted, the protest they bore as fruit. The range of language and expression explores the fervor of protest as well as its idiom and literary achievement.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

text:
(Because Love Is Not Blind). Published 2012. Author, Temistokles Adlawan. Editor, Hope Sabanpan-Yu. With an introduction by the editor. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

This posthumous collection of short stories features many of Adlawan’s late 20th-century works, which were previously published in magazines like Bisaya, Alimyon, and Bag-ong Balud. English translations of the 10 stories are provided by Merlie Alunan in the second half of the book.

Most of the stories are set in Adlawan’s hometown of Naga, Cebu, and the prose leans toward the poetic, humorous, but most importantly, thoughtful. Characters use colloquial speech unique to the region, and the author demonstrates a sharp ear for it.

The stories “Lumba” (Race) and “Kay Dili Buta ang Gugma” (Because Love Is Not Blind) depict how the natural and instinctive drive of males attracts the opposite sex. Here, the young male protagonists’ firm belief and confidence in superficial qualities—machismo in “Lumba,” and clothes and good looks in the title story—are sufficient to win the attention and admiration of a woman. In “Kay ang Krimen Magbayad Usab” (Because Crime Does Pay), Adlawan uses a more mature writing style as he enters the mind of the vengeance-seeking Rito, whose parents were murdered 10 years before, by an acquaintance named Manolo. The story shows how the effects of Rito’s long-festering preoccupation with revenge affects his relationships with the people around him.

Adlawan also touches on the themes of man-versus-nature in “Ang Tiki nga Miipon sa Balay ni Moniko” (The Lizard That Lives in the House of Moniko) and the longer “Pagsalig” (Faith). In the former, the subject is a small, ubiquitous animal present in perhaps every Cebuano household: the lizard. Moniko, the resident of the eponymous home, tries to rid his dwelling of the reptile by stabbing at it, but it surprises him in the end by leaving its dropping on him. Moniko is then humbled, and he realizes that he has no choice but to peacefully coexist with it.

A greater challenge is found in “Pagsalig,” where Sido, a young man living close to the coast combs the beach for edible, shallow-dwelling creatures for his livelihood. He is pitted against the mighty, uncontrollable forces of nature: the strong wind and waves. He succumbs to these forces, after he refuses to heed the many warnings of other folks to stay away from the tidal flats in that area, where numerous parties of beachcombers and fishermen are known to vanish.  Written by Charles Dominic Sanchez

article_title: Kay Lalim na ng Gabi at Iba Pang Kuwento
text:
(How Late It Is and Other Stories). Published 2011. Author, Agustin C. Fabian. With an introduction by Roberto T. Añonuevo. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This collection of 19 of Fabian’s short stories showcases his ability both to write within the mold of Liwayway, where his stories were published in the 1950s and 1960s and of whose editorial board he was a member, and to modify entrenched literary conventions. Fabian had to deal with what the reading public expected—their weekly dose of “aliw at aral” (delight and instruction) that was the magazine’s motto. However, one also detects in Fabian’s fiction a deep sense of control, avoiding sentimentality and didacticism.

The deft deployment of irony is illustrated in “Bagong Sapatos” (New Shoes), a story that probes the depth of a man’s love for his family, especially during Christmas and its ritual of gift-giving; in “Pangkasal” (For Weddings), where in a few pages Fabian explores the significance a wedding dress has for two generations; in “Magsabi Ka Muna” (Get Permission First), where a man finds out that a lie he concocted in a fit of temper has been exposed, thanks to a talkative young girl; and in a delightful love story, “Ayos Na Kami” (We’re Okay Now), where the identity of the humble candidate’s real love is revealed in a surprising denouement.

Fabian understood that readers demanded to read about the tortuous complexities and vicissitudes of love. Thus, a great number of his stories revolve around love, a few focusing on class difference as an initial obstacle that can be surmounted if there is no vaulting ambition or excessive self-love between the lovers. This depiction of love appears in “Sampung Taong Nagdurusa” (Ten Years’ Suffering), “Ni Kailanman” (Not Even Forever), and “Napilay si Edeng” (Edeng Got Crippled). Its most complex delineation, however, is found in “Bilanggo” (Prisoner), in which a poor lover seeks revenge, only to realize his folly after he has risen to wealth.

Fabian also turned to the theme of “the prostitute with the golden heart” in “Mula sa Puso ng Dagat” (From the Heart of the Sea), “Sa Dako Pa Roon …” (Over There), and “Kay Lalim ng Gabi” (It’s Late). The women in these stories are forced (usually by the doings of a villainous lover) into prostitution or into becoming cabaret dancers. To their rescue come men who themselves are experienced in the ways of the world.

A notable quality of Fabian’s stories is their incorporation of humor, a device only a few Tagalog writers at that time, such as Amado V. Hernandez and Macario Pineda, deployed. In stories like “Napakalurit na Paglalaga ng Mais” (Meticulous Boiling of Corn), “May Saya Ka Na ’Ata” (Seems Like You’ve Got a Skirt), and “Loleng, Naka-aabala Ka …” (Loleng, You’re in the Way), Fabian turns to stock situations: the tribulations of a tongue-tied lover, a couple preferring to elope rather than have an expensive wedding, a young man facing a tough rival for a woman’s heart who learns a lesson from his father’s comical fate as an eager suitor.

Writing for a popular magazine, Fabian churned out stories and novels with familiar plots and characters: the poor man struggling to educate himself (usually ending up as a lawyer), young lovers who view love with few illusions, married couples coping with growing families, the woman of ill-repute and the men who take care of them, the retired couple helping people in their predicament. Yet while working with familiar themes, he managed to inject some freshness. The compass of the stories is usually the family or the barrio. Readers looking for his more encompassing vision of postwar society in turmoil will have to focus their attention on his serialized novels, whose grand narratives involve politics, corruption, power, and greed.  Written by Soledad Reyes

Fabian also turned to the theme of “the prostitute with the golden heart” in “Mula sa Puso ng Dagat” (From the Heart of the Sea), “Sa Dako Pa Roon …” (Over There), and “Kay Lalim ng Gabi” (It’s Late). The women in these stories are forced (usually by the doings of a villainous lover) into prostitution or into becoming cabaret dancers. To their rescue come men who themselves are experienced in the ways of the world.

A notable quality of Fabian’s stories is their incorporation of humor, a device only a few Tagalog writers at that time, such as Amado V. Hernandez and Macario Pineda, deployed. In stories like “Napakalurit na Paglalaga ng Mais” (Meticulous Boiling of Corn), “May Saya Ka Na ’Ata” (Seems Like You’ve Got a Skirt), and “Loleng, Naka-aabala Ka …” (Loleng, You’re in the Way), Fabian turns to stock situations: the tribulations of a tongue-tied lover, a couple preferring to elope rather than have an expensive wedding, a young man facing a tough rival for a woman’s heart who learns a lesson from his father’s comical fate as an eager suitor.

Writing for a popular magazine, Fabian churned out stories and novels with familiar plots and characters: the poor man struggling to educate himself (usually ending up as a lawyer), young lovers who view love with few illusions, married couples coping with growing families, the woman of ill-repute and the men who take care of them, the retired couple helping people in their predicament. Yet while working with familiar themes, he managed to inject some freshness. The compass of the stories is usually the family or the barrio. Readers looking for his more encompassing vision of postwar society in turmoil will have to focus their attention on his serialized novels, whose grand narratives involve politics, corruption, power, and greed.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Canvas: Ilocano Stories). Published 1988. Compilers, Reynaldo A. Duque, Jose A. Bragado, and Linda T. Lingbaoan. Manila: GUMIL-Filipinas.

The book, the first anthology of translations in Filipino of Ilocano stories, was cited by the Linangan ng mga Wika sa Filipinas in 1989. This anthology contains 30 short stories originally written in Ilocano and translated into Filipino, about half of them by the authors themselves. Each story was chosen by the author as representative of his or her work. Most of the original texts in Ilocano were published previously in Bannawag and Ilocano anthologies or collections; a few of the translations into Filipino appeared in popular Tagalog magazines.

Among the writers included are Benjamin M. Pascual, Juan S. P. Hidalgo Jr, Greg Laconsay, Jose A. Bragado, Reynaldo A. Duque, Lorenzo G. Tabin, Pacifico D. Espanto, Dionisio S. Bulong, Rogelio A. Aquino, Eldorado E. Licos, Crispina B. Bragado, Cecilio T. Teñoso, Firmo A. Estopacio, Eden Cachola Bulong, Benito S. de Castro, Jacinto B. de Peralta, Agustin D. C. Rubin, Paul B. Zafaralla, Noel V. Lansangan, Herman Garcia Tabin, Bernardo Donat Tabbada, Cles B. Rambaud, Hermilinda T. Lingbaoan, Feliciano Martin T. Rochina, and Marcos B. Cate.

Kurditan, which literally means “canvas,” is used by the editors to mean “Ilocano literature.” According to them, the book is a testimony of the Ilocano writers’ desire to take an active role in the formation of a national literature, believing as they do that such a literature is not possible without their participation or contribution. A glossary of Ilocano terms may be found as a footnote to some of the stories.  Written by Herminio Beltran Jr

text:
(Twenty Stories by Vicente Sotto). Published 1998. Editor, Erlinda K. Alburo. Translator, Remedios B. Ramos. With an introduction by the editor. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Sentro ng Wikang Filipino.

This short story collection in Cebuano, with translations in Filipino, represents Vicente Sotto’s principles and beliefs as a statesman, lawyer, and journalist. In the introduction, Erlinda K. Alburo notes that Sotto’s writings are expressions of his aspirations in the face of the conflicts between dogma and reason and between love and human behavior. Some of the stories were written in 1908 in Hong Kong, where Sotto was exiled for his political convictions. The stories are set against the background of the two significant events in Philippine history: the 1896 Revolution and the beginning of the American conquest.

Patriotism during the height of the revolution against the Spaniards is a prominent topic in the collection. In both “Ang Inahan sa Sundalo” (A Soldier’s Mother) and “Ang mga Ilo” (The Orphans), two revolutionary soldiers are torn between love of family and love of motherland. In the end, the soldiers choose to sacrifice themselves for their compatriots.

The effect of maternal love and romantic love on human behavior is depicted in the other stories. In “Gugma sa Inahan” (A Mother’s Love), an aging mother takes back her leprosy-ridden son, who had shunned her when she was sick. In “Panikas sa Gugma” (A Cheat in Love), a middle-aged widow leaves her three daughters for a younger man who is only after her wealth. The stories “Ang Salamin” (The Mirror) and “Kabuotan” (Goodness) show the stages of love from courtship to amicable separation.

The stories in the collection also have as their theme the effect of law and order on the psyche of an individual. “Hain ang Katarungan?” (Where Is Justice?) questions the justice system that would penalize a man for a consensual elopement. “Ang Timaan” (The Mark) concerns a good man who is imprisoned for a crime committed by the father of the woman he loves. The man, now embittered, is released and commits a crime of passion. Themes about family are found in “Don Benigno,” which is about infidelity, and “Amahan ug Anak,” (Father and Son), which is about disobedience of children.

The conflict between social convention and an individual’s convictions runs through most of the stories. In “Donato,” the title character is a 41-year-old English professor who breaks his engagement with a beautiful yet promiscuous heiress from Maguindanao to marry his pudgy servant. In “Ang Tinagoan ni Teresa” (Teresa’s Secret), a woman gives birth to a boy out of wedlock and sends him far away to Maguindanao. This attempt to keep up the appearance of propriety brings about dire consequences. Moreover, Mindanao, in these two stories, is used by Sotto as the antithesis of Christian morals and mores.

This bilingual collection makes available to a larger readership the beginnings of modern Cebuano fiction, written by one deemed by his peers and literary scholars as the “Father of Cebuano Literature.”  Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

 

Source

Lucero, Rosario Cruz. 2007. “The Nation in Vicente Sotto’s Literary Imagination: A Study of Thirteen Cebuano Stories.” In Ang Bayan sa Labas ng Maynila/The Nation beyond Manila, 103-23 Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.
