article_title: Landas sa Bahaghari at Iba Pang Kuwento
text:
(A Trail to the Rainbow and Other Stories). Published 2003. Author, Benjamin P. Pascual. Editor, Roberto T. Añonuevo. With an introduction by the editor. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The stories in this posthumous collection consists of 21 of the 200 or so written by Pascual between 1951 and 2002, most of which were published in Liwayway. Pascual’s protagonists are people on the margins: the underprivileged working class, the urban poor, prostitutes—whom he invariably depicts as victims of the system. However, even in his very first short story, “Ang Kalupi” (The Wallet), 1952, he treats the familiar theme of class oppression with a double irony as he demonstrates how the poor can also be oppressed by the poor. In the story, a boy accused of stealing a wallet is killed by a car as he tries to escape his accuser, Aling Marta.

In “Di Mo Masilip ang Langit” (You Cannot Get a Glimpse of Heaven), an arsonist recollects the events that resulted in his incarceration: his firstborn died when the hospital that he had helped to construct turned them away while his wife was in labor. He thus loses his faith in both the system and God. In “Pera sa Ilalim ng Estante” (Money underneath the Rack), the Chinese vendor of trinkets on a side street is contrasted with an unsuccessful writer, a non-Chinese, who becomes a beggar and thief.

Although Pascual’s male protagonists are manipulative and macho (virile and domineering), Pascual does not always portray them as oppressive. In “Keso de Bola” (Cheese Ball), a newspaperman sleeps with his sick friend’s mistress and then gives them both some money. There are stories where the men get their comeuppance. In “Ang Linggo ni Pepe” (Pepe’s Week), the playboy Pepe is stranded on an island with six beautiful women. Pepe must divide his week among them, giving them one day each to maintain peace on the island. The seventh day, Sunday, is his only rest day.

But the female punisher can also end up being the punished. In “Kung Ano ang Ginawa Mo” (Whatever You Did), Marissa discovers that her husband is having an affair. To get back at him, she has a one-night stand with a stranger, but, in the end, she is filled with self-disgust and is more guilt-ridden than he is.

While Pascual’s settings and narrative situations are rendered realistically, they are not always grim. Some stories end with the promise of hope and salvation, and thus they have a romantic outlook. “Landas sa Bahaghari” (A Trail to the Rainbow) tells of a Waray sales girl Salud, who is raped by her Chinese employer in order for him to force a marriage and secure Filipino citizenship. After seven years, Salud escapes back to Samar with her six-year-old daughter. This story and “Di Mo Masilip ang Langit” won first prize at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature in 1965 and 1981, respectively.   Written by Edgar C. Samar

article_title: Langaw sa Isang Basong Gatas at Iba Pang Kuwento
text:
(Housefly in a Glass of Milk and Other Stories). Published 1996. Author, Amado V. Hernandez. With a foreword by Bienvenido L. Lumbera and an introduction by Rosario Torres-Yu. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This book gathers together 42 of Amado V. Hernandez’s stories, written within a span of 45 years and previously published in popular magazines such as Liwayway, Bulaklak, Dalaga, and Sampaguita, and literary anthologies. With a few exceptions, the stories are chronologically arranged, starting with “Magpinsan” (Cousins), 1924, and ending with the title story, 1970. The order shows the development of Hernandez’s fiction writing, with the subject matter of love and society threading through them. Personal relationships, as depicted, are tested by social realities like class conflict, war, crime, and displacement.

Hernandez’s inclination for questioning social convention is instantly apparent in “Magpinsan” (Cousins), which depicts two cousins defying the taboo against incest. However, its initial optimism is followed by love stories that end badly: in “Liham na Lihim” (Secret Letter), 1924, a letter reveals the truth behind a sportsman’s death; in “Kay Saklap” (How Bitter), 1925, a finicky young man gets his comeuppance from the woman he finally chooses; in “Nasawing Bulaklak” (Fallen Flower), 1925, a man chooses America over his sweetheart, who then wastes away; and in “Kasal sa Pastor” (Wed by a Pastor), 1928, a girl chooses a doctor over other, lowlier suitors, to her misfortune. Hernandez is adept at giving the formulaic plot a refreshingly novel twist. In “Sa Oras ng Panganib” (In a Perilous Time), 1928, four suitors undergo an ordeal by fire, and only one can come out unscathed. “Panata ni Pilar” (Pilar’s Vow), 1936, proves that constancy in love has its rewards but also exacts a price. Thirty-four years after Hernandez’s first, taboo-breaking story, he again challenges social convention in “Sapot ng Panganorin” (Horizon’s Cobweb), 1958, which places a 1950s couple in multiple scandalous situations: a nurse-patient, May-December, adulterous affair that leads to divorce and a legal, second marriage.

Some stories feature women’s relationships across generations. In “Reyna ng Tahanan” (Queen of the Household), 1956, a girl consults her grandmother about love and career as a beauty queen. In “Ang Kanaryo at ang Bantay” (The Canary and the Warden), 1958, a demanding mother chooses a rich Chinese for her reluctant daughter.

Power is personified by rich old men who misuse it either through cunning manipulation or outright violence, such as the lecherous old businessman, in “Pangalugi ng Milyonaryo” (Millionaire’s Loss), 1958, posing as a benevolent employer, whereas in “Dalawang Metro sa Lupang Hindi Malipad ng Uwak” (Two Meters of the Land the Crow Cannot Range Across), 1970, it is a rapacious landlord. Standing like David to such Goliaths are Hernandez’s heroes, such as the idealistic mayor in “May Uling sa Palayok” (There’s Soot on the Pot), 1959, and the beleaguered union leader in “Panata ng Isang Lider” (Vow of a Leader), 1960.

The large-scale violence of war is dramatized through individual, human dilemmas, such as that in “Takas” (Runaway), 1959, in which enemies in war are also entangled in a love triangle; and in “Nasaan ang Medalya?” (Where Is the Medal?), 1957, in which a grandfather aids an American fugitive from the death march.

Country life is shown in a positive light, especially in contrast to Manila. In “Sa Sariling Pugad” (In One’s Own Nest), 1925, a trip to Manila reaffirms for the character the virtues of farm life. In “Pamana” (Heritage), 1958, a peasant family’s wealth is an heirloom piece, a jade plate that is beyond price. On the other hand, Hernandez’s Manila is populated by desperate individuals who were once innocent country folk, such as those in “Ang Aginaldo ng Kanyang Anak” (Her Son’s Gift), 1929, about a student turned boxer; “Buntot ng Bahaghari” (End of the Rainbow), 1957, about two job-seeking friends; and “Kislap ng Utak, Pawis ng Noo” (Spark of the Brain, Sweat of the Brow), 1970, about a jeepney driver with a teaching degree. In the last story, “Langaw sa Isang Basong Gatas,” Hernandez dramatizes the inevitability of the oppressed proletariat taking up arms. Here, an informal settler (or “squatter” in Hernandez’s time) forced out of his home ends up taking two bolos and a whetstone as the church bells in the newly built subdivision ring out.

Hernandez’s stories are a chronicle of Filipino historical experience through the Commonwealth, the Japanese occupation, and post-World War II rehabilitation.  Written by Arbeen Acuña

text:
Published 1960. Author, Estrella Alfon. With an introduction by Francisco Arcellana. Manila: Regal Publishing.

This collection of short stories revolves around daily lives; doubts, pains, and little joys are portrayed with unerring emotional insight. The title story explores a topic still considered a taboo: child molestation committed by a trusted adult friend.

Alfon’s astuteness concerning gender differentiation is shown in little details. The mother’s fierceness when she discovers the molester’s true intentions is contrasted with the father’s relatively insignificant role in the story. There is, too, a sharp contrast in the behavior and treatment of the little brother and sister. In these stories, Alfon is unrelenting in baring motives and pretensions. “Those That Love Us” shows how for the rich young girl, affection is given or withheld as a reward; for the spoiled baby girl, it is something one cannot get enough of; but for the poor cousin, rather out of place in the rich house, it must be repaid with gratitude, awe, and hungry expectation. The story also depicts how gender differentiation is established in childhood and how gender roles are crystallized in adulthood. “Water from the Well,” somewhat heavy with fecundity symbols, is a love story with a happy ending, as the middle-aged lovers Tesiang and Mr Gloria deserve. In this languorous story, Alfon weaves a bucolic “dream of silence, peace, and contentment.” In contrast, “The Gentle Rain” is about a woman of the upper class who leads an unloved life, even as she herself loves passionately. “Man with a Camera” and its twin piece “The Photographed Beggar” are about charity, kindness, and cruelty. At least three stories—“Servant Girl,” “English,” and “Those That Love Us”—show a scope and sensitivity reaching to other classes, other climes. Here are vivid, precious, secret joys and apprehensions that, to the insensitive characters in the stories, are just rawness, clumsiness, or timidity.

As Arcellana notes in his introduction, these are “lived” stories, confessions of the writer herself or of other people through her. But the author’s sense of emotional communion with the characters rescues these stories from being maudlin, even as Alfon’s sure touch with the cadences of the English language enables her to express what are, in the end, emotions unmistakably Filipino.

One story by Alfon, “A Fairy Tale for the City,” published on 21 Aug 1955 in This Week, the Sunday magazine of the Manila Chronicle, could not be included in the collection because a court injunction had banned it from republication on the charge of obscenity. Alfon’s stories are also collected in The Stories of Estrella D. Alfon, 1994, edited by Lina Espina-Moore and The Estrella D. Alfon Anthology, 2000, edited by Herminia Santos-Bas.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

In these stories, Alfon is unrelenting in baring motives and pretensions. “Those That Love Us” shows how for the rich young girl, affection is given or withheld as a reward; for the spoiled baby girl, it is something one cannot get enough of; but for the poor cousin, rather out of place in the rich house, it must be repaid with gratitude, awe, and hungry expectation. The story also depicts how gender differentiation is established in childhood and how gender roles are crystallized in adulthood. “Water from the Well,” somewhat heavy with fecundity symbols, is a love story with a happy ending, as the middle-aged lovers Tesiang and Mr Gloria deserve. In this languorous story, Alfon weaves a bucolic “dream of silence, peace, and contentment.” In contrast, “The Gentle Rain” is about a woman of the upper class who leads an unloved life, even as she herself loves passionately. “Man with a Camera” and its twin piece “The Photographed Beggar” are about charity, kindness, and cruelty. At least three stories—“Servant Girl,” “English,” and “Those That Love Us”—show a scope and sensitivity reaching to other classes, other climes. Here are vivid, precious, secret joys and apprehensions that, to the insensitive characters in the stories, are just rawness, clumsiness, or timidity.

As Arcellana notes in his introduction, these are “lived” stories, confessions of the writer herself or of other people through her. But the author’s sense of emotional communion with the characters rescues these stories from being maudlin, even as Alfon’s sure touch with the cadences of the English language enables her to express what are, in the end, emotions unmistakably Filipino.

One story by Alfon, “A Fairy Tale for the City,” published on 21 Aug 1955 in This Week, the Sunday magazine of the Manila Chronicle, could not be included in the collection because a court injunction had banned it from republication on the charge of obscenity. Alfon’s stories are also collected in The Stories of Estrella D. Alfon, 1994, edited by Lina Espina-Moore and The Estrella D. Alfon Anthology, 2000, edited by Herminia Santos-Bas.  Written by Victoria S. Calizo

text:
(Kapampangan and Pangasinan Short Stories). Published 1996. Editors and translators, Lourdes H. Vidal and Ma. Crisanta S. Nelmida. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This two-part anthology consists of 21 short stories in Kapampangan, edited by Vidal, and 10 short stories in Pangasinan, edited by Nelmida. The Kapampangan stories were originally published in magazines between 1911 and 1980; the Pangasinan, between the 1930s and the 1960s. Vidal and Nelmida translate the stories into Filipino, and each provides a historical introduction to her section.

The Kapampangan stories reflect the times in which they were written. Written right after the Philippine-American war, “Ing Pasionaria” (The Pasyonara) by Crisostomo Soto has for a protagonist a native soldier who is not cowed by the superior arms of the enemy. “Y Miss Phatupats” (Miss Phatupats), also by Soto, satirizes those who aspire to Western ways.

The influence of the Church is evident in “Luis, ing Mamulang” (Luis, the Madman) by Amador (pseud. of Felix Bautista), where the protagonist meets Sinang during Lent and loses his sanity when she marries somebody else.

In the 1920s, Kapampangan poetry entered a vigorous phase, encouraging short story writers to attempt stories in verse. These are lyrical stories. Such are Amado M. Yuzon’s “Rosa” and “Simbang Bengi” (Midnight Mass) and Rosario Tuazon Baluyut’s “Mepuspus Na” (Finished). “Simbang Bengi,” consisting of 21 rhyming quatrains, with each verse having 16 syllables, is about Mary and Ruben. When Mary’s parents have her wed another man, Ruben kills himself outside the church. “Mepuspus Na” describes a storm that landed on 16 Oct 1934 in 10 quatrains of rhyming dodecasyllabic lines.

Alongside this development, however, is the influence of journalism, seen in Baluyut’s “Pamamali” (Revenge), which recounts the hunting down and execution of a landowner who mistreated the protagonist’s family.

After World War II, Kapampangan fictionists began to employ indirection and the telling narrative detail. Such a style is observed in “Sisilim” (Twilight) by Diosdado Macapagal where an old man and woman sitting in the park recount their failed romances. By the story’s end, the reader discovers that they were once a couple and each has been looking for the other.

Love of country is the subject of “Matimbu” by Magdiwa (pseud.) in which a soldier of the Katipunan loses his life trying to save his comrades on the other side of the river Matimbu from an ambush. “Sumpa ning Poeta” (A Poet’s Curse) by Jose M. Gallardo reflects on the paradoxical life of a poet, whose fame did not save his son from death.

In the 1980s, realism dominated the Kapampangan short story, and the selections reflect contemporary issues: illegal recruitment and the hardships suffered by overseas workers, in Querubin D. Fernandez’s “Ing Kapagpabustan” (Negligence); violence wrought by militarization, in Ramiro Mercado’s “Bye Alamang” (A Dog’s Life); and the pollution of the river, in Florentino Turla’s “Ing Buluc ning Sentral” (The Garbage of Central).

The other stories in the anthology are “Cuadrong Matuling” (Black Picture) by Juan Crisostomo Soto, “Talimhaga” (Metaphor) by Amado M. Yuzon, “Ing Manuc Cung Texas” (My Texas Chicken) by Rosendo M. Vergara, and “Pascu ning Preso” (The Prisoner’s Christmas) by Mariano C. Sigua.

Nelmida observes that the Pangasinan short stories, taken from the magazine Silew, are informed by orality and didacticism. In stories like the anonymous “Tita ya Agwari Asabin Iyanak” (Tita Who Was Almost Not Born), the author directly states his or her opinions and endorses the values of respect for one’s parents and faith in God. Drawing on the exemplary tales of the Spanish colonial period, Maria Magsano’s “Kaonoran ya Bilin: Tongtong a Tugtuwan Agawa” (Last Words: A True Story) reminds readers to ask Jesus to help them carry life’s crosses and portrays women as long-suffering, weak, and reserved. Bella Luz’s “Ulaula to Lambengat” (His Blandishments) warns girls against forming amorous relationships too early.

“Vida” by Maria Magsano and “Panibeg tan Irap na Linawa” (Love and Pain) by Juan C. Villamil share the same premise—the protagonist’s love interest is a blood relation of his enemy—but arrive at opposite conclusions.

Love triumphs in “Say ‘Gayuma’ nen Laki Simeon” (Grandfather Simeon’s ‘Charm’) by Leonarda Carrera, which has a surprise ending, “Pinawil Toray Boleg To” (He Returned to His Family) by Eufemia Villamil, and “Kaonoran ya Kaut” (Last Ball) by Juan C. Villamil.

The other stories in the anthology are “Aseleng na Inawa” (Blinded by Comfort) by Eufemina Villamil and “Siopay Akankasalanan?” (Who’s to Blame?).

On the whole, the short stories in the anthology are a record of life in two provinces for the greater part of the 20th century.  Written by Rowena Festin

text:
(The Tagalog Short Story, 1886-1948). Published 1949. Editor, Teodoro A. Agoncillo. Manila: Inang Wika Publishing, 1949, 1954, 1965, 1972.

This collection of 21 stories represented for the anthologist-historian and poet Agoncillo—some of the best writing done in Tagalog during the first half of the 20th century. His lengthy introduction to the book, “Kami: Ang Maikling Kuwentong Tagalog, Pasulyap na Tingin sa mga Tao at Kilusan” (We: The Tagalog Short Story, a Glimpse of the Writers and the Movement) provides a literary history of that early period, serving as a rich source of information on the literary activities of writers, and the kind of critical attitudes and writing tendencies they manifested. Agoncillo gives an account of the beginnings of the short story as a modern genre in the Philippines, in particular the short form called dagli or sketch, which appeared in Manila newspapers at the time. It readily won immense popularity, and even threatened to overshadow the much longer and older Tagalog novels. He focuses on the efforts of young critics, such as Clodualdo del Mundo and Alejandro G. Abadilla, in providing some direction to the fledgling literary form during the 1920s and 1930s. The highlight of this account is the discussion on Panitikan, the group of young, university-educated writers who saw the need to stage a revolt against the perceived authoritarianism of the more established writers. What starts out as a chronicle turns into a treatise on what were then regarded as the ideal qualities of the short story: objectivity, brevity, absence of sentimentality, revolving point of view, and deft characterization. For Agoncillo, the short stories published in Liwayway during World War II were among the supreme achievement in the genre, with their consistent and sensitive use of technique in fleshing out the fictional material. The introduction ends with a description of the events that took place in the literary scene after the war. The anthologist concludes that the efforts of enlightened critics like del Mundo and Abadilla came to naught because of the rampant commercialism that shaped most of the stories written after the war.

Included in this anthology are the works of writers like Macario Pineda, Liwayway Arceo, Hernando Ocampo, and Narciso Reyes. One common denominator among these writers is the influence of American short-story writers, notably Sherwood Anderson, O. Henry, and Edgar Allan Poe. Apart from the introduction and the actual selections, Agoncillo provides biographies of the authors. Titled “Sila” (They), this section includes Agoncillo’s analysis and evaluation of the author’s short story, as well as his personal comments about the author.

By being one of the first anthologies to follow an unambiguous critical viewpoint, Agoncillo with this selection canonizes the “modern” Tagalog short story influenced by Western literary technique, and relegates the more tradition-bound Tagalog texts to a marginal status.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
(Apparition and Other Stories). Published 2007. Author, Benigno R. Juan. With an introduction by Roberto T. Añonuevo. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This collection gathers 32 of the short stories, three of them Palanca-award winners, written by what Añonuevo in the introduction describes as “one of the forgotten storytellers of our time.”

Twelve are set in his hometown of Pasig City. The opening story, “Wala Nang Lawin sa Bukid ni Tata Felipe” (The Hawks Are Gone from Tata Felipe’s Farm), interweaves the themes of social injustice, parenthood, and old age that run through the whole collection. It uses the allegory of the hawk and the chicken to narrate an old farmer’s struggle to save his farm from being taken over by factories, only for him to be betrayed by his own son. “Dilim” (Darkness), “Tinik” (Thorn), and “Inhustisya” (Injustice) depict impoverished people doubly suffering from exploitation perpetrated by the elite class and the state.

Correlative to the theme of aging is the loneliness afflicting elderly couples. The title story, “Malikmata” (Apparition), is about a couple haunted by premonitions of death in the barrio; and “Maluwalhating Pasko” (Glorious Christmas), which tells of another couple’s wish for a Christmas family reunion that is inadvertently but tragically fulfilled. Providing comic relief is “Ang mga Deboto” (The Devotees), a satire on the elitism and hypocrisy of “servants of God” from the point of view of an aged couple.

The stories of fatherhood evoke tenderness, as in the story of a son’s final fishing trip with his father in “Isang Ganap na Paglaya” (An Absolute Freedom). Biblical allusions are used in two other such stories: “Ama … Anak” (Father … Son) is a reworking of the parable of the prodigal son; “Awa” (Mercy) is a futuristic story with the characters, named Abraham and Isaac, reflecting on their intertwined fates as the father awaits execution.

The author ranges over diverse topics and themes, such as ill-fated romances, individual misfortunes, and serendipity, with the use of equally diverse narrative voices. A gay showbiz reporter narrates the rise and fall of a child actor in “Kabayo-kabayuhan” (Toy Horse); “Piitan” (Prison) is told through a convict’s monologue; and a comic touch is employed in “Sorpresa” (Surprise), which is an anecdote of a prank played by a group of employees on their friend. “Pangamba” (Anxiety) and “Kapag Di Ukol” (If It’s Not Meant) are both inspirational sketches about characters overcoming obstacles as they venture into gardening.

The final story, “Orasyon: Sa Simbahan, sa Piitan at sa Coral Ballroom ng Manila Hilton” (Evening Prayers: In the Church, Prison, and the Coral Ballroom of Manila Hilton), uses multiple voices as a device to contain the emotionalism of the material. The interior monologues of the anguished beggar and her son, who is accused of theft and attempted murder, are interrupted by those of elite young men, one of whom is the real culprit. With its deliberately restrained style and its atmosphere of a foreboding tragedy, this is an example of Philippine social realism at its best.

The three Palanca-winning stories in this collection are “Malikmata,” third prize, 1974; “Wala Nang Lawin sa Bukid ni Tata Felipe,” third prize, 1975; and “Orasyon: Sa Simbahan, sa Piitan at sa Coral Ballroom ng Manila Hilton,” third prize, 1980.   Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo

text:
(The Healer of Salay-salay). Published 1989. Author, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago. Manila: Kalikasan Press.

The five stories and two chapters of a proposed novel in this collection dramatize life in the northern countryside on the eve of martial law. They speak about resistance and struggle against oppression, injustice, and exploitation by the ruling class. The narratives range from the armed conflicts in a remote nook of the mountains to an indigenous ritual feast in Baguio, and to the picket lines in the city.

The title story is about the coming of age of a boy in a far-flung barrio, where the people are caught in the cross fire between the military and rebel factions. The story opens with a lifeless body of a rebel sprawled in front of the municipal hall. The boy becomes politically enlightened as adult conversations about their family’s ties with the rebel are filtered through his innocent mind. Later on, the boy discovers that the executed rebel was the same person who had been his brother’s companion in the mountains. It is the doctor who helped them heal the barrio’s physical and social illnesses. In “Mga Panauhin ni Selo” (Selo’s Visitors), the title character is a former rebel-turned-peasant, who chooses to isolate himself and his family from the town center. One stormy night, a rebel group takes shelter in his house. Selo recounts to them his past as a rebel. This recollection reawakens his sociopolitical beliefs and convictions. The story’s end depicts a reborn and triumphant Selo as he takes his scythe to start a new day of mowing, reaping, and struggling.

Two stories feature female protagonists who shatter stereotypes of the feminine heroine. “Mga Titik sa Dambuhalang Bato” (Letters in the Giant Rock) is an epistolary narrative that pieces together the portrait of a woman who turns her back on a “normal” life in the city for her political convictions. Clarita, the protagonist, after devoting her life to the city’s picket lines, now continues the struggle in the mountains. She has given up her lover, Noel, because of their conflicting ideologies.

The eponymous character in “Ang Pinakahuling Kuwento ni Huli” (The Final Story of Huli) is a mute outcast whose life story has been authored for her by other people, whose speculations and conjectures are based on presumptions about the nature of women. Here, the author weaves together various myths and legends about women in patriarchal literature: the seamstress made pregnant by her employer, the prostitute suffering from syphilis, and the woman sold by her grandfather to a landlord. Despite her isolation, Huli is visited by nameless friends who, like her, yearn for freedom and equality. This story is told in a lyrical style, which creates a surrealistic effect.

The story “Grand Cañao” is a striking portrait of a conflict between an indigene and a colonizer. During the day of the grand cañao (indigenous ritual feast in Benguet), an Igorot gets into a brawl with his American employer after the latter’s sexual innuendos. “Ang Tugtugin ni Kabayan” (The Music of Kabayan) and “Pagka’t Ako, si Naciana Madrigal, Ay Laging May Ipinagpapaliban” (For I, Naciana Madrigal, Am Always Deferring) are chapters from an intended novel. Told in a stream-of-consciousness style, these stories sketch a woman writer’s life, from her youth in Baguio, up to her First Quarter Storm awakening.

“Manggagagamot ng Salay-salay” won first prize at the 1978 Palanca Awards.   Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

During the day of the grand cañao (indigenous ritual feast in Benguet), an Igorot gets into a brawl with his American employer after the latter’s sexual innuendos. “Ang Tugtugin ni Kabayan” (The Music of Kabayan) and “Pagka’t Ako, si Naciana Madrigal, Ay Laging May Ipinagpapaliban” (For I, Naciana Madrigal, Am Always Deferring) are chapters from an intended novel. Told in a stream-of-consciousness style, these stories sketch a woman writer’s life, from her youth in Baguio, up to her First Quarter Storm awakening.
“Manggagagamot ng Salay-salay” won first prize at the 1978 Palanca Awards.   Written by Jay Jomar F. Quintos

article_title: The Many Ways of Being Muslim: Fiction by Filipino Muslims
text:
Published 2008. Editor, Coeli Barry. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Despite the diversity of subject matter, the 22 stories by nine authors in this collection all speak about characters, whether Muslim or Christian, whose main concern is society’s rejection of those who are different.

The collection opens with Ibrahim Jubaira’s “Blue Blood of the Big Astana,” which compresses the history of the Filipino Muslims in the story of the harelipped Jaafar, a servant of a dayang-dayang (princess). His physical deformity having ensured his exclusion from society, his closeness to the dayang-dayang gives him hope that he too might live a normal life. In the end, when the Christian government comes in conflict with the Muslim royal families, Jaafar finds himself trying very hard to be part of the new order of things, while his beloved dayang-dayang ends up with nothing, not even her dignity. This story is symbolic of the destruction of the proud sultanates that used to dominate much of Muslim Mindanao.

The theme of alienation continues in “Obituary for Today” by Noralyn Mustafa. The town idiot’s funeral provides the occasion for the various members of the community to come together and hence the opportunity for the story’s dissection of their lives and motivations. But, even as the focus is on these people, the narrative always returns to how the idiot Pilo, despite his unobtrusiveness, shaped their lives, their worldviews, and their many resentments. Pilo, after all, was the son of a prominent judge, and while his eccentricities brought shame to his family, the people who really knew him actually liked him.

“The Trip to a Forbidden Land” by Loren Hallilah Lao, “Maghrib” by Pearlsha Abubakar, and “Mukna” by Arifah Jamil are stories about the problems that young Muslim women face even within their own families. The many different beliefs and traditions represented in these stories give rise to conflicts with modernity and tensions accompanying interactions with the Christian majority

The stories are arranged chronologically from 1941 to 2004. In the early stories, the problems of alienation are explicitly shown to be the effect of difficulties preventing the Muslims’ full integration into Philippine society. Bewilderment, sometimes mixed with humor, is the tone employed in many of these older stories. In the later ones, however, the alienation is depicted with an undertone of rebellion.

But even in the darker hues of the newer stories, hope emerges from time to time. In Mehol Sadain’s “Old Father,” a young boy takes to heart the fantastic stories that his seemingly addled grandfather told him, and when he comes back to bury his grandfather, he is left with a sense of validation of those tales. He knows that in him, in his generation, rest the hopes and dreams of his forefathers, and that Filipino Muslims will always find their way back to who they are.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: Marcel M. Navarra: Mga Piling Kuwentong Sebuwano
text:
(Marcel M. Navarra: Selected Cebuano Stories). Published 1986. Author, Marcel Navarra. Editor and translator, Teresita G. Maceda. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Panitikan Series.

The 12 short stories in the book were published in the Cebuano magazines Bisaya, Bulak, and Alimyon between the years 1930 and 1955. The introduction includes a brief biographical account of Navarra and a commentary on the stories included in the collection. In a literary tradition that was dominated by sentimentalism and didacticism, Navarra was the first Cebuano writer to realistically depict the life of the lower class in Cebu, particularly in the small town of Tuyom. His stories are characterized by a restrained style, the ironic twist, and a pessimistic worldview.

The theme of poverty permeates all of his stories; and his characters are farmers, hacienda workers, rural people set in wartimes, and rural migrants to the city. “Apasumpay” (Postscript) is evidence of Navarra’s deft handling of the modern short story conventions, such as the flashback device and imagery. The first-person point of view is used in this story to depict the narrator as a victim of psychological compulsion. “Ug Gianod Ako” (And I Was Carried Away) is Navarra’s award-winning story that brought attention to his writing. Again a story of psychological realism, it portrays a friendship ruined by a man’s surrender to his baser instincts.

“Tingali ang Adlaw Mosilang Ugma” (Maybe the Sun Will Rise Tomorrow) is marked by the absence of a conventional plot. It follows the consciousness of the characters Dikoy and Garita, a married couple who are tenant farmers. The tragic ending, in which the couple receive the news that they are about to be evicted, is ironically emphasized by the sun suddenly breaking out after a spell of bad weather. “Si Zosimo” (Zosimo) lends an element of magic realism to the landlord-versus-tenant theme. Zosimo, the tenant, can overtake a jeepney, catch fish in a rocky yard, and carry a carabao by the horns as he climbs up a coconut tree. “Si Manang Merin ug ang Kasing” (Manang Merin and the Top), set in a copra plantation, and “Pahigmata” (The Awakening) are initiation stories, with hunger as an underlying theme.

Two stories explore the contrast between city and barrio. “Ang Kalibutan Matapos” (The World Will End) dabbles in a bit of black humor. Ingko Bayon, having returned to the barrio after living a life of dissipation in the city, is convinced that the end of the world has come as a typhoon rages outside his hut. However, when he finally works up the courage to stand up against the storm, something falls on his head and knocks him unconscious. “Ang Tawo nga Nangita sa Katahum” (The Man Who Searched for Beauty) is a semiautobiographical story. A successful Cebuano writer named Carlos Miramar, residing in Tuyom, is visited by publisher Ben Medida from the city to invite him to be magazine editor. The story affirms that happiness lies in detachment from material desires, even if one lives amidst poverty.”

“Ang Hunsoy Sungsongan Usab” (The Empty Clay Pipe), “Paingon sa Bag-ong Kalibutan” (Toward a New World), and “Usa Niana ka Gabii” (One Evening) are three war stories that take a cynical look at the way the rural folk are caught between their enemy, the Japanese forces, and their supposed allies, the local guerrillas and MacArthur’s troops.

Navarra shows that even outside Tuyom there is no escaping the poverty that is the lot of those who work the soil. “Sa Lunhawng Tugwayanan” (In the Green Fields) is set in a hacienda or plantation outside Tuyom and later at a Mindanao homestead. In the hacienda, the workers’ lives are defined by their low wages and debt peonage; at the homestead, nature plays a cruel joke on the farmers.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: May Buhay sa Looban at 20 Kuwento
text:
(There Is Life in the Slums and 20 Stories). Published 1996. Author, Pedro S. Dandan. With an introduction by Virgilio S. Almario. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Written between the post-World War II years and the early 1970s, this posthumous collection of 21 stories charts a period of great transition for the country. This is manifest in such subjects as the city’s physical configuration in “May Buhay sa Looban” (There Is Life in the Slums); the rural landscape in “Ang Kalabaw at ang Tren” (The Carabao and the Train) and “Paalam kay Kalakian” (Farewell to Kalakian); and history in “Ang Inahing Aso at Limang Tuta” (A Dog and Her Five Puppies), “Sugat ng Digma” (Wound of War), “Ang Kalmen at Batumbuhay … sa Isang Estero” (The Scapular and Stone … at an Estuary).

The title story is a bildungsroman that follows 13-year-old Popoy, whose facade of toughness is shaken by his family’s impending move to Dampalit, possibly in Malabon, then a town in the suburban province of Rizal. His father, a writer who is looking to enter the real-life Commonwealth Literary Contests, bemoans the lack of love, beauty, and life in the ugly surroundings of the looban, a labyrinthine network of slums in Dandan’s Tondo. In the same breath, however, his father enumerates the sights and sounds in the slums, the constant bustle and activity, the cast of characters that, to Popoy and the reader both, are enough evidence of “life.” This delineation between literary illusion and immediate reality is revisited in “Kalapating May Sugat sa Dibdib” (Dove with a Wounded Breast), in which an aging writer pines over a “beloved” whom he has “bought” from a brothel with proceeds from his last novel. He reflects on the little control writers have over their own lives, unlike the material for art at their disposal.

The other stories that probe various aspects of city life are by turns tragic and humorous: “Nasa Dugo ni Tana” (It Runs in Tana’s Blood) is on gambling addiction; “Isang Showdown sa Tundo” (A Showdown in Tondo), on street violence; “Batman,” on mental health; and “Mabangis na Kamay, Maamong Kamay” (Ferocious Hand, Tame Hand), on grinding poverty.

In the rural stories, the carabao is a prominent figure, whose death signals such change and transition. Tradition and modernity clash in “Ang Kalabaw at ang Tren,” in which a train collides with the carabao; and in “Paalam kay Kalakian,” about the impending replacement of carabaos by tractors.

The stories that invoke the war are the most unflinching in their brutality. In “Palitan” (Exchange), a man trades his son for a sack of rice to feed his starving wife and their four other children. In “Ang Inahing Aso at Limang Tuta” (The Dog and Her Five Puppies), extreme hunger drives a young boy to take extreme measures. “At Nupling ang Isang Lunting Halaman” (And a Green Bud Sprouts) follows the last excruciating moments of a soldier amid an exchange of gunfire and retreat.

Perhaps the most tragic and allegorical in the lot, “Ang Kalmen at Batumbuhay … sa Isang Estero” revolves around the vagrant Mang Simo, who was an informal settler in Intramuros before his eviction. When he is run over by a train, bystanders partake of his possessions and capitalize on his death. Toward the story’s close, Mang Simo’s full name and his important but forgotten contribution to Philippine history are revealed.

The narratives and lives in this collection are bleak, although every now and then the collection breaks into a smile, whether it is due to an odd sexual awakening in “Burlesque,” an anticlimactic brawl in “Isang Showdown sa Tundo,” or a surprising act of gratification in “Nakayungyong ang Kawayan” (The Bamboo Bows).

Virgilio S. Almario notes in his introduction that Dandan’s prose is invariably lyrical and winding, and his modes alternate between philosophical and austere realism. This range reveals Dandan’s mastery of both craft and subject, especially in rendering history and its devastations.

The following stories won Palanca awards: “Mabangis na Kamay … Maamong Kamay,” second prize, 1951; “Sugat ng Digma,” first prize, 1957; “Lakas” (Strength), third prize, 1958; “Ang Anino ng Kanyang Ama” (His Father’s Shadow), second prize, 1966; and “Ang Daong ni Noe” (Noe’s Anchor), first prize, 1972.  Written by Glenn Diaz

text:
(Streams in the Desert). Published 1962. Editor, Efren Abueg. Mandaluyong: Cacho Hermanos. Reprinted, Manila: National Book Store, 1974. Quezon City: C & E Publishing, 2010.

A collection of 15 stories by some of the youngest fictionists of the 1960s, Mga Agos sa Disyerto self-consciously points to itself as the life-giving waters that would inundate the desert that was Tagalog literature by opening it to modernist influences. The writers in this anthology are Edgardo Reyes, Rogelio Sikat aka Rogelio Sicat, Efren Abueg, Eduardo Bautista Reyes, and Rogelio Ordoñez.

Borrowing their norms from the formalist doctrines, the writers considered the works of older writers inartistic, as these texts lent themselves to sentimentality and didacticism. Contextualized against the achievements of fiction in English, traditional fiction suffered in comparison. Where the likes of Nick Joaquin, Bienvenido Santos, and Wilfrido Nolledo were writing pieces in English with consummate artistry and skill, many Tagalog writers were still showing the influences of such writers as Fausto Galauran and Francisco Laksamana.

Thus, the collection must be viewed as a kind of revolt against the canonized forms of writing in Tagalog literature and an expression of the writers’ attempt to prove that they too could fashion artistic texts that repudiated the qualities valued in traditional fiction writing.

Modern fictional techniques and strategies were used in the delineation of character and the composition of various points of view, in the complex treatment of plot structure, in the exploration of language to constitute varied realities, and in the creation of psychological dimensions to give depth of character. The works in the collection were deeply immersed in the world as constructed by the likes of John Steinbeck, Ernest Hemingway, and John Dos Passos, writers whose texts depicted the world of the defeated and the dispossessed, and whose themes generally dealt with alienation.

Violence pervades most of these stories, shaping even the most private accounts of young love, as in Abueg’s “Sa Bagong Paraiso” (In the New Paradise), in which two characters attempt to grapple with the norms and strictures of a society that denies them their personal happiness. In Reyes’s “Yaong Tinatawag na Habag” (That Which Is Called Disconsolation), the use of naturalistic details helps create the impression of profound despair. Sikat’s “Tata Selo” (Old Man Selo) presents many forms of violence and is probably the most dramatic presentation of how violence determines much of reality. In Mirasol’s “Mga Aso sa Lagarian” (Dogs in the Sawmill), violence is imaged graphically in the dog that devours meat juxtaposed with the plight of the laborers in a sawmill. Edgardo Reyes’s stories pay attention to the ravaged world of children in “Di Maabot ng Kawalang-Malay” (Innocence Cannot Reach), and the systematic destruction of the barrio by unfeeling relatives from the city in “Lugmok Na ang Nayon” (The Village Has Fallen). In these stories the reader gets the impression that the world is controlled by some malevolent force that delights in seeing characters suffer.

The stories in Mga Agos sa Disyerto are crucial to the development of contemporary fiction in the Philippines. The entry of these young fictionists in the 1960s provided a much-needed impetus in order to construct other strategies for constituting contemporary realities. By drawing on Western techniques, the writers of this collection succeeded in exploring familiar experiences with more care and attention to craft.  Written by Soledad Reyes

 

Source

Lumbera, Bienvenido L. 1967. “The Literary Relations of Tagalog Literature.” In Brown Heritage: Essays in Philippine Cultural Tradition, ed. Antonio G. Manuud, 323-30. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

text:
(Stories of Grandma Basyang). Published 1963. Author, Severino Reyes. Editor, Jose Villa Panganiban. Three volumes. Manila: Surian ng Wikang Pambansa. A second collection was edited by Pedrito Reyes, two volumes. Quezon City: Severino Reyes Publishing Corporation, 1975.

Lola Basyang is a familiar figure in modern Philippine folklore as the purveyor of fairy tales, fables, parables, and fantasies, all of which had a large following when they appeared in Liwayway magazine, and later aired over the radio. The universe of Lola Basyang is peopled by a colorful constellation of characters who are magical, mythical, religious, romantic, or supernatural, who dwell on the earth, underground, under the sea, in the sky, and in enchanted places. These characters are drawn from metrical romance stories, ancient folklore, local legends, apocrypha, and the like. While the primary object of Lola Basyang’s storytelling is to entertain, the didactic or moralistic content of the stories has had a great impact, particularly on young listeners or readers to whom they are primarily addressed. The legendary narrator of the stories is herself a fictitious character, the real author being Severino Reyes, who was a pioneering figure in Tagalog theater. However, there was indeed a Lola Basyang who served as Reyes’s inspiration in writing his stories. (Golden Stories 1925-1935). Published 1936. Editors, Alejandro G. Abadilla and Clodualdo del Mundo. Reprinted, Manila: Alberto S. Florentino, 1972.

 

The legacy of Abadilla and del Mundo lies not only in their creative works but also in their critical writings. Pioneers in literary criticism in the field of Tagalog literature, they wrote critical essays about the poems and stories written during their time. Their anthologies of what they considered the best works by Tagalog writers constituted, in themselves, a critical appreciation and judgment of literary pieces. In their preface to Mga Kuwentong Ginto, the anthologists declare that the anthology consists of pieces that, first of all, can qualify as short stories, since many fiction-type pieces have been written lacking the content and/or structure of the genre.

The stories in this collection do not merely represent the best in a given year, but also what the editors consider to be the best work of a short-story writer among several. According to the editors, the stories can be grouped according to the style of the writer and their effect on readers: those which give a general sense of pleasure to the ordinary reader, such as “Nalantang Krisantemo” (Withered Chrysanthemum) by Buenaventura G. Medina, and “Doktor: Diyata?” (Doctor, Can It Be?) by Remigio Mat. Castro; those which strictly hew to the strictures of the modern short story genre, and still appeal to the taste of the majority used to traditional fare, such as “Sugat ng Alaala” (Memory’s Wound) by Fausto J. Galauran, “Pag-ibig na Walang Kanluran” (Undying Love) by Alberto Segismundo Cruz, and “Balatkayo” (Disguise) by Carmen S. Herrera; and those which use modern techniques in fiction in vogue during the period, as in the case of “Ulilang-Ulila” (Thoroughly Orphaned) by Gregorio N. Garcia, and “Ulilang Bituin” (Lone Star) by Brigido C. Batungbakal.

Two short stories, considered by the editors as resembling prose poems, are included. These are “Ako’y Mayroong Isang Ibon” (I Have a Bird) by Deogracias A. Rosario and “Takipsilim” (Dusk) by Antonio G. Sempio. Other stories included are the following: “Hiwaga” (Mystery) by Arsenio R. Afan; “Ay! Ay!” (Oh! Oh!) by Rosalia L. Aguinaldo; “Paniningil ng Isang Alila” (A Servant’s Revenge) by Salvador N. Barros; “Anak” (Child) by Carmen A. Batacan; “Tubig sa Buslo” (Water in the Basket) by Mateo Cruz Cornelio; “Hindi Maaari” (Not Allowed) by Teodoro E. Gener; “Nang Matapos ang Pangarap” (When the Dream Died) by Jovito Martinez-Memije; “Impong Sela” (Old Woman Sela) by Epifanio Gar. Matute; and “Pusong Uhaw sa Pag-ibig” (Heart Thirsty for Love) by Iñigo Ed. Regalado. Each story is introduced by a one-paragraph synopsis of the basic theme of the story, as well as its most outstanding quality as a piece of fiction.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Men of the East and Other Stories
text:
Published 1990. Author, Charlson Ong. Manila: Kalikasan Press. Reprinted, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 1999.

In most of the six short stories in this collection, stubborn sons and even more stubborn fathers are the central characters, through whom Ong examines the Chinese Filipino experience. In the title story, “Men of the East,” a boy shelters his friend’s grandmother, who is the lone survivor of a village massacre. His strict, superstitious father, himself fleeing from his own ghosts of war-torn China, vigorously protests. In “Rain,” the new, much younger female employee at an old umbrella shop exacerbates the already strained relationship between its owners: a father who insists on living in the past and his only remaining son.

In “Owl,” a young man caring for his emaciated, comatose father is visited by a ghost from his father’s past: a half-sister, abandoned in childhood, seeking what she is owed. In “The Hanging, Tomorrow,” exile, torture, death, and kinship across two lands are explored through the lives of three generations of men: a prisoner of war, his exiled son, and the idealistic grandson. Their lives eerily echo one another.

In “Another Country,” a homesick young man—a huaqiao (Chinese born outside of China)—finds work as a journalist in a bustling Taiwan plagued with earthquakes. He is there “to learn more about China” but falls in love with a Filipina masseuse/prostitute instead. In “A Song of War,” a high school student secretly visits his Chinese-language teacher, who reveals his tragic, revolutionary past and his present secrets.

Ong writes about the harrowing topics of war, loss, and xenophobia with a deft hand and in elegant prose. This collection provides poignant views of generations of Chinese immigrants and the lives they lead in distant lands. The stories that won prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature are “Men of the East,” third prize, 1985; “Another Country,” third prize, 1987; and “Owl,” third prize, 1989. “Another Country” also won second prize in the short story competition of the magazine Asiaweek, 1988.  Written by Katrina del Rosario

text:
Published 1983. Author, Arturo B. Rotor. With a foreword by Francisco Arcellana. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

The Men Who Play God is a collection of 10 short stories about doctors, patients, and the ailments that not only call for a cure but also provoke a philosophical search for meaning in death and mortality. Rotor’s doctors struggle to arrive at the correct diagnosis not only to treat patients but also to solve ethical or moral dilemmas.

The book’s title story, “The Men Who Play God,” establishes the shared time and setting of the collection. Setting the tone for the life-and-death decisions that doctors must make about their patients are the rich and detailed contrasts between Taft Avenue, Ermita, and Malate during the American era and these places in the late 1970s and 1980s; a quoted passage from History and Description of the Philippine General Hospital; and the limited equipment of the government hospital. The godlike role that the doctors play is emphasized when they convene to decide which of their patients gets the one vacant room available in the Philippine General Hospital (PGH). All three patients have equally critical conditions, but the decision lies in the personal preference of the physicians.

The doctors and patients in each story wrestle with mortality and morality. Dr Morales, protagonist of “The Orchid of Five Wounds,” forgoes the objectivity demanded by the field as he seeks meaning in the unfortunate blinding and possible demise of a young, kindhearted girl named Inday. The three doctors in “Club Euthanasia” debate the morality of ending the life of a comatose individual. In “Santiago’s Syndrome,” a patient comes to terms with a mysterious illness, which brings fame to the medical community and death to him. Even the socioeconomic aspects of the medical field are subjected to Rotor’s philosophical eye: in “Judas Iscariot, MD,” the title character clinically assesses a patient’s ability to pay.

“The Jubilarians” is ostensibly an account of a PGH alumni homecoming, the underlying theme being the passing of time and the body’s deterioration. The temporary is similarly adverted to in “The Balikbayan Doctor,” where Dr Ramos is conflicted between living the life he has worked hard for in the United States and returning to his roots.

“The Clinical Trials” borrows elements from the fable by situating animals in a medical conference, and “The MD and the Faith Healer” contrasts science and indigenous healing methods. In both, however, Rotor employs the logical and exact language of medicine.

In his foreword to the book, Arcellana characterizes the stories as ones that “only a doctor of medicine could have written.” The stories are creations of a doctor’s memory and a writer’s imagination, both of which Rotor possessed. Each story explores how people, whether doctor or patient, attempt to play God in the confines of a hospital and only within the limits of their human capacity. Rotor’s characters are smart, proud, and accomplished, yet the situations they are in raise questions of power and powerlessness in the face of pain, suffering, and imminent death.  Written by Angela L. Velasco

article_title: The Music Child and Other Stories
text:
Published 1991. Author, Alfred Yuson. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This book demonstrates Yuson’s versatility as he deftly handles with equal ease a variety of modes and styles: the realistic, surrealist, fabulist, nostalgic, and satirical.

Two are memoir pieces rather than stories. In “Big Street,” the nine-year-old narrator and his family live in a rented second floor of a house on Dimasalang Street. He spends magic moments with a friend, listening through a pipe to underground elves and playing pranks on passersby with a 10-centavo bill tied to a string. The family moves away three years later when a bout of heavy drinking ends with the boy’s father running for his life from the landlord’s gun-toting stepson. “Avenida Vignettes” hops through random episodes in the narrator’s life as it is bounded by Avenida Rizal and with Gordon MacRae singing “The Desert Song” as leitmotif. The piece is dotted with landmarks like the Grand Opera House, where a youthful Pilita Corrales is a magician’s assistant; the big bookstore, where he is caught stealing Nabokov’s Lolita; and the Odeon theater, where two corrupt policemen prey on him but also treat him to a meal at Golden Star.

Two children’s tales are “The Boy Who Ate Stars” and “The Mountain That Grew.” The first is about greed and its dire consequences. A stranger comes to the village and grants a boy’s wish to eat all the stars in the sky, just as he gives the villagers everything they want in exchange for the right to cut down their trees. In the second tale, a mountain that grows steadily up to heaven is invaded by people wanting to climb it. When the mountain mysteriously stops growing, the villagers offer their conjectures and dream up tentative solutions.

“Voice in the Hills” is a well-made, coming-of-age story set in 1986, at the start of the Corazon Aquino administration. Fourteen-year-old Bingo’s circumcision marks his entry into adulthood as he makes the obligatory choice between two opposing forces, here represented by government soldiers and mountain rebels. In the title story, “The Music Child,” the first-person narrator, an American journalist, is hunting for exotic stories when he stumbles upon Luisito. This 10-year-old mestizo sings everything he says, not only in the human languages of his Spanish-Scottish father, Don Julio, and of the native plantation workers, but also of the numberless languages of nature and its wildlife. In the end, the American is thrown in the midst of a war between the indigenous people, led by Don Julio, and the loggers encroaching upon their lands.

“A Balikbayan Christmas” is a satire that begins in a Vegas casino, where a Filipino card dealer’s huge winnings at the slot machine give him reason to return home for Christmas. From the Ninoy Aquino International Airport to Bulacan, he is met with a string of misfortunes that he recounts so cheerfully that they feel like any Filipino’s lot in life: his missing balikbayan boxes, the gauntlet of airport extortionists, a hijacking, a military siege, a typhoon, hometown spongers, and finally a firecracker blowing two of his fingers off. It is Yuson’s deadpan humor that preempts what might otherwise be a distressful story.

“Romance and Faith on Mount Banahaw” is a “romance” told in the mixed modes of surrealism, science fiction, and allegory. Cops leap out of the TV set. A punk from Saturn sings in falsetto at an interplanetary drinking party. A windmill sends people flying from a pit “across dragons’ lands, yoga deserts, and corned beef forests.” But the 11 demons on Mount Banahaw are the most prosaic elements in the story, most being unambiguous stereotypes of the ills that plague Philippine society and the rest being simply the irksome details of daily life.

Three of the eight stories in this collection won in the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: “Romance and Faith on Mount Banahaw,” first prize, 1975; “The Boy Who Ate Stars,” second prize, 1990; and “The Music Child,” second prize, 1991. “Voice in the Hills” won first prize in the 1987 short story competition of Asiaweek magazine and is anthologized in Prizewinning Asian Fiction, edited by Leon Comber, Hong Kong University Press, 1991.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

Published 1997. Author, Carlos Ojeda Aureus. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Second edition, with an introduction by Paz Verdades M. Santos, Naga: Ateneo de Naga University Press, 2012.

Nagueños is a collection of stories set in the streets, schools, and churches of Naga, the “Queen City” of Bicol. In her introduction to the 2012 edition, Paz Verdades M. Santos lists four major themes of the collection: desire for woman, death and resurrection, the search for deity, and the sacred feminine. Suffusing the stories are nostalgia for the solemnity and ritual of the pre-Concilar Church and the anxious search for meaning and true spirituality upon the coming of the new millennium.

The loss of faith in the post-Concilar Church is emblematic of death, while the struggle to keep or regain that faith is emblematic of resurrection. This struggle is central to nearly every story in Nagueños. In “Typhoon,” it is explicitly dramatized directly when its narrator, Father Itos, contemplates leaving the Church after its rigid and patriarchal laws ostracize a battered housewife for seeking refuge with another man. In most of the stories, however, the crises of faith are couched in other, less obviously religious narratives, tying the personal and the spiritual together with the tropes of death and resurrection.

The most common narrative involves the erotic desire of middle-aged men for young women. In “The Late Comer,” Epifanio Bagting, whose marriage is on the rocks, struggles against his lust for a certain Suzette Uy, the classmate of his niece. Similarly, in “Chinita,” ex-seminarian Rick Caceres struggles with both the loss of faith and his sudden desire to impress a college girl named Cynthia Dee. The story continues in “Sanctuary,” where Rick and Cynthia are accosted by a gang of thugs as they are discussing the cosmic battle between good and evil. Somewhat related to these is “Reunion,” published in the second edition, whose middle-aged narrator sulks over his insignificance during a class reunion, but who is reenergized upon encountering a young woman named Pandora.

The acceptance of death also appears in these stories. In “The Night Express Does Not Stop Here Anymore,” a mother wrestles with faith and forgiveness after the brutal murder of her son in a fraternity hazing. In “Flakes of Fire, Bodies of Light,” Tanya keeps her husband alive on life support though he wills and wishes to die.

Finally, there is the comedic and somewhat out-of-place “Wings,” which follows a man’s attempt to get over his fear of flying so he can live a fuller life and talk to beautiful women.

Nagueños is often compared to Dubliners, but it is more limited in its perspective. Nearly every story centers on a middle-aged man steeped in Catholic theology, brooding over Vatican II. All these men are essentially the same person, and their overall limitations are seen best in the stories’ portrayals of women. The women in Nagueños are important symbols—of purity, innocence, nature, temptation, commitment, or hope—and as connections to the primal and the natural or to the mystical Sacred Feminine. The nostalgia for solemnity and ritual is identified with a return to the Sacred Feminine, itself identified with both the Virgin Mary and with the many young women. But the men are the centers of discourse; it is from them alone that the women learn—if ever—the intricacies of Catholicism and the significance of its rituals. The women, serving merely metaphorical functions, are objectified: they are significant only vis-à-vis their destabilizing or reenergizing effect on the discourses of the men. Only in “Typhoon” is the woman’s narrative equal in stature to that of the man’s, and only in “The Night Express Does Not Stop Here Anymore” do women play central roles as subjects of the story’s discourse.

Nagueños is a valuable contribution to Bikol literature, using recurring characters, cultural references, and meticulous detail to construct a cohesive portrait of Naga at the end of the 20th century.   Written by Dominic Sy

article_title: Now and at the Hour and Other Stories
text:
Published 1957. Author, Aida L. Rivera (Ford). Manila: Benipayo Press.

This collection is made up of the five stories which won for the author the Jules and Avery Hopwood Award for Fiction in 1954, while she was working for master of arts degree in English language and literature at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. The stories had been published in the Diliman Review, This Week, and Sands and Coral, the literary magazine of Silliman University, where the author obtained her bachelor of arts degree.

The stories depict the human struggle for survival in times of war and peace. “Now and at the Hour,” “The Madonna Face,” and “Young Liberator,” set in the Bacolod of the war years and onto liberation, speak of human behavior when threatened, caught between keeping death at a distance and keeping values and cultural identity intact against the onslaughts of invader and liberator. Mr Asuncion mysteriously disappears from a convent turned into a home for the displaced and dislocated. Marilou de Juan latches on to Captain Ishmaru. “Love in the Cornhusks” and “The Chieftest Mourner” portray women’s struggles for survival, and the struggles are identified with selfhood. For Tinay, the struggle is a life turned miserable after she marries a Bagobo man; tragedy is in a letter she receives too late. The other woman, unnamed, her mascara running down her cheeks, gives up her share of a man’s funeral, finally.

The stories also show, not just the author’s “excellent control of … material” and very high “craft-sense,” as cited by Nolan Miller, novelist and member of the board of judges of the contest, but a fine wit. Pictures on the wall of the Mendez home in “Young Liberator” are of the “two very dead-looking ancestors.” Aunt Sophia in “The Chieftest Mourner,” reporting on her estranged husband’s getting thinner and thinner, is “now crowding Mama off the sofa.”

Written in the 1950s, the stories show irony, tension, and emotionalism held in check, a quality admired by the then emerging New Critics.  Written by Lolita R. Lacuesta

text:
Published 1984. Author, Jose Y. Dalisay. Manila: Asphodel Books. Second edition, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 2002. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for fiction, 1985.

The collection contains 10 short stories written from 1978 to 1984. They traverse time and space, from precolonial times to post-World War II, from local beaches to a diner in New York City.

Love and desire are common themes in these stories. “Beloved,” the most experimental in style, is about a despairing man and the prostitute he desires. In “The Mirror,” a man must find the perfect gift to appease his betrothed. “Cameo” chronicles a boy’s first love and its brutal end. The same theme is found in two pieces of flash fiction. In “Kiss Me Goodbye,” the protagonist whiles away the nights in bars along Cubao, while in “Message to Zenocrate” a dying man laments an old but still stinging infidelity. Youth and aging appear in “Revelations,” which tells of a boy and an old sweeper who meet every afternoon in the park

America’s ineluctable presence in the lives of Filipinos is the basis of two very different stories. In the highly comedic “Spy Story,” Fred, a chauffeur for the US embassy, believes that he is working for the CIA as he brings dignitaries to the strip clubs of Manila. “Oldtimer” follows two Filipino-Americans, a minor and an oldtimer, who become business partners in a successful New York City diner.

Politics and social reality come into play in some of the stories. “The First of Our Dead” recounts the death of a student activist from the eyes of his comrades, while “Heartland” follows a disillusioned surgeon in the 1896 Revolution. Published in the thick of the Marcos dictatorship, these stories are powerful critiques of the violence, anomie, and loss of innocence that characterized life under the dictatorship.

In this, Dalisay’s first book, a variety of subjects and styles proliferate, from the realism of “Cameo” and the unreliable narration of “Beloved,” to the comical “Spy Story” and the historical “The Mirror” and “Heartland.” All these announce the skill and versatility of the young Dalisay who has since become one of the most renowned Filipino writers in English.  Written by Dominic Sy

text:
PAGLUWAS (Going to the City). Published 2006. Author, Zosimo Quibilan Jr. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Manila Critics Circle’s National Book Award for fiction, 2007; Madrigal-Gonzalez Best First Book Award, 2008.

This collection of 52 dagli (vignettes) traces the lives of different people before they intersect in a mysterious accident involving a bus bound from Baguio City to Manila. Written in crisp, colloquial Filipino, the vignettes take their titles from mundane objects, such as a camera, a nail clipper, and a lipstick, that figure as symbols in them. These stories serve as fragments that construct the larger narrative of the tragedy. Thus, the book straddles a short story collection and the form of a novel.

The characters come from various walks of life, but an ominous sense of foreboding is present in all the narratives, resulting in an “imagined community,” as Benedict Anderson conceives it. In a narrow space of no more than four pages, each vignette puts the characters in unpleasant or dangerous situations, whether a failed relationship in “Visitor Pass” and “Tinidor” (Fork), impending expulsion from school in “Capo,” or domestic conflict in “Crayola” and “Levi’s 501.” The opening story, “Silinyador” (Brake), about the bus driver’s premonitions of death a few moments before the accident, foregrounds the sense of collective or shared tragedy.

The narratives in the first half of the collection bear references to the martial law period. In “Kondensada” (Condensed Milk) and “Pop Cola,” ordinary citizens confront the perils posed by the Philippine Constabulary Metrocom in their neighborhood. In “Martilyo” (Hammer), somebody’s son climbs up the roof to witness the EDSA Revolt, only to have an accident.

The middle part of the collection is metafictional. The story “Rearview Mirror” situates the preceding vignettes within the narrative of the bus accident. A driver passing the scene of the accident finds not a single body but sees a rearview mirror and a piece of paper which bears the first few lines of “Rearview Mirror.”

The vignettes in the second half of the collection are located in the post-EDSA milieu, with references to the 1999 film The Virgin Suicides in “Vitamins” and Figaro Coffee Company in “Tasa” (Cup). The sudden shift from the milieu of the earlier narratives suggests that the accident mysteriously occurs in two time frames.

The final vignette, “Alarm Clock,” returns to the territory of metafiction explored earlier. As the investigator interrogates the character in “Rearview Mirror,” he discovers that he himself is enclosed in the fiction surrounding the accident. Instead of closing the narrative full circle, the collection, in its excursion to the various genres of fiction, inaugurates its characters’ own trip or pagluwas into the ever-shifting terrains of reality.  Written by Laurence Marvin Castillo

text:
Published 1995. Author, Jose Y. Dalisay. Mandaluyong City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

In each of the seven stories and one novella in this collection, characters attempt but fail to make connections with other people. The more that they try to rise above the frustration, the more they end up sinking into it because of some flaw in their character. The rather bleak states of the characters are in marked contrast to the beauty of the prose employed by the author.

The main character in the short story “Penmanship” takes pride in his old-fashioned way of writing letters (with a roller pen, not a typewriter), but try as he might, the beauty of his penmanship is incongruous with the plainness of the world he inhabits. He tries to connect with, and perhaps find solace in the blind woman who is sent to work for him, but he discovers that even her life is more colorful than his own.

“Dessert” depicts the simple flirtation between Matilda and her former college instructor and is told from both viewpoints. While the situation brims with sexual tension, both characters speak of everything but the attraction they feel for each other. In the end, both are frustrated by their inability to create even the most basic of human links. Bowing to the social realities they find themselves in, they deny their true selves.

In “Delivery,” Protacio, an underling of Mr O, volunteers to return a wreath sent to his boss. He is also given an envelope to deliver to the general. Protacio, however, is so overcome by greed that he ends up bungling what should have been a simple task. In this story, the author continues his theme of how humans carry the seeds of their own destruction, even in the most humdrum of situations.

In the novella Voyager, the main character is a Spaniard who has found peace in the colony but is then manipulated by his superiors into assassinating the son of a prominent Filipino family who they suspect has ties to the native resistance. Caught in a dilemma, he does what he believes he could live with. For most of his life, the main character has found himself being like a ship floating from place to place, eager to sell beliefs and comforts for adventure and for profit. In the end, he decides that such a life is meaningless.

In this book Dalisay shows that he is a penetrating writer, able to depict in beautiful prose the condition of people ensnared by their weakness and their superficiality. His vision, however, is not completely bleak, for his protagonists are not simply pawns of fate but act of their own free will.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

text:
PHILIPPINESHORTSTORIES 1925-1940

Published 1975. Editor, Leopoldo Y. Yabes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

 

PHILIPPINE SHORT STORIES 1941-1955: PART 1 (1941-1949)

Published 1981. Editor, Leopoldo Y. Yabes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

 

PHILIPPINE SHORT STORIES 1941-1955: PART 2 (1950-1955)

Published 1981. Editor, LeopoldoY.Yabes. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This three-volume anthology of 220 short stories in English by Filipinos was started by Professor Yabes in 1940 as part of a planned compilation of “Readings in Philippine Literature” (poems, short stories, essays, and plays). Almost 35 years later, the first volume was published, and includes what Yabes considers “the best short stories written in English by the more important Filipino writers before the outbreak of the war in the Pacific. It constitutes the first recorded attempt to collect together in one volume the worthwhile stories that were published between 1925—the year the first Filipino short story in English appeared in a Filipino-owned and Filipino-edited periodical in English—and 1940.”

The volume has a threefold purpose: “to preserve in a more permanent and handy form the best that have been produced in English by Filipino short story writers; to give a better chance for these writers to be known and appreciated abroad; and to help promote better understanding between the Filipinos and other peoples.” Obviously the compelling motive then was to introduce Filipino writers to the English-reading public abroad.

The anthology is historical and critical, and sometimes, Yabes admits, “it was necessary to include some inferior stories of an earlier year and exclude obviously better stories of a later date, because the former were the best of the crop published in that particular period, and to exclude them would leave a gap in the chronology of the anthology.”

An essay, “Pioneering in the Filipino Short Story in English,” written in 1941, precedes the anthology proper of 1925-40 volume, which starts with Paz Marquez Benitez’s “Dead Stars,” and includes such writers as Casiano T. Calalang, Loreto Paras, Paz Latorena, Jose Garcia Villa, Arturo B. Rotor, Juan Cabreros Laya, Sinai C. Hamada, Amador T. Daguio, Bienvenido N. Santos, Manuel E. Arguilla, Lydia C. Villanueva, N. V. M. Gonzalez, Narciso G. Reyes, Francisco Arcellana, Consorcio Borje, Hernando R. Ocampo, Estrella Alfon, Alfredo E. Litiatco, Conrado V. Pedroche, I. V. Mallari, and at the very end, before the glossary and notes on contributors, Nick Joaquin and Teodoro M. Locsin.

The 164 stories from 1941 to 1955 are divided into two volumes, and a preface explains that the 15-year period “constitutes a most critical era in the history of the nation—war and Japanese occupation, restoration of the Commonwealth government in Manila, proclamation of independence, birth of the republic, euphoria and disenchantment,” and that the stories reflect this. The authors include some already in the first volume, like Nick Joaquin, and more who are not: Edilberto Tiempo, Ibrahim Jubaira, T. D. Agcaoili, Maximo Ramos, D. Paulo Dizon, Carlos Bulosan, Manuel Viray, J. Capiendo Tuvera, Edith Tiempo, Stevan Javellana, Aida Rivera, Kerima Polotan, Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil, F. Sionil Jose, Alejandro Roces, Lina Espina, Juan Gatbonton, Elmer Ordoñez, Andres Cristobal Cruz, Adrian Cristobal, Gregorio Brillantes, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, and Rony V. Diaz.

The anthology retrieves stories from the magazines of the era, arranges them according to dates of publication, and thus enables the reader / critic / literary historian to see them within the historical milieu, as well as within the development and achievement of the Philippine short story in English.

Continuing the work of Yabes, Gemino Abad edited the following anthologies, each two volumes long: Upon Our Own Ground, 2008, covering 1956-72; Underground Spirit, 2010, covering 1973-89; and Hoard of Thunder, 2012, covering the 1990s and the 2000s.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez

The volume has a threefold purpose: “to preserve in a more permanent and handy form the best that have been produced in English by Filipino short story writers; to give a better chance for these writers to be known and appreciated abroad; and to help promote better understanding between the Filipinos and other peoples.” Obviously the compelling motive then was to introduce Filipino writers to the English-reading public abroad.

The anthology is historical and critical, and sometimes, Yabes admits, “it was necessary to include some inferior stories of an earlier year and exclude obviously better stories of a later date, because the former were the best of the crop published in that particular period, and to exclude them would leave a gap in the chronology of the anthology.”

An essay, “Pioneering in the Filipino Short Story in English,” written in 1941, precedes the anthology proper of 1925-40 volume, which starts with Paz Marquez Benitez’s “Dead Stars,” and includes such writers as Casiano T. Calalang, Loreto Paras, Paz Latorena, Jose Garcia Villa, Arturo B. Rotor, Juan Cabreros Laya, Sinai C. Hamada, Amador T. Daguio, Bienvenido N. Santos, Manuel E. Arguilla, Lydia C. Villanueva, N. V. M. Gonzalez, Narciso G. Reyes, Francisco Arcellana, Consorcio Borje, Hernando R. Ocampo, Estrella Alfon, Alfredo E. Litiatco, Conrado V. Pedroche, I. V. Mallari, and at the very end, before the glossary and notes on contributors, Nick Joaquin and Teodoro M. Locsin.

The 164 stories from 1941 to 1955 are divided into two volumes, and a preface explains that the 15-year period “constitutes a most critical era in the history of the nation—war and Japanese occupation, restoration of the Commonwealth government in Manila, proclamation of independence, birth of the republic, euphoria and disenchantment,” and that the stories reflect this. The authors include some already in the first volume, like Nick Joaquin, and more who are not: Edilberto Tiempo, Ibrahim Jubaira, T. D. Agcaoili, Maximo Ramos, D. Paulo Dizon, Carlos Bulosan, Manuel Viray, J. Capiendo Tuvera, Edith Tiempo, Stevan Javellana, Aida Rivera, Kerima Polotan, Carmen Guerrero-Nakpil, F. Sionil Jose, Alejandro Roces, Lina Espina, Juan Gatbonton, Elmer Ordoñez, Andres Cristobal Cruz, Adrian Cristobal, Gregorio Brillantes, Gilda Cordero-Fernando, and Rony V. Diaz.

The anthology retrieves stories from the magazines of the era, arranges them according to dates of publication, and thus enables the reader / critic / literary historian to see them within the historical milieu, as well as within the development and achievement of the Philippine short story in English.

Continuing the work of Yabes, Gemino Abad edited the following anthologies, each two volumes long: Upon Our Own Ground, 2008, covering 1956-72; Underground Spirit, 2010, covering 1973-89; and Hoard of Thunder, 2012, covering the 1990s and the 2000s.  Written by Doreen G. Fernandez
