Published 1989. Compiler, editor, and translator, Pilar E. Mariño. With a preface, an introduction, a glossary, and authors’ biography by the editor. Quezon City: Office of Research Coordination, University of the Philippines.

This is an anthology of 60 short stories in Spanish and their English translation. The writers include Cecilio Apostol, Rafael Palma, Manuel S. Guerrero, Fernando Ma. Guerrero, Jesus Balmori, Sixto Roces, Jose V. Mariño, Buenaventura Rodriguez, Pascual H. Poblete, Francisco Rodriguez, Enrique K. Laygo, Epifanio S. de los Santos, Angeles Lopez de Ayala, Antonio M. Abad, Antonio Luna, Jose Gavira Hernandez, Evangelina L. Guerrero-Zacarias, Serafin G. I. Enriquez, Manuel R. Cabrera, Manuel Bernabe, A. Pica Valdez, Jose Ma. del Rosario, Emmanuel M. D’Exploits, Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero, Estanislao B. Alinea, Wenceslao F. Flores, and Benigno G. del Rio.

Mariño’s introduction divides the stories into the following types: love stories emphasizing moralistic or idealistic attitudes, realistic and humorous stories with local color, criticisms of religious and social foibles, depictions of life in Mindanao, criticisms of society’s double standards of morality, character sketches combined with local color, stories about domestic problems, moralistic tales, criticisms of the American regime, stories of provincial life, stories about social class differences, and stories about the decadence of city life.

Characters run the gamut of Philippine society, and Mariño enumerates them thus: “teachers, artists, bank clerks, office workers, priests, prostitutes, lepers, politicians, barrio officials, fugitives, beggars, sweepstake vendors, fortune hunters, servants, unfaithful husbands or wives, the insane, the downcast, children, and beggars.” Forms that were adapted by the writers for their story materials are the Muslim legend, fairy tale with folkloric elements, beast fable, rafaga or brief story poetically rendered, nature story, frame story, French tale called conte, character sketch, epistolary form, religious satire, and social satire.

This anthology is valuable for bringing together for the first time representative works of Filipino writers in Spanish during that period now called the Golden Age of Philippine Spanish Literature.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: The Philippines Is in the Heart
text:
Published 1978. Author, Carlos Bulosan. With an introduction by Epifanio San Juan Jr. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

This is a collection of short stories from the Bulosan papers in the archives of the University of Washington in Seattle. The stories, all set in the Philippines, exhibit the same generally comic tone and satirical mode as the stories in another anthology, the Laughter of My Father, 1944. As such, San Juan notes in his introduction, they are equally open to the same sort of undervaluation by formalist criticism, which completely misses the political point of Bulosan’s works.

The stories are an interesting combination of what might be called magic realism and folk humor. In “The Angel of Santo Domingo,” folk religiosity is satirized, as it becomes a means by which a poor peasant generates money to pay his debts: an angel poses as an attraction for a fee to a curious crowd. The success of the enterprise causes a dispute among the landlord, the priest, and the mayor, all of whom claim ownership of the angel and, ultimately, of the profit. “My Father’s Angel” is an ironic tale about how an angel, having sold her halo and dress to save a gambler from debt, is mistaken for a prostitute and is rejected by the townsfolk. There are also ghost stories, such as “The Amorous Ghost Came to Town,” “The Return of the Amorous Ghost,” and “Really, A Ghost?”

Other stories are more direct and biting. “Through the oblique modes of irony, allegory, and other symbolic devices,” San Juan notes in his introduction, “Bulosan denounced oppression and exploitation.” The “uncle stories,” for example, condemn the capitalist-colonial situation of the times and its attendant malady: greed. “The Wisdom of Uncle Sator” shows the acumen of the narrator’s uncle when he opens a gambling hall during harvest time, thereby easily gaining for himself what the farmers worked so hard to earn. In “The Way of All Men,” the same uncle bewails that children have begun to gamble. However, it is not their corruption he fears but the possibility of their being better gamblers than he. Even the supposed upholders of virtue are not spared. When the narrator scatters coins in the schoolyard, the teachers race for them, only to be driven away by the principal who wants his part of the money.

The revival of interest in Bulosan among Filipino Americans, as well as other Asian-Americans, in the 1970s owes its impetus to the happy coincidence of San Juan’s interest and work on the papers and the beginnings, at that time, of the Asian-American movement which found in Bulosan a highly articulate spokesperson for a group long relegated to silence.  Written by Susan P. Evangelista

(Selected Short Stories 1939-1992). Published 1992. Author, Genoveva Edroza-Matute. With an introduction by Virgilio S. Almario. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This collection of 31 of Matute’s short stories is representative of her narrative style and theme: a deeply personal reflection, through her various characters, on her own experiences as writer and teacher, as well as poignant commentary on a wide range of human suffering and misfortune in a society beset by social problems. A third of the stories are in the first person point of view. Many of the stories employ the technique for which Matute is well-known: the use of the child as narrator or the depiction of children as central characters.

“Walong Taong Gulang” (Eight Years Old), first published in Mabuhay Extra in 1939, was hailed as the best short story of the year, and was included by Teodoro Agoncillo in his anthology of the best short stories in Tagalog written between 1886 and 1948. A sickly looking schoolchild named Leoncio Santos sets himself apart from his classmates through silent brooding and impenetrable shyness. He is completely missed one day; the child has fallen sick, and her impoverished mother cannot afford medicine or good food for him, because her husband is in prison for having participated in a failed strike years earlier.

Three stories about the war years, all published in 1945, stand out for the bitter irony and dark atmosphere created by the author. “Bughaw Pa sa Likod ng Ulap” (Blue Sky behind the Clouds) shows the brutalization wrought by war. Edro and Iding are brothers who earn a living by salvaging recyclable objects. At the story’s end, Iding dreams that the Americans have landed, their father has returned from his guerrilla camp in the mountains, and he and his older brother are walking toward the school. However, his father, as it turns out, has been captured, tortured, and executed by the Japanese. “Hakbang sa Kalawakan” (A Step into the Void) is about a soldier recollecting his life as he lies dying. In “Si Mento, si Andang, at ang Panahon ng Buy and Sell” (Mento, Andang, and the Age of Buy and Sell), Mento is a minor-league operator who never makes enough and invites an escalating persecution from his wife Andang, who envies the smart and rich operators and wishes her husband were a guerrilla instead so he could collect back pay.

The final story, “Sana” (Wish), 1992, is a simple but moving dramatization of a modern Filipino tragedy. Almost entirely in dialogue form, the story builds up toward a final revelation. Mon has accompanied his friend Bert to Copenhagen to visit Anicia, Bert’s sweetheart and one among the many who work as domestic helpers in a foreign country. They find her displayed in a sex shop showcase with four other naked women. Bert is devastated. Mon comes home, unable to tell the old woman about her daughter.

In 1992, Matute received the Gawad CCP para sa Sining for her writings in Tagalog. She was cited for her achievements in the Tagalog short story, in which she has characteristically shown psychological depth, intuition, and restraint.  Written by Edgardo Maranan

text:
Published 1952. Author, Nick Joaquin. With an introduction by Teodoro M. Locsin. Reprinted, Manila: Alberto S. Florentino, 1963; Makati City: Bookmark Inc, 1991.

This is a collection of short stories, poems, and a novella, The Woman Who Had Two Navels, which was later expanded into a novel. In his short stories, Joaquin conceives of the Filipino as a historical creation, the result of the forced yoking together of conflicting forces. In “The Summer Solstice,” the submerged ancient culture rears its head defiantly in the tadtarin, a ritual celebrating fertility and the female principle, which coincides with the folk Christian devotional feast dedicated to Saint John the Percursor. When not plumbing the primordial caverns of the Filipino spirit, Joaquin dwells nostalgically on the Spanish colonial heritage, cherished and lavishly described in the Intramuros of “The Mass of St. Sylvester” and The Woman Who Had Two Navels.
There are also reflections on the devastation wrought by World War II on culture and the psyche. The sadly diminished characters alternately reject the heritage of the past and flounder about in the present, as they search for a rudder to lead them into the future. Joaquin’s protagonists are forced to confront the reality that they are creatures in which all three forces—the native-animist, the Spanish colonial, and the postwar modern—either coexist or conflict with one another. Both Agueda and Badoy Montiya of “May Day Eve” face the mirror to see into the future and discover the images of their prospective spouses. Each sees the other’s face: demon/witch and lover. Celo Monzon of “Three Generations” seeks to defeat the spirit of his violent father by forcing him into submission. In doing so, he is likewise forced to recognize that the same tendencies exist in him. The past continues to confront the protagonist both from without and within. Until these conflicting, confounding forces are resolved, the strains are unsuccessfully interwoven and harmonized, the portrait of the Filipino, Joaquin suggests, will emerge only as a blur.

In his poetry, Joaquin is a blend of cultures and traditions: Bible, Greek mythology, Mother Goose, Lorca, and Jose Rizal. The poems have different voices, styles, resonances. “The Innocence of Solomon” is psalm-like, intoned with purposely imperfect rhyming: “But wisdom never was content / and flesh when ripened falls at last: / what will I have when the seasons mint / your golden breasts into golden dust?”

The poem “Six P.M.” has a refreshing contemporary sound, memorable for its ironic wit and parallel images. It is about a workaday employee, incidentally a poet too, whose life is thus alternately cramped and cosmic: “Trouvere at night, grammarian in the morning, / ruefully architecting syllables.” The poet/employee takes his place “in the bus among people returning / to love (domesticated) and the smell of onions burning.”
His meditations end with a definitive acceptance of his lot: “conquistador tonight, clock-puncher tomorrow.” The best-known poems of Joaquin in this collection are “Verde Yo Te Quiero Verde” (Green I Love You Green), a title inspired by Federico Garcia Lorca, and “Valedictory Address,” Joaquin’s translation of Rizal’s “Mi Ultimo Adios” (My Last Farewell). The former is structured rather in the avant-gardist style, with its truncated lines, single-word lines, double and triple colons, unusual compounds, and startling images. The preference and love for green is expressed at various planes of feeling: the pristine quality of the natural world, associations with peace and tranquility, and the quality of being alone, primordial, and virgin.  Written by Edgardo Maranan and Elena Rivera Mirano

article_title: Pula ang Kulay ng Dugo at Iba Pang Kuwento
text:
(The Color of Blood is Red and Other Stories). Published 1997. Author, Brigido C. Batungbakal. With an introduction and interview by Rolando B. Tolentino and a literary biography by Lilia Antonio. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

This collection of 17 short stories, written between 1938 and 1946, in the vein of social realism, probes into the socioeconomic relationships of people in the countryside. The stories in the first section explore popular themes: love and filial piety in “Ingkong Berto” (Grandfather Berto), the kindness of an innocent, prayerful young girl to an escaped convict in “Ama Namin” (Our Father), a young boy’s discerning look at love and its different manifestations in “Laki sa Nuno” (Raised by Grandfather), the limits of a woman’s sufferings and sexual desire in “Nasa Binhi” (In the Seed), and a rich man’s betrayal and its dire consequence in “Ang Dios Ama” (God the Father).

The stories in the second section shatter the stereotypical impression of barrio folk as peaceful and passive in the face of injustice and exploitation. In “Pula ang Kulay ng Gabi” (The Color of Night Is Red), Diego leads the dissident movement to prevent the further destruction of his town at the hands of crooked politicians and tyrannical landlords. “Balo Marta” (The Widow Marta) is about the struggle of a hardy farmer’s wife to understand the causes of her barrio’s plight, and shows how a national figure like Manuel Quezon fares against the established power base in the nation’s poverty-stricken areas. “Karimlan sa Bukang Liwayway” (Darkness at Daybreak) is a narrative of love set against the tenancy problem, which leads to a killing and the central character’s imprisonment. “Aklasan” (Strike) indicts capitalism as an evil system destroying the lives of factory workers and their families.

Making up the final section are seven stories, including “Gabi sa Nayon” (Night in the Countryside), which is about death in the barrio; and “Kaylamig ng Amihan” (How Cool is the North Wind), about love’s waywardness leading to despair.

Batungbakal’s stories are never sentimental even when they detail the woes of romantic love. They are always critical of the material conditions that cause the characters’ suffering, and seldom resort to pat resolutions when it is injustice in the social system that triggers the plot. Rather, they evoke emotions even as they pose challenging questions by means of allusive, oblique but interconnected impressions and images.

“Pula ang Kulay ng Dugo” won honorable mention at the state-sponsored Commonwealth Literary Contests in 1940.  Written by Soledad Reyes

text:
Published 2003. Author, Tara FT Sering. With an afterword by Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This collection of five short stories and one novella showcases the best qualities of the author’s works: a minimalist style; varying tones, which is the author’s main strength; and her main characters’ shifting moods from one sentence to the next.

The first short story, “Preview,” is about a newly wedded woman who has a very uncomfortable time with her in-laws at lunch. She sees the family members quarrel over who gets the eyes of the fish they are feasting on. The narrator’s mood begins with annoyance, then progresses to discomfort, until it ultimately leads to horror. The very subtle shifts in tone are effected by the author’s precise choice of words.

The title story, “Reconnaissance,” is about a young girl’s rite of passage as she witnesses her neighbors drop their proper demeanor and reveal their real natures during a war game. A flash-forward shows the young girl as an adult, and she is now confronted with her future wrecked marriage. Once more, the tone shifts are very subtle; they move from fear, to curiosity, to fascination, to possible enlightenment—all within a single page.

The author’s skill at handling tone shifts is evident in the other stories. In “Wonder,” a young woman is initiated into the corporate world. In less than a thousand words, this story captures the politics, the backstabbing, and the circus within the staid walls of a corporate building. “The Vacation” highlights the pathetic ways by which an elderly couple attempts to impress their guests by recounting their trip to France and England. In this story, the narrative voice shifts from one character to the next and thus overpowers the elderly couple’s desire to make their guests envy them. In “The Last Chip Off the Walled City,” a young woman, who has romantic notions of family, is at a loss over the imminent breakup of hers.

The novella Getting Better is in the mode of a self-help manual; thus, it is in the unusual second-person point of view. A young woman’s relationship is crumbling and she must find a way to overcome her broken heart. The author’s command of tone is evident as her main character goes through a wide range of emotions, sometimes within the same paragraph. The narrative voice is vulnerable yet tough, funny, and sad all at the same time. She neither moralizes nor rants. The main character comes off as very likeable despite her mistakes. The novella shows that as people, we are subject to hurt, and that the people we trust the most may end up betraying us. We are allowed to grieve the end of important phases in our lives, but we always move on.

“The Vacation” won second prize in the short story contest of the Philippine Graphic magazine in 1999.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

This collection of five short stories and one novella showcases the best qualities of the author’s works: a minimalist style; varying tones, which is the author’s main strength; and her main characters’ shifting moods from one sentence to the next.

The first short story, “Preview,” is about a newly wedded woman who has a very uncomfortable time with her in-laws at lunch. She sees the family members quarrel over who gets the eyes of the fish they are feasting on. The narrator’s mood begins with annoyance, then progresses to discomfort, until it ultimately leads to horror. The very subtle shifts in tone are effected by the author’s precise choice of words.

The title story, “Reconnaissance,” is about a young girl’s rite of passage as she witnesses her neighbors drop their proper demeanor and reveal their real natures during a war game. text:
(Outside the Parlor). Published 1998. Author, Honorio Bartolome de Dios. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Written between 1986 and 1997, Sa Labas ng Parlor is Honorio Bartolome de Dios’s first collection of stories. As the title suggests, these stories deal with the experience of homosexuals beyond stereotypes of the beauty parlor gay. Ranging from the personal to the political, each story in the collection tackles the different aspects of homosexuality and the roles that homosexuals play in society.

“Atseng” (a nickname given to effeminate gay men) depicts the sexual awakening of boys and the desire and struggles between gays and straight men in the barrio. “Nobena” (Novena) portrays the relationship of a father with his gay son. “Eulohiya” (Eulogy) depicts a gay man coming to terms with the death of a former love and the beginning of a new relationship. “Geyluv” tells the development of a romantic relationship between a heterosexual and gay man. “Lalaki” (Man) explores the financial, psychological, and sexual exploitation of a gay man by his lover.

These personal relationships become the launching pad for political participation in a society that has yet to accept a plurality of genders and sexualities. “Kas” compares the different paths two friends, a rebel and a homosexual, have taken and asserts that the struggles in their respective fronts are necessary in the reshaping of collective perceptions. “Sumpa ng Tag-araw” (Curse of Summer) exposes the prejudice against homosexuals by the people of a barrio threatened by land development. And in “Giyera” (War), the exploitation by corporations and corrupt government officials is met by gay activists who offer their voice to shape and sustain the struggle of marginalized communities against environmental exploitation. In these stories, de Dios disengages gay culture from the sexual act and instead attaches it to a set of behaviors, values, and ideas that force society to rethink how traditional and heteronormative lifestyles have made different groups in society susceptible to oppression and environmental degradation.

The collection does not just test the boundaries of storytelling in the Philippines by intertwining the theme of homosexuality with the political but also pushes the genre by experimenting with form. De Dios uses stream of consciousness to allow the reader to imagine homosexuality outside of the moral and religious concerns affecting its understanding in Philippine society. He uses dialogue and alternating points of view to depict the contrasting ideas dividing straight men from gay men. Mythic elements are also used in a style reminiscent of Latin American magical realism.  Written by Christopher Mitch Cerda

text:
(A Hundred Dresses: 16 Short Stories). Published 2007. Author, Fanny A. Garcia. With an introduction by the author. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press. Fourteen out of the 16 stories in this collection were previously published as Sandaang Damit at Iba Pang Maikling Kuwento (A Hundred Dresses and Other Short Stories), Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 1994.

The stories in the collection were written between 1971 and 1990 and bear the burden of the conflicts prevailing during martial law and its aftermath. Included are two stories that were not in Garcia’s earlier collection: “Tulay sa Langit” (Bridge to Heaven) and “Bathala” (God). Garcia explains that these were excluded because they were not so explicitly political as the other stories.

Both stories, however, charted a new direction in fiction writing in Tagalog. They were experiments in various narrative devices and were studies of the characters’ complex psyche. They foreground the plight of female characters, constructed not as types, as traditional stories tended to do, but as three-dimensional characters.

In “Tulay sa Langit,” Garcia’s first published story, an illegitimate daughter of a woman is derided as a prostitute by the neighbors in the slums. She begs her father to take her in after her mother dies and is treated like a slave in the father’s house. She falls for a handsome seminarian, who is eventually ordained. With her mother dead and her seminarian gone, the embittered Mira leaves her father’s house to try her luck in the city. She finds a job as a waitress but the proprietor makes her a mistress. He maltreats her and leaves her to starve in the toilet. As she gradually loses her sanity, specters from her past haunt her, ending with her mother waiting for her.

“Bathala” is a study of the ever-changing and complex relationship between Clarissa, a stiff and straitlaced nun, and her father and her sister, Magda, a woman whose views on sex, love, and marriage revolt her. The author constructs a narrative of fierce sibling rivalry, the Electra complex, a mother’s betrayal, a father’s instransigent and unforgiving nature, incest, and antagonism against the institutional Church. In the end, the dying Clarissa admits that the sorrows of her life, precipitated by bad decisions, directly spring from the forbidden love for the father.

The rest of the stories in this anthology are variations on themes of poverty and exploitation, and the characters’ inability to rise from misery and want. “Sandaang Damit” (A Hundred Dresses) begins with a girl who brags of having expensive clothes for every occasion. It turns out that she is desperately clinging to this illusion in order to hide her impoverished life. The story proceeds to events in the life of a young student and her sweetheart and his unconditional commitment to a cause that the woman fails to understand.

The short story “Puti” (White) centers on Lenka, a recurrent character in the author’s fictional world. Lenka is given a dog that the family calls Puti, and she finds some joy in its company. But her father is forced to sell it, and Lenka falls ill. After seeing how distraught Lenka is, the father tries to get the dog back from its new owner, but he must return 40 pesos to the current owner.

The academe as an ivory tower is critiqued in “Alay sa Isang Kuwago” (Offering to an Owl), the evils of tenancy are explored in “Pantabangan” and “Pagbabalik” (Return), and the plight of the overseas Filipino workers is examined in “Arrividerci.” An award-winning story, “Pina, Pina, Saan Ka Pupunta?” (Pina, Pina, Where Are You Going?) allegorizes the unequal relationship between the United States and the Philippines.

The stories in this collection are examples of naturalistic fiction, with characters that are overpowered by their social conditions and other external forces. They present a grim vision of life. However, the author Garcia does suggest that there is need for urgent and radical change.  Written by Soledad Reyes

article_title: Selebrasyon at Lamentasyon: Antolohiya ng Mga Maikling Kwento sa Panay
text:
(Celebration and Lamentation: An Anthology of Short Stories of Panay). Published 1998. Editors and translators, Carmen L. de los Santos, Ma. Milagros Geremia-Lachica, and John E. Barrios. Quezon City: Sentro ng Wikang Filipino, Unibersidad ng Pilipinas.

The book consists of 16 short stories in Aklanon, Karay-a, and Hiligaynon, with Filipino translations.

Feudal bondage and the uneven pace of progress in the countryside are pervasive themes in the Hiligaynon stories. Quin Baterna’s “Ginbaid ang Binangon” (Sharpened Bolo) dramatizes the land tillers’ age-old desperation when the protagonist tries to scale a mythical mountain that promises “power, wealth, and joy” to those who succeed in getting past its malevolent spirit-guardians. Alice Tan-Gonzales’s “Binhi” (Seed) depicts the plight of a peasant family and the mother’s dangerous dalliance with a shady character to save her youngest child’s life.

The bridge as a metaphor for development is used in two other Hiligaynon stories. In Carlo Dalisay’s “Taytay sang Paglaom” (The Bridge of Hope), a series of freak accidents in an engineer’s construction project and scenes of street children in downtown Iloilo trigger an early memory of rumors of children being kidnapped for their blood to strengthen the foundations of the San Juanico Bridge. In Mario Villaret’s “Ang Naghabyog nga Tulay” (The Dancing Bridge), a little girl falls off a makeshift bridge and drowns during a raging storm while her father is preoccupied with his own political ambitions.

Tan-Gonzales moves back to the remote past in “Daba-daba sa Sidlangan” (Fire in the East), an elegant paean to a peaceful tribe that is vanquished by Spanish forces. With one final act, the widow of the tribe’s fallen leader eludes a life of slavery and indignity. In “Sa Punta sang Balangaw” (At the End of the Rainbow), a teenage girl escapes her father, finds work in Bacolod, but is caught in another abusive relationship with her male employer.

How history impinges on the present is the subject of two other stories. The protagonist in R. C. Garganera’s “Batungdaan” (Stone Marker) struggles to dismantle a stone structure amid rumors of his father’s collaboration with the Japanese during World War II. In Ner Jedeliz’s “Landong sa Dulom” (Shadows in the Dark), a woman turns to her grandmother for comfort when she is shunned by her neighbors for working as an “entertainer” in Japan.

The Karay-a stories center on gender and sexuality. The death of the title character in Alex de los Santos’s “Ang Sastre” (The Tailor) prompts the return of his estranged gay son, whose dressmaking skills have afforded him a life of freedom in the city. Sex tourism at a popular beach in Antique is the subject of Lea Marlie Lourdes Pagunsan-Tambanillo’s “Babaye: Ginabaligya” (Woman: For Sale), which is told in the young, colloquial voice of a student being propositioned by an American. Finally, Ma. Milagros Geremia-Lachica’s “Sa Pagtubu kang Tahud” (When the Spur Grows) is about the sexual awakening of a 13-year-old boy who turns his attentions on an unsuspecting hen when he feels rejected by the woman he likes.

Young people being jolted into questioning long-held notions of the world are the focus of the Aklanon stories. In John E. Barrios’s “Bisikleta” (Bicycle), a boy resolves his religious doubts when he chooses the ordinary activity of human life and nature over what he perceives is an indifferent God. In Julian Talisman’s “Last Trip,” a bus driver’s strict work ethic puts him on forced retirement, and he directs his resentment at an innocent passenger, a student.

Alexander de Juan’s “Nana, Nobya ni Edipos” (Nana, Girlfriend of Edipos) also follows a student on a bus, whose thoughts about his “friend” Edipos are interrupted by a passenger suddenly giving birth. A crime-infested Jaro is the backdrop of Melchor Cichon’s “Silabu” (Outburst), in which tension arises between a mother and daughter while the father works in Saudi Arabia. Disturbed by the prayer rally at the nearby plaza, the governor’s son in Joeffrey Ricafuente’s “Konsiyerto sa Plasa” (Concert at the Plaza) hacks the preacher to death and, at the precinct, explains his reasons to a former teacher.

The relationship between tradition and modernity is the predominant theme in these stories, dramatized through topics like religion, sexuality, indigenous culture, and transnational employment. The range of subject matter is matched by the variety of fictional modes: intricate storytelling, hagiography, austere naturalism, social realism, and the strange and experimental. All these attest to these Western Visayan writers’ able handling of the protean nature of the genre.  Written by Glenn Diaz

text:
Published 1962. Author, Francisco Arcellana. With a critique by Leonard Casper. Manila: Alberto S. Florentino.

This small volume is a collection of four short stories that have been previously published in Philippine Magazine, Sunday Times Magazine, Philippines Free Press, and This Week. The four stories are “The Mats”; “The Flowers of May,” which won a Palanca award in 1951; “The Yellow Shawl,” which placed second at the short story contest of the Philippines Free Press for 1953 under the title “Wing of Madness”; and “Divide by Two.”

“The Mats” focuses on Mr Angeles’s homecoming from the south, bringing brightly colored mats for every member of the household. That there are also mats for those family members who have died brings about the realization that the story is really about the difficulty of resigning oneself to the death of loved ones. Like the first story, “The Flowers of May” depicts the shock that comes upon a grieving family when they finally come to accept a beloved member’s death two months after her funeral.

“The Yellow Shawl” is divided into three sections subtitled “The Man’s Story,” 1953, told from the man’s first-person point of view; “The Girl’s Story,” told from the woman’s first-person point of view; and “The Yellow Shawl,” 1944, with a child as the central consciousness. The first two sections focus on the anxiety felt by the man and woman as they deal with the uncertainties of love in its initial stage. These serve to emphasize the tragedy narrated in the third section, which is set in the Japanese occupation. The child watches her father pacing in her room as they both listen to her mother screaming repeatedly in another room. The yellow shawl is the image that threads through the whole story.

“Divide by Two” is the subject of Casper’s critical analysis, titled “Vision Indivisible,” at the end of the book. The main narrative device of the story is dialogue. As the two characters, the narrator and his wife Belle, focus their attention on their neighbors, whom Belle resents, the reader begins to realize that the real focus of the story is the deterioration of the couple’s relationship, especially their inability to communicate.

Arcellana has been lauded for having perfected the “underwritten story,” using devices that are more characteristic of lyric poetry than of fiction. Thus, the emotive power of his short stories derives from imagery, symbol, and repetition.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Si Tatang at Mga Himala ng Ating Panahon
text:
(Tatang and the Miracles of Our Time). Published 1988. Author, Ricardo Lee. Quezon City: Bagong Likha Productions Inc.

This collection brings together some of the best writings of Lee in several genres: screenplay, short story, essay, feature article, and interview. Lee created a sensation in the late 1960s with short stories written in a style unfamiliar to Filipino readers—long, uninterrupted, paragraphic sentences, and a deft manipulation of time, sometimes interweaving flashbacks and flash-forwards, thus creating a complex but tight narrative in a stream-of-consciousness fashion.

The “Tatang” in the book’s title comes from his story “Si Tatang, si Freddie, si Tandang Senyong at Iba Pang mga Tauhan ng Aking Kuwento” (Tatang, Freddie, Old Man Senyong and Other Characters in My Story), 1971, which is about “Tatang” Valentin delos Santos, real-life leader of the millenarian-peasant cult Lapiang Malaya, whose members were massacred by the Philippine Constabulary in 1967. The story involves an inner story of a young writer’s initiation into social reality as a result of the incident. As he lies dying, his life flashes before him like an agitated procession of souls and failed dreams and he resolves to live on, because “the world has yet to listen to his words.”

text:
(Storm). Published 1972. Editors, Mila Carreon, Lily Chua, Ricardo Lee, Jesus F. Ramos, and Romulo Sandoval. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

This is a collection of short stories written by young as well as veteran writers who were involved in the political protest movement of the 1970s. They include Wilfredo Virtusio, Epifanio San Juan Jr, Efren Abueg, Domingo Landicho, Ricardo Lee, Edgar Maranan, Jose Rey Munsayac, Fanny Garcia, and Norma Miraflor. The title was derived from Unang Rebolusyonaryong Sigwa, or First Quarter Storm, referring to the events in the first months of 1970 which saw the birth of the radical student movement and cultural activism among writers, artists, and teachers. The stories in this anthology depict a world of violence and injustice in what was then perceived as a neocolonial Philippine society. They were written in a manner that showed understanding of modern narrative technique in fiction, while at the same time dealing with issues that have been addressed by past generations of socially conscious writers.

Sigwa chronicles the changes in the writers’ perception and understanding of the relationship between literature and society. The authors were a varied lot. Abueg was one of the writers in Mga Agos sa Disyerto, 1965, a landmark in Philippine social realist fiction writing. San Juan had achieved some reputation as a poet, polemicist, and literary critic. Miraflor had made an effortless shift from English to Pilipino.
Domingo Landicho was an experienced writer of nationalist poetry and passionate prose. The rest were young writers who were starting out as fictionists. The stories in Sigwa exhibit various levels of the writers’ awareness of the linkages between the characters and the forces they contend with. A common theme strings the stories together: awakening and initiation. Characters who start out as uncommitted, concerned only with their private world, eventually become actively involved in the difficult task of exposing and opposing the evils of an unjust system. This is evident in Virtusio’s “Maria, ang Iyong Anak” (Maria, Your Child), Garcia’s “Sandaang Damit” (Hundred Shirts), Miraflor’s “Sulat mula sa Pritil” (Letter from Pritil), Maranan’s “Ipis sa Guhong Templo” (Cockroach in the Demolished Temple), Landicho’s “Elias at Salome” (Elias and Salome), Munsayac’s “Isang Araw sa Buhay ni Juan Lazaro” (A Day in the Life of Juan Lazaro), San Juan’s “Anay” (Termite), and Lee’s “Si Tatang, si Freddie, si Tandang Senyong, at Iba Pang Tauhan ng Aking Kuwento” (Tatang, Freddie, Old Man Senyong, and Other Characters in My Story).

The stories signaled the entry into contemporary literature of a generation of writers deeply committed to the view that literature can indeed be a medium of struggle. In retrospect, Sigwa may be seen as having been a powerful response to the crisis-ridden condition of Philippine society, just as a decade earlier, the Agos anthology of stories appeared in order to end a perceived drought in Philippine creative and critical writing.  Written by Soledad Reyes and Edgardo Maranan

article_title: Ang Silid na Mahiwaga: Kalipunan ng Mga Kuwento't Tula ng Mga Babaeng Manunulat
text:
(The Enchanted Room: An Anthology of Stories and Poems by Women Writers). Published 1994. Editor, Soledad S. Reyes. With an introduction by the editor. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc, 1994, 2003.

The anthology is composed of 106 poems and 51 short stories arranged chronologically, starting from 1897 with the poem “Kasaysayan ng Isang Pag-ibig” (History of One Love) by Gregoria de Jesus and ending in 1994 with the short story “Nasaan si David?” (Where Is David?) by Liwayway Arceo. The bookends establish a woman’s place—home and country—and her roles—mother, spouse, daughter, and revolutionary. Jovita N. Martinez’s story “Ang Silid na Mahiwaga” (The Enchanted Room) is the inspiration for the title of the anthology; a room could be a woman’s prison or her salvation. Martinez weaves an eerie tale of a resurrected woman who finds the courage to face her spouse and her fears of rejection.

There are 41 poems and 35 works of fiction selected from the American period until the 1970s. From the 1920s, poems by Vicenta C. Navarro, Simeona Decena, Virginia Ignacio, and Filomena T. Alcanar speak of love, sorrow, infidelity, and sacrifice. The 1930s include two short stories: Rosalia L. Aguinaldo creates a woman ahead of her time in “Ay, Ay!,” and Carmen S. Herrera skillfully applies the epistolary method in “Balatkayo” (Pretense).

Liwayway A. Arceo’s “Uhaw ang Tigang na Lupa” (Thirsty Is the Arid Land), 1944, reveals the tensions between a married couple from their young daughter’s point of view. Genoveva D. Edroza develops an empathetic character in a model teacher who bears a secret in “Kuwento ni Mabuti” (Story of Mabuti), 1952. These last two stories are a departure from the traditional story, which often had a contrived happy ending.

The 1960s are represented by Susana C. de Guzman’s “Ang Liham” (The Letter), about the growing solitariness of a woman in old age; Mercedes J. Jose’s “3 Sugat sa Kanyang Dibdib” (3 Wounds on Her Breast) and “Bukas ang Ikalawang Langit” (The Second Heaven Is Open), both probing the mother-child relationship; Rosario de Guzman-Lingat’s “Isang Patunguhan” (One Destination), where a woman chooses between taking care of an aging parent and a long-planned marriage; Lualhati Bautista’s “Ako, Hindi ang Pag-ibig Ko” (I, Not My Love), which asks how a woman can affect a man’s mental and psychological growth; and Carmen H. Acosta’s “Kandidata” (Candidate), where a young woman’s idealism is challenged by the reality of political corruption.

The poems from the same period express themes that are just as varied: a mother longing for her child who has left her in Filonila G. Abordo’s “Sa Iyo, Aking Anak” (To You, My Child); the importance of proper conduct during courtship in Zenaida Arcega Flores’s “Papanhikin ang Pagsuyo” (Let Courtship into the House); the torment of scorned love in Natalia A. Baltazar’s “Sa Paglulunggati” (In Desiring); and nostalgia for a bygone era in Nieves Baens-del Rosario’s “Nasaan ang Kahapon” (Where Is Yesterday).

The stories from the 1970s onward show the writers’ increasing confidence and skill. Fanny A. Garcia’s “Alamat ng Sapang Bato” (Legend of Sapang Bato) contains the beginnings of metafiction. The thin line between individual and social madness is explored in Bautista’s “Buwan, Buwan, Hulugan Mo Ako ng Sundang” (Moon, Moon, Drop Me a Dagger) and Amor M. Datinguinoo’s “Tulad ng Dati, sa Underpass” (As Usual, at the Underpass). Creatures of folklore enrich Rosario Cruz-Lucero’s coming-of-age story “Demonyo” (Devil). Francine Y. Medina’s “Dalaw” (Visit) brings to light a social taboo, abortion.

The poems in the collection, clustering in the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, show a growing sophistication and maturity in style, technique, and tone. There are Ruth Elynia Mabanglo’s powerful poems: “Regla” (Menstruation), “Puta” (Whore), “Kung Ibig Mo Akong Makilala” (If You Want to Know Me), and “Gahasa” (Rape). Aida F. Santos celebrates a woman’s time for herself in “Pag-iisa” (Solitude). Joi Barrios expresses the same theme more defiantly in “Babae Akong Namumuhay Nang Mag-isa” (I Am a Woman Who Lives Alone), which rejects the labels that oppress women. Benilda S. Santos recounts a woman’s singular identity in “Pagkatapos ng Almusal” (After Breakfast). In Marra PL. Lanot’s “Maihahambing Kita” (I Can Compare You), Lilia Quindoza-Santiago’s “Kaisampalad” (The Destined One), and Lualhati Bautista’s “Dyugdyugan” (Having Sex), women choose to love, not docilely, but with eyes wide open.

The anthology is a significant step in the revaluation of women’s writings in Tagalog and Filipino, although the first two decades of the 20th century are underrepresented. The thumbnail biographical notes on the authors at the end of the book and the absence of such notes on Emma Maria Cristina, Ma. Gloria Esguerra, Virginia Ignacio, Noemi A. Medina, Vicenta C. Navarro, Cleotilde Reyes, and Adela Vera underscore the need to respond to the editor’s call to do more research on women writers. The companion anthology is Songs of Ourselves, 1994, edited by Edna Z. Manlapaz, consisting of writings in English by women.  Written by Rebecca T. Añonuevo

article_title: The Song from the Mango Tree
text:
Published 2004. Author, Ampatuan Ampalid and Hazel J. Wrigglesworth. With a foreword by Miguel A. Bernad, SJ. Manila: Linguistics Society of the Philippines.

The book is a bilingual collection of five relatively long folktales told by Ilianen Manobo storyteller Ampatuan Ampalid to Hazel Wrigglesworth, who provides not only the English translation but also abundant annotations on the translation, rhetorical devices, and cultural context. The five stories are two Pilanduk (or trickster) tales, an animal tale, a courtship-by-trial tale, and a novelistic tale of the child-as-dragon slayer. Each of these tales consists of a series of episodes cleverly linked together by structural devices that make the episodes integral to one another.

“Pilanduk and the Crocodile Chief” is the tale to which the book title alludes. Pilanduk decides to abduct the chief’s wife by pretending to be a bird singing on a mango tree. To do so, he resorts to a series of deceptions, first, on the crocodile chief, and then on the chief, his wife, and their underling. Smaller members of the animal kingdom become embroiled in the ensuing contest of wits between Pilandok and the betrayed crocodile chief. In the second tale, “Pilanduk and the Giant,” the mischievous trickster saves the world from a devouring giant that is fast depleting the world’s population.

The third tale, “Lizard and Deer,” is known to have been used by Manobo chieftains to guide them in the settling of real-life cases in which the original blame is traced back to the complainants themselves. Lizard’s attempt to hunt for food triggers a chain of startled reactions that end with her own baby lizards suffering the consequences. The grieving Lizard takes her case to the chieftain’s court, and the chieftain traces the original culprit back to herself. Similarly, “Butterfly and Flower” has a plot complication that provides a real-life illustration of the methods employed by Manobo chieftains to settle grievances brought before them. However, it is a charming courtship tale in itself, replete with imagery designed not only to awaken one’s sense impressions but also to evoke romantic sentiments.

The fifth and last tale, “The Child Who Was Abandoned by His Parents,” would be called a novelistic tale due to its length and episodic structure. The child engages in a series of adventures involving magic objects, a grateful lion, a ferocious dragon, and a kickball contest for the hand of the chieftain’s daughter.

Although “Pilanduk and the Crocodile Chief” and “Lizard and Deer” were previously published in Wrigglesworth’s An Anthology of Ilianen Manobo Folktales, 1981, with the titles “Pilanduk” and “Lizard,” one might say that these reprints are a different set of texts entirely, because Wrigglesworth’s meticulous annotations and the insertion of the audience’s enthusiastic comments call attention to the oral nature of these tales. Thus, the book’s title reminds us that these tales are not to be read solely like lyrics on a music sheet but are to be heard and seen being performed, or at least imagined by the reader to be so.  Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero

article_title: Songs of Ourselves: Writings by Filipino Women in English
text:
Published 1994. Editor, Edna Zapanta Manlapaz. With an introduction by Edna Zapanta Manlapaz. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

This anthology of 127 stories by 53 writers from three generations spans seven decades, beginning with Paz Latorena’s “The Small Key,” 1927, and closing with Ophelia A. Dimalanta’s “This One Legacy,” 1993. In between are works by both major and minor voices.

Manlapaz’s introduction gives a profile of women writers in English in the Philippines: they are generally of the intellectual and social elite, highly educated, gainfully employed, professionally trained, and well-traveled. The middle-class background informs and delimits their writings, but the politicization of women writers in the 1960s and 1970s and their increased self-awareness as women writers, a high point of which was the publication of The Forbidden Fruit, 1992, have led to an expansion of the world of their works.

The stories and poems portray women playing various roles in various situations, and ruminating about their experiences, such as love, whether initial (Lourdes Vidal’s “Virgin”), incipient (Toribia Mano’s “Tambourines in My Heart”), terminated (Merlie Alunan’s “We Kept a Jarful of Keys”), or consummated (Marjorie Evasco’s “Elemental”); the delights and dilemmas of parenthood and parenting (Lily Lopez-Chua’s “Poem for a Child about to Grow” and Jessica Zafra’s “Portents”); the relations between women, whether erotic (Rebecca Crisostomo’s “Tender Rituals”), sisterly (Lina Espina-Moore’s “Sam-It and the Loom”), or antagonistic (Paz Latorena’s “The Small Key”); the attempt at self-definition according to one’s own terms (Trinidad Tarrosa-Subido’s “I, Your Wife” and Myrna Peña-Reyes’s “Ruth Was Not Penelope”); and the acknowledgment of one’s cultural heritage (Ma. Luisa B. Aguilar-Cariño’s “Woman from the North”).

The styles and modes are as varied as the subjects. Aida Rivera-Ford’s “The Chieftest Mourner” is satirical in its depiction of the hypocrisies of high society. Realism is the dominant mode in the collection, but Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo uses elements of fantasy in “The Ghost of La Casa Grande.” Jessica Hagedorn’s “Pearl” is a modernist fable, with only virgules for punctuation marks. In the tradition of the fable, it has a moral, which, in the spirit of modernism, requires an ironic reading. The poems range from the fixed forms of Angela Manalang-Gloria to the dizzying enjambments of Dimalanta’s free verse, and, in tone, from the coolly philosophical (Edith Tiempo’s “Bonsai”), to the enthused (Frances Anna Bennett-Icard’s “Saturday Night”), to the elegiac (Lydia Arguilla Salas’s “Invitation”).

Although many of the stories and poems appear to depict “private” experiences, they advert to realities of Philippine life that make these experiences comprehensible: the job discrimination that forces Lucia to contemplate an abortion in Ligaya Victorio-Reyes’s “Maternity Leave”; the clashes between the military and the activists during the Marcos administration and the consequent loss of lives mourned in Grace Monte de Ramos’s “Brave Woman”; or the poverty in the homeland, the thought of which the expatriate persona of Fatima Lim’s “Confessions of a Green Card Bearer” represses as she buys apples and wine.

The pieces are chronologically arranged, allowing readers to hear, as it were, reprises and counterpoints, and reassess iterations of the same tune. Thus, Nita Umali-Berthelsen’s “The Money Makers,” 1949, echoes in Ninotchka Rosca’s “Generations,” 1983. Both are set against the backdrop of an oppressive social system. The first is told from a child’s point of view, a technique that results in ironic distance without blunting the story’s point (who is the real “money maker”?). The second, which is from the point of view of Old Selo’s family, is unflinching in depicting the cruelties that feudalism generates—whether between the classes or within the family. The three decades that separate the two stories serve to remind readers of how persistent the problems are.

Songs of Ourselves demonstrates that, contrary to the notion that women’s worlds are confined to the domestic, women writers have asked significant questions and have given answers as significant, in a manner as polished and as memorable, as their male counterparts’. The companion anthology is Ang Silid na Mahiwaga (The Enchanted Room), 1994, edited by Soledad S. Reyes, consisting of writings in Tagalog by women.  Written by Jonathan Chua

text:
Published 1999. Author, Jose V. Ayala. With an introduction by Francisco Arcellana. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

A common theme of transformation runs through the 17 stories here by Jose V. Ayala. The collection unravels the inner lives of characters with a style that mirrors the fragmentation of the psyche.

The first and last pieces bookend the stories within the concept of (re)birth. “And the Dancer, Dancing” depicts a hunted man who emerges out of his hiding place, “prodded out of the womb of safety,” and into imprisonment by the “Enemy” in some unspecified war. In “Green Rice,” the farmer Cardo investigates his mother’s claims that his wife, Lupe, is carrying somebody else’s child. Cardo is indifferent to her delicate condition even as her term draws nearer. But when Lupe goes into long and painful labor, Cardo is remorseful and asks for her forgiveness.

Some stories, ranging in style from the interior monologue to stream of consciousness, reflect modern themes of alienation and isolation. In “The Astronomer,” an inventory clerk discovers a new vocation when he chances upon “the full Harvest Moon of the Autumnal Equinox.” The tug of lunar gravity at his heart sets him to speculating on spatial dimensions relative to what the mind perceives. As he traces the relationship of celestial bodies with his own physical state, he undergoes an expansion of the self.

“Night Is a City” echoes T. S. Eliot, beginning with the line, “November is the saddest month.” As the narrator wanders the streets at night, he gives stark descriptions of nonspecific places, which mirror his troubled state of mind. In “The Alien,” Manuel Constancio, a retired teacher, returns to his hometown only to find that he has become an “alien” there and is treated like a regular tourist. In “Down the Days and All the Nights” the protagonist struggles to fall in love with life again despite the suicide of his friend and his bouts with the humdrum tedium of a Monday workday. The story has an impenetrable first-person narrator, whose erratic, disjointed shifts of ideas are in the stream-of-consciousness style, thus creating a surreal effect. The narrator flits from one scene to the next, with occasional direct confrontations with characters (thus addressing them and the reader as “you”), whose relationship with him remains amorphous. “Bestiary,” written in the same surreal style, is historical fiction with allegorical characters representing the Philippines, Spanish colonialism, and American neocolonialism.

Other stories in the collection are more plot-driven: the characters, left to fumble in their circumstance, are led to outcomes they might not expect. In “Hard Earth,” Gil Flores, trying to prove his worth to villagers by digging a well, learns that his scientific ways may not be enough against the hard, impenetrable earth. An office manager in “The Board Meeting” stands up to his superiors for his co-workers’ sake. But when his boss reminds him of the possible consequence of his defiance, his resolve weakens. In “Man in a Crate,” a crane operator strives to mend his life after earning enough by illicit means. On the day that a new system of monitoring illicit activities is set in place at work, he comes home to find his wife and his savings gone. Poverty forces a nameless beggar in “The Other Half of the World” to sneak into the barges at night to scrounge around for grains of rice for his wife and children. With the narrator’s tone of foreboding and the wife’s dream of finding him dead, the story inexorably leads toward the fatal consequences of his attempts to preserve his family’s life.

The other stories in this collection are: “Salt and Rice,” “The Innocent,” “The Walled City,” “The Sound of Reflections,” “So Still, So Bright,” and “In the Garden of Children.” Through interior monologues and situational ironies, Ayala shows contrasts between the world and the perception of it; to be human therefore, is to be excruciatingly aware of every minute detail of one’s circumstance.  Written by Julian dela Cerna

text:
Published 1968. Author, Kerima Polotan. Manila: Bookmark. Reprinted, Quezon City: University of the Philippines (UP) Press and UP Creative Writing Center, 1998.

This is a collection of 11 of Polotan’s short fiction, including the seed for her novel The Hand of the Enemy, 1962. Several of the novel’s characters make their first appearance here. Polotan’s masterful handling of the elements of the short story is evident in her dynamic characterization of her protagonists—all female, all conflicted—and in well-crafted dialogue and action.

The tension between acknowledging desire and retaining personal control in the midst of a crucial revelation is a prominent theme in the stories. In “The Virgin,” the uptight and inhibited Miss Mijares, long restrained by a desk job and her family obligations, is confronted and visibly shaken by the arrival of a stranger. In “The Trap,” 14-year-old Elisa develops romantic feelings for her teacher, Mr Gabriel, and so discovers the pangs of adolescence. And in “A Various Season,” Lourdes attempts to make sense of her desires in her relationships with her husband and her newfound lover.

Another theme explored in the stories is entrapment. In places where the odds are against them, the characters struggle to find voice and space, and to get a hand in shaping their destinies, with uneven results. In “This Door,” the young woman Fe confronts death—present, imagined, and impending. In “Cost Price,” poverty drives Isabel, a librarian, and her love interest Joe apart. In “The Visit,” a married couple revisits a long-held grudge against their mother-in-law. In “Gate,” a memory of a past tragedy in the country bleeds into Ester’s life in the city, where a man awaits her. “The Face of Virtue” details Celia’s motives for an abortion—a form of escape—and her story of attempting escape from life in other ways.

The characters in The Hand of the Enemy appear in stories that depict the theme of corruption against the backdrop of the city. In “The Sounds of Sunday,” Domingo Gorrez sinks morally as he climbs up the corporate ladder. Personal corruption expands onto the public sphere in “The Giants,” as the political couple, Alberto and Leonora Cosio, flaunt their riches and power before writer Carmen Reyes. In “The Tourists,” Paz Nuqui witnesses the degeneration of her former love interest Ernesto Bello’s life, from one lived according to moral principles to one corrupted by power, wealth, and ambition.

 

Six of the stories in this collection won prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: “The Virgin,” first prize, 1951; “The Trap,” first prize, 1955; “The Tourists,” first prize, 1959; “The Sounds of Sunday,” first prize, 1960; “The Giants,” second prize, 1958; and “A Various Season,” second prize, 1962.  Written by Maria Amparo Warren

text:
Published 1997. Author, Juan Capiendo Tuvera. With an introduction by Edith L. Tiempo. Quezon City: Book Media Inc.

This is a collection of 21 stories and 15 essays and articles, most of them written between the 1940s and the 1960s. In her introduction, Tiempo notes Tuvera’s “intuition for restraint.” A number of the stories take place against the backdrop of the countryside and use rural images to symbolize the course of relationships. In “Ceremony,” the enactment of a rice-throwing ritual interweaves with Junior’s thoughts about his mother and his older sister Elisa. In “If You Hear Thunder,” a boy escaping a thunderstorm recalls his wish to attend high school and conquer his fears and insecurities.

Tuvera proves to be a master of the act of revelation, as his characters layer by layer discover truth from both within and outside them. The revelation is particularly moving in the stories where male characters fall in love, confess, and confront the pain that comes with the frustration of their desires, as in “Of the River and a Simple Tale,” “High unto Morning,” and “Vacation Spell.” In other stories, revelation takes place in the face of death. The titular character in “Young Man” writes a letter from his hospital bed to his cousin expressing fears; in “Flood,” Tino braves the rain, the thought of his beloved driving him on, a tragedy awaiting him; and in “Final Bud,” an old man suffers the consequences of his wrongdoings to his wife.

The most poignant of Tuvera’s stories capture the anguish, frustration, and resignation of the characters living in the cusp of World War II. In “Heritage,” a boy seeks courage after his father’s brutal death at the hands of the Japanese; “Portrait of a Patriot” depicts the life and simple desires of a soldier awaiting the day that he can marry the girl of his dreams.

The second half of Tuvera’s book consists of essays and articles on Philippine culture and society. “The Walls of Intramuros” and “A Brief History of Medicine in the Philippines” are accounts of Philippine history; “New Upheaval in Red China” and “Cracks in the Iron Claw” present issues in foreign policy, international relations, and conflict; “A Country Full of Ilocanos” is a sociological study; “The Uses of the Common Man” speaks of the relation between the ordinary Filipino and the glib, self-serving politician; “Mass Communication and Cultural Growth” is about the rise of media in Philippine society; and “Philippine Movies” and “The Literary Scene” are about art and culture. Tuvera comments on American influence in “Fallacies of the Vietnam War” and “Human Rights—American Standard,” and highlights trade, industry, security, and foreign aid as factors in shaping “Philippine Nationalism.”

Stories and Other Writings showcases Tuvera’s mastery of prose. The material transcends its time and is relevant in the present.  Written by Maria Amparo Warren

article_title: Sugilanon: Mga Piling Maikling Kuwentong Hiligaynon
text:
(Sugilanon: Selected Hiligaynon Stories). Published 1991. Editor and translator, Rosario Cruz-Lucero, with Ricardo Oebanda. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

The book is a bilingual anthology of 13 Ilonggo short stories. Eleven were taken from Hiligaynon Magasin, which started in 1934; one came from Yuhum Magasin, and one is previously unpublished. With themes ranging from sexual passion and insanity to election fraud and armed struggle, the stories parallel the development of the Ilonggo region itself. Usually set outside the city, either Iloilo or Bacolod, which is seen as a source of evil, the stories trace the way individual lives are ruined by social, economic, and political forces emanating from the city. Although most of the stories follow what Lucero calls in her introduction “the sentimental and melodramatic tradition of Hiligaynon literature,” they invariably subvert this tradition by taking explicitly antigovernment stands on political issues. Lucero situates this subversion within hegemony—that is, the battle for minds and hearts between nationalists and imperialists.

Victorio L. Hinolan’s “Sa Alinsuso sang Iluluthang” (In the Barrel of the Gun), for example, uses a dream scene with an extended speech to attack the power structure in prewar Bacolod. Ariston Em. Echevarria’s “Kon ang Katarungan Lupigon” (If Justice Is Suppressed) uses a 33-year-old Christ figure in jail to condemn the system of justice. Juanito C. Marcella’s “Panaghoy sang Ginahandos nga Palpal” (Lament of One Being Beaten), using some symbolism, traces postwar land conflicts to prewar personal relationships.

Mainstream Ilonggo fiction writing is male oriented and marginalizes women’s issues. Leothiny S. Clavel’s “Ang Hustisya sang Dagat” (The Justice of the Sea), for instance, is influenced by Hemingway’s Old Man and the Sea and follows the Hemingway concept of heroism. Ernesto F. Javellana’s “Hamuok ang Katalugon” (In Deep Sleep) relates how violence thwarts a young man’s good intentions in campaigning for change. W. P. Virtusio’s “Suwerte” (Luck) is a light story about a barber who believes that it is his fate to remain a barber. Nilo Par. Pamonag’s “Diin ang Hustisya?” (Where Is Justice?) debates the question of elections against rebellion.

Five stories focus on women. Ismaelita Floro-Luza’s “Sa Lawod sang Pangabuhi” (In the Lake of Life) tells the story of a housewife who goes back to work after her husband strikes her, but does not condemn the husband. Similarly, the woman protagonist in Ali F. Bedaño’s “Babae” (Woman) follows her physical desires indiscriminately and ends up alone, thus indirectly attacking current feminist demands for sexual equality. Isabelo S. Sobrevega’s “Si Pingkaw” (Pingkaw) makes its poverty-stricken Sisa-figure mad when her children die because doctors prefer to minister to the rich. M. J. Jose’s “Ang Kalipay ni Anita” (Anita’s Happiness) portrays a mistress who uses her body to keep her purse full, and ends up losing everything when she has an affair with a man other than her sugar daddy. Lucila Hosillos’s “Bunyag-Takas” (Baptism-Escape) focuses on tenancy issues from the point of view of a girl on the brink of womanhood.

“Paltos sa Paa sang Burgis” (Bruises on the Feet of the Bourgeois) by Ricardo Oebanda, aka Julian Magtulis, is a good example of what Lucero and others call “alternative hegemony,” or literature of the future, when nationalism finally triumphs over imperialism. This story uses 19th-century realism to follow a rich young boy’s initiation into the ways of rebellion. The sincerity of the sentiment is unassailable: at some point in every young man’s life, violence may seem to be the only path to justice.  Written by Isagani R. Cruz

Although most of the stories follow what Lucero calls in her introduction “the sentimental and melodramatic tradition of Hiligaynon literature,” they invariably subvert this tradition by taking explicitly antigovernment stands on political issues. Lucero situates this subversion within hegemony—that is, the battle for minds and hearts between nationalists and imperialists.

Victorio L. Hinolan’s “Sa Alinsuso sang Iluluthang” (In the Barrel of the Gun), for example, uses a dream scene with an extended speech to attack the power structure in prewar Bacolod. Ariston Em. Echevarria’s “Kon ang Katarungan Lupigon” (If Justice Is Suppressed) uses a 33-year-old Christ figure in jail to condemn the system of justice. Juanito C. Marcella’s “Panaghoy sang Ginahandos nga Palpal” (Lament of One Being Beaten), using some symbolism, traces postwar land conflicts to prewar personal relationships.

Mainstream Ilonggo fiction writing is male oriented and marginalizes women’s issues. Leothiny S. Clavel’s “Ang Hustisya sang Dagat” (The Justice of the Sea), for instance, is influenced by Hemingway’s Old Man and the Sea and follows the Hemingway concept of heroism. Ernesto F. Javellana’s “Hamuok ang Katalugon” (In Deep Sleep) relates how violence thwarts a young man’s good intentions in campaigning for change. W. P. Virtusio’s “Suwerte” (Luck) is a light story about a barber who believes that it is his fate to remain a barber. Nilo Par. Pamonag’s “Diin ang Hustisya?” (Where Is Justice?) debates the question of elections against rebellion.

Five stories focus on women. Ismaelita Floro-Luza’s “Sa Lawod sang Pangabuhi” (In the Lake of Life) tells the story of a housewife who goes back to work after her husband strikes her, but does not condemn the husband. Similarly, the woman protagonist in Ali F. Bedaño’s “Babae” (Woman) follows her physical desires indiscriminately and ends up alone, thus indirectly attacking current feminist demands for sexual equality. Isabelo S. Sobrevega’s “Si Pingkaw” (Pingkaw) makes its poverty-stricken Sisa-figure mad when her children die because doctors prefer to minister to the rich. M. J. Jose’s “Ang Kalipay ni Anita” (Anita’s Happiness) portrays a mistress who uses her body to keep her purse full, and ends up losing everything when she has an affair with a man other than her sugar daddy. Lucila Hosillos’s “Bunyag-Takas” (Baptism-Escape) focuses on tenancy issues from the point of view of a girl on the brink of womanhood.

“Paltos sa Paa sang Burgis” (Bruises on the Feet of the Bourgeois) by Ricardo Oebanda, aka Julian Magtulis, is a good example of what Lucero and others call “alternative hegemony,” or literature of the future, when nationalism finally triumphs over imperialism. This story uses 19th-century realism to follow a rich young boy’s initiation into the ways of rebellion. The sincerity of the sentiment is unassailable: at some point in every young man’s life, violence may seem to be the only path to justice.  Written by Isagani R. Cruz

SUGILANONG SUGBOANON / CEBUANO FICTION UNTIL 1940

 

SUGILANONG SUGBOANON / CEBUANO FICTION 1941-2005

Published 2009. Editors and translators, Erlinda K. Alburo, Vicente Bandillo, Simeon Dumdum Jr, and Resil B. Mojares. With a preface in each volume by the editors and an introduction in each volume by Resil B. Mojares. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This is a two-volume anthology of 28 sugilanon (short stories) in Cebuano and their English translation. In the preface, the editors explain that these sugilanon are selected according to “distribution of texts in time, representativeness in themes and styles, and literary merit.” Capsule biographies are provided at the end of each book.

The first piece is an excerpt from Spanish friar Antonio Ubeda de la Santisima Trinidad’s La Teresa, 1852, which may be considered the prototype of Cebuano modern fiction. Details of Visayan life, such as typhoons and folk beliefs, lend verisimilitude to the characters’ dialogues, which impart lessons in Christian living. At the turn of the century, the writers’ preoccupation with the two anti-imperialist wars following one another is evident. Continuing the anticlerical tradition begun in the Spanish revolutionary period is Vicente Sotto’s “Maming,” 1901, also known as the first published Cebuano short story. “Gugma sa Yutang Natawhan” (Love for the Native Land), also by Sotto, denounces Filipino collaborators under American colonial rule. An excerpt from Juan I. Villagonzalo’s picaresque novel, Wala’y Igsoon (Without a Brother), 1912, contrasts two brothers who suffer through two colonial wars: the revolution against Spain and the Filipino-American war. After the Philippines’ capitulation to American aggression, social conflict becomes a main concern. Amando Osorio’s “Gugma sa Magbabalak” (The Love of a Poet), 1915, gives a modern twist to the formula of forbidden love caused by social class differences.

Since the 1920s, peasant unrest has been a dominant theme in Philippine fiction: Vicente Garces’s “Ang Sugilanon ni Iyo Simon” (Iyo Simon’s Story), 1925, is an allegorical tale about the origins of power structures; Vicente Rama’s “Si Amar ug si Leon” (Amar and Leon), 1927, shows personal entanglements obfuscating legal land claims; and Pantaleon V. Kardenas’s “Ang Panimalus ni Sido” (Sido’s Revenge), 1935, dramatizes the fatal effects of land-grabbing.

By the 1930s, moral questions have become less cut-and-dried. “Giagak sa Kamot ni Bathala” (Led by the Hand of God), 1935, is a story of rape and its unpredictable consequences. Estrella D. Alfon’s “Panamilit sa Kabatan-on” (Farewell to Youth), 1938, is a richly textured coming-of-age story of two female best friends, whose discovery of the complexities of womanhood is rendered as an epiphany. Marcel Navarra’s “Ug Gianod Ako” (And I Was Swept Away), 1937, is a landmark in modernist experimentation. Written in epistolary form, its first-person narrator addresses a “you,” who is his best friend. Its style is a sustained interior monologue, although it has a clear plot conflict that is character driven. The author, through his narrator, reveals his admiration for Jose Garcia Villa and hints at his chagrin at his unappreciative readers.

In Florentino D. Tecson’s “Mga Kasingkasing Dagku” (Magnanimous Hearts), 1939, unrequited love unfolds amid details of a village schoolteacher’s life. The last piece in this volume is “Ang Kaguol ni Banogon” (Banogon’s Grief), 1940, a picaresque story about a fighting cock. Its author, Antonio Abad, is also a prizewinning fictionist in Spanish.

Although the second volume’s subtitle promises a coverage of 1941-2005, Cebuano writing and publishing stopped during World War II, 1941-45. Hence, the first story in this volume is dated 1947. Postwar fiction has a markedly gloomier worldview, the plot conflicts dramatizing the futility of preserving one’s humanity.

“Labawng Magtutudlo” (The Greatest Teacher), 1946, by Fausto Dugenio, uses a female first-person point of view in this story of a husband’s serial infidelities and the betrayal of women’s friendship. In Maria A. Kabigon’s “Pagtulon-an” (Lesson), 1947, a female narrator struggles to keep her virtue intact through World War II and after.

In the 1950s, the plotless story starts to emerge, such as Eugenio A. Viacrucis’s “Mga Mata sa Dagat” (The Sea’s Eyes), 1955, about a fisherman’s elaborate battle with a cat; Godofredo M. Roperos’s “Usa ka Botelyang Suka” (A Bottle of Vinegar), 1956, about a jealous husband’s dying moments; Potenciano Cañizares Jr’s “Ang Naghulat sa Kangitngit” (He Who Waits in the Dark), 1963, about a dog that witnesses Death coming to fetch its master; and “Ang Bisita” (The Visit), 1973, by Austregelina Espina (aka Lina Espina-Moore), about a ghost and his widow who engage in intelligent and tender repartee on Christmas Eve.

The classic, well-made stories, however, continue to be written, now with greater skill: in Fornarina Enemecio’s “Kuwentas nga Manol” (Jasmine Necklace), 1957, a girl raised in affluence becomes estranged from her mother; in Agustino M. Pujida’s “Lunop” (Flood), 1964, a disastrous storm tests the characters’ humanity. Male rite-of-passage stories are depicted in “Ang Gidak-on sa Dagat” (The Immensity of the Sea), 1966; and Dionisio R. Gabriel’s comic “Ang Tigtupo sa Dalan V. Rama” (The Matchmaker of V. Rama Street), 1973.

From the mid-1970s onward, martial law, industrialization, and urbanization are presented as forms of institutional violence; and the countryside is no longer the romantic refuge from urban decadence. Thus, the stories are about the Mindanao war, as in Gremer Chan Reyes’s “Agianan Paingon sa Adlaw” (A Trail toward the Sun), ca 1975; advertising and fishing in Marcel Navarra’s “Siya ug ang Iyang Tungdonon” (Within His Compass), 1975; mining deaths in Ricardo I. Patalinjug’s “Itom nga Sabado” (Black Saturday), ca 1984; hardened criminals in Januar Yap’s “Dekada” (Decade), 1997; and female diaspora in Maria Victoria Beltran’s “Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria Kirschbaum” (The Dream of Eleuteria Kirschbaum), 2005, of which the film version, Ang Damgo ni Eleuteria (The Dream of Eleuteria), 2009, won local and international awards.

Indeed, these stories hold their own as Philippine fiction, anchored on the local realities of the Cebuano-speaking population, which is spread throughout central Visayas and Mindanao. Companion anthologies are Cebuano Poetry / Sugboanong Balak until 1940 and Cebuano Poetry / Sugboanong Balak 1940-1988, both published in 1988; and Dulaang Sebuwano (Cebuano Drama), 1997.   Written by Rosario Cruz-Lucero and J. Quintos

text:
Published 2005. Author, Delfin Fresnosa. Editor, Teresita E. Erestain. With an introduction by the editor. Manila: Far Eastern University Publications.

Delfin Fresnosa has been cited as being among the first Filipino writers to bring the typically marginalized into the spotlight, describing their wretched circumstances in brisk, clear prose. The 25 short stories in the collection settle on unfortunate characters, the setting shuttling between the city and the “probinsya” (countryside), both of which Fresnosa paints in an unforgiving light.

Five of Fresnosa’s stories deal with death: in “Candles,” an old man visits his wife’s grave for the first time since her death; “Tragedy at Lumba’s Bend” tells of a village reeling from the gruesome death of four local miners; “Death of a Hero” depicts the heartbreaking life and death of a war hero who has outlived his glory; in “The Quick and the Dead,” a young man at his wife’s funeral muses on how profits are made from the dead; and in “One Last Goodbye,” a man nearing death opts to have himself arrested, not wanting to die alone. Two love stories in the collections are “Lucia” and “Mariana,” both of which are about sexual awakening and end in heartbreak.

In three stories, Fresnosa details the effects of World War II on the people caught in the cross fire. In “Brown Girl,” the eponymous character is spirited away by Japanese soldiers and tries to find her way back home; in “The Accursed,” a Japanese couple scarred by the atomic bomb are paraded as monsters in a circus. However, Fresnosa gives us a sliver of optimism in “But Once a Year,” where a young couple savor a single cigarette on Christmas Eve at the beginning of the Japanese occupation.

Fresnosa is also keen on focusing on the underdog. In “Anticlimax,” readers enter the mind of a laborer as he makes grand plans for himself, only to see these backfire on him. In “Requiem for a Simple Man,” readers watch from a distance as the village fool is persecuted and ultimately murdered for rescuing a girl above his station. But Fresnosa’s skills are not limited to the grit and grime of realism; some stories have the elements of legend or the folktale. The collection’s title story, “Tandoz,” tells of a farmer who steals an enchanted stone from a giant carabao and becomes the strongest man in the village. “The Orange Tree” has a jealous husband cutting down the orange tree his wife planted when their son disappeared, only to see it grow and bear poisonous fruit. In ”Three Strangers,” a schoolteacher dreams of the impending doom of three strangers after a chance encounter. In “Dove,” a woman coping with the loss of her family is visited by a strange and mystical dove.

The stories included in this collection were published in several national magazines: Philippines Magazine, Commonwealth Advocate, Sunday Tribune Magazine, Graphic, Monthly Post, Sunday Times Magazine, Philippines Free Press, Evening News Saturday Magazine, and This Week. Although not well known to readers today, Fresnosa wrote hundreds of stories and essays in his time, some of which are now lost. This collection reacquaints students of Philippine literature to his best stories.  Written by Katrina del Rosario

article_title: Timbulan ng Pag-ibig at Iba Pang Kuwento
text:
(Buoy of Love and Other Stories). Published 2000. Author, Rosario Ladia Jose. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

This is a collection of 26 stories, originally published in the 1950s in Liwayway. Like other writers of the magazine, Jose handles traditional themes, but she surprises readers with her wit, her daring imagination, and unorthodox views of life.

The title story enables the reader to have a glimpse of the writer’s art. Daniel is a poor farmer who is miserable because of his unrequited love for the rich heiress Leonor. But when he rescues her from outlaws who rape her, her father asks him to marry her. He refuses, because he thinks that she is likely to find another man someday. They keep up the pretense of being married to salvage Leonor’s reputation. After Leonor gives birth, Daniel decides to leave her, as he has promised to. Enough hints in the narrative are given that Leonor will decide to seek out Daniel and declare her love for him. This is a well-made story that presents the traditional theme of the opposing classes being united by love.

Jose makes careful use of the surprise ending, a device that figures in several of Jose’s other stories. In “May Puso ang Bawat Tao” (Every Person Has a Heart), a poor employee realizes that his employer, Mr Reyes, is not a Scrooge after all. He gives Maneng’s daughter a beautiful doll on Christmas Eve. The narrative unfolds more subtly in “Maingat na Binura” (Carefully Erased), where a modern-day Lothario is unexpectedly humiliated by the woman he has tried to dupe. The last scene shows him erasing her name from his list of potential victims.

The different faces of love appear in Jose’s fiction. In “Dalaginding si Kupido” (Cupid Is a Lass), an irrepresible adolescent plays Cupid for her brother and a woman from the province. “Sapatos ni Sinderela” (Cinderella’s Shoes) is a modern version of the Cinderella story. “Siyam na Ama Namin … Siyam Na Gabi” (Six Our Fathers … Six Nights) is Jose’s interpretation of the May Day Eve motif, where the woman finally meets her future husband after she fulfills a rite.

Jose’s stories are replete with references to the fast-changing life in the postwar years: rapid urbanization, the gradual rise of the middle class, and increasing modernization. This was a world of employees interacting in large corporations in Manila, of families that played pelota, of teenagers attending barn dances, of young girls wearing pants, of young people joining singing competitions, of traditional ways inexorably giving way to the modern. Timbulan ng Pag-ibig retrieves from obscurity the stories of a popular fictionist whose body of work is insightful, gritty, breezy, and always a delight to read.  Written by Soledad Reyes
