text:
Published 2004. Author, Luis. V. Teodoro. With an introduction by Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The Undiscovered Country gathers the hitherto uncollected short stories of journalist Luis Teodoro, all of which were written in the 1960s. The tensions of the times appear in the stories, as seen in their common central conflict: the vacillation of the petty bourgeoisie between commitment to the revolution and participation in the existing system of power. 14864162

The university serves as the primary locus for these conflicts, being simultaneously a site for the development and propagation of revolutionary ideology, and a site of censorship, bourgeoisie individualism, and insularity. In “The 13th Disciple,” two professors attend the funeral of a former colleague, who had in his early years been a progressive intellectual but had soon left the university for a comprador law firm. In “The Adversary,” a student temporarily leaves the university to support his widowed mother by working for another intellectual-turned-politician. In “The Trial of Professor Riesgo,” a politically apathetic professor is put on trial for allowing a subversive document to be published in the academic journal he edits. In “The Undiscovered Country,” a Filipino professor’s American wife struggles with the radical and revolutionary discourses circulating in the university, which challenge US hegemony. Finally, in “The Distant City,” two professors struggle with the need to hide their romantic affair and political activity from the eyes of their conservative colleagues at the university. In all of these stories, the central characters arrive at an epiphany about their inability to take sides despite the proven validity of the people’s revolutionary right and the necessity of constant struggle.

The Undiscovered Country also collects some of Teodoro’s earlier, less political works. “In Transit” follows a man’s attempt to finally settle after years of transitory movement. “Ghost of Houses” tells the story of young girl Cita, whose disease, ignored and untreated by her parents, eats away at her spirit and leaves her ostracized by her family. Finally, Teodoro’s first published story, “Paper Stars,” shows the intersections of love, care, and maturity in the life of a suffocatingly maternal elementary teacher.

Teodoro writes in a journalistic style that Bienvenido L. Lumbera, in his introduction, connects to early 20th century Philippine fiction. article.value: Published 2004. Author, Luis. V. Teodoro. With an introduction by Bienvenido L. Lumbera. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

The Undiscovered Country gathers the hitherto uncollected short stories of journalist Luis Teodoro, all of which were written in the 1960s. The tensions of the times appear in the stories, as seen in their common central conflict: the vacillation of the petty bourgeoisie between commitment to the revolution and participation in the existing system of power. 14864162

The university serves as the primary locus for these conflicts, being simultaneously a site for the development and propagation of revolutionary ideology, and a site of censorship, bourgeoisie individualism, and insularity. In “The 13th Disciple,” two professors attend the funeral of a former colleague, who had in his early years been a progressive intellectual but had soon left the university for a comprador law firm. In “The Adversary,” a student temporarily leaves the university to support his widowed mother by working for another intellectual-turned-politician. In “The Trial of Professor Riesgo,” a politically apathetic professor is put on trial for allowing a subversive document to be published in the academic journal he edits. In “The Undiscovered Country,” a Filipino professor’s American wife struggles with the radical and revolutionary discourses circulating in the university, which challenge US hegemony. Finally, in “The Distant City,” two professors struggle with the need to hide their romantic affair and political activity from the eyes of their conservative colleagues at the university. In all of these stories, the central characters arrive at an epiphany about their inability to take sides despite the proven validity of the people’s revolutionary right and the necessity of constant struggle.

The Undiscovered Country also collects some of Teodoro’s earlier, less political works. “In Transit” follows a man’s attempt to finally settle after years of transitory movement. “Ghost of Houses” tells the story of young girl Cita, whose disease, ignored and untreated by her parents, eats away at her spirit and leaves her ostracized by her family. Finally, Teodoro’s first published story, “Paper Stars,” shows the intersections of love, care, and maturity in the life of a suffocatingly maternal elementary teacher.

Teodoro writes in a journalistic style that Bienvenido L. Lumbera, in his introduction, connects to early 20th century Philippine fiction. The dialogue is often stilted and contrived, but the works’ highly polished techniques and structures enhance the stories’ abilities to serve as social critiques.  Written by Dominic Sy

article_title: Utos ng Hari at Iba Pang Kuwento
text:
(The King’s Command and Other Stories). Published 1981. Author, Jun Cruz Reyes. With an introduction by LuluTorres. Quezon City: New Day Publishers. Reprinted, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press, 2002.

The author believes that there are only two types of stories—the “mababaw” (shallow) and the “mabigat” (heavy). He wants to write stories that are both. To do this, he consciously junks the rules of conventional storytelling; writes stories with no clear beginning, middle, and end; uses different moods—comic, satirical, irreverent, inflammatory; and most of all, creates language that always rings true—to ear and character. The successful use of salitang kanto or language of the street corner, as language for literature and expression of political commitment, is one of the achievements of this collection.

The most familiar story of Reyes, “Utos ng Hari” is a litany of a student’s travails, and more. For as 17-year-old Jojo pours out his anguish against a hoard of terror teachers whose thinking seems to have been caught in a time warp, he, too, gives vent to his anger against the debilitating restrictions and hypocrisies in a society ruled by authoritarianism, obsolete conventions, and reactionary morals. While there is no obvert mention of martial law, there are references to it, as in the referendums where one voted either “yes” or “no.” While Jojo reels from the onslaught of his various enemies, he also shares in the fate of Minyong, a classmate who hails from a tribal community, and of course, in the humiliation of Tess, his girlfriend.

Authenticity of character and language also characterizes the other stories in the collection: “Sulat mula sa Kanto” (Letter from the Street Corner), the depiction of a gallery of “survivors” in a slum area called Looban; “Kuwento ni Rey” (Rey’s Story), the sketch of a young boy who is regarded as a nonachiever and nuisance by his own family; “Isang Kuwentong Pag-ibig” (A Story of Love), the portrait of Neneng, who is given as payment for attorney’s fees and works as a burlesque dancer to make ends meet; “Isang Lumang Kuwento” (An Old Story), a slum-dweller’s monologue; “Mula kay Tandang Iskong Basahan, mga Tagpi-Tagping Alaala” (From Old Man Isko the Ragpicker, a Patchwork of Memories), a fond portrayal of an old man who sells rags; “Araw ng mga Buldoser at Dapithapon ng Isang Bangkang Papel sa Buhay ni Ato” (The Day of the Bulldozers and the Twilight of a Paper Boat in the Life of Ato), the story of a boy whose family is evicted, dislodged by a demolition team in a Malabon urban poor area; “Doon Po sa Amin” (Back Home), a description of the life of an ordinary office employee; “Mga Kuwentong Kapos” (Incomplete Stories), vignettes about four characters that the persona meets along his meanderings.  Written by Nicanor G. Tiongson and Victor Pablo

text:
(Virgintarian and Other Works). Published 2002. Author, Mayette Bayuga. With an introduction by Rosario Cruz-Lucero. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

In this collection of 13 stories, Bayuga engages the breadth and range of the female experience in the Philippines, from a 17-year-old’s introduction to a stratified society in Palawan to a young urban professional’s sexual awakening in a dingy boarding house in Manila.

In her introduction, Rosario Cruz-Lucero offers a useful way of dividing the stories in terms of thematic preoccupation and corresponding formal verve. The first group, mostly told from a young character’s point of view, consists of initiation-themed stories. In “Rosal” (Gardenia), a Catholic school student comes of age after she witnesses a classmate’s tryst in a garden by the grotto of the Virgin Mary. The second group probes sexual politics. Domestic violence is at the center of “Ang Baliw” (The Crazed), in which an unspoken abuse on Myla by his seemingly good husband Vance is brought to the fore by the titular character’s intrusion into their lives. The last group of stories, which are also Bayuga’s most daring formally, examines the otherness and power of women in various guises, as babaylan, aswang, a lesbian lover, or the Muse herself. This group includes “Pagdiwata” (Babaylan Ritual) which charts, in a hypnotic stream-of-consciousness chant, the life of a babaylan from a Tagbanwa tribe through a century of Philippine history. Also a mother, she struggles under the weight of history, from the American period to World War II and the more recent wave of missionaries, researchers, NGOs, cultural workers, and media, who come in droves, curious about her tribe’s “exotic” culture.

While concerned with the permutations of a distinct female consciousness, Bayuga’s stories use a wide range of locales as setting and various fictional modes. The romantic bildungsroman “Karatig-Silid” (Adjoining Room) takes place in a boarding house in Paco, Manila, while “Kaloong” (Nautilus) follows two sisters as they gallivant around Zamboanga City. Western and indigenous traditions meld in “Kinabinhian” (Sowed Upon), which features a group that practices an animist brand of Christianity, with orations in which native chants alternate with Latin prayers. The titular story “Virgintarian” also intertwines two arenas, this time of desire, as the vegetarian Ava suffers twofold torture on a stalled bus, one from the smell of barbecued pork intestines wafting onboard and the other from his male seatmate whose thigh, she could feel, would brush against hers.

Fittingly, a feminist ars poetica ends the book, with the writer in “Pasiyam” addressing her dead cat during the close of the ritual nine-day prayer, to which the title alludes. Drawing a parallelism between the cat’s myriad experiences throughout its nine lives and the writer’s pursuit in crafting stories, she pleads for the same gift of wisdom and storytelling voice. The most successful feminist texts, Lucero notes, demand an aesthetic lens that is different from universal—that is, male—literature, and through which Bayuga’s expansive and dexterous stories must be read.

The following stories won Palanca awards: “Rosal,” first prize, 1993, and “Ang Baliw,” second prize, 1997.  Written by Glenn Diaz

article_title: The Voice from Sumisip and Four Short Stories
text:
Published 2003. Author, Antonio Enriquez. Quezon City: Giraffe Books, 2003.

Taken together, the four short stories and one novella that make up this collection can be loosely considered a novel, in scope covering the arrival of the first Spaniards in the Zamboanga Peninsula to the Moro insurgency that swept the island of Basilan after the declaration of martial law.

The first story, “The Turtle Egg Hunter,” recounts how the Spaniards capture a Subanon boy and torture him for information on the whereabouts of his village. This story sets the tone for the entire collection. “Gatherer of the People” details the conversion of the Subanon chieftain to Christianity. The Spanish friars are able to convince the local leaders that their beliefs are not incompatible with Christianity. Thus does Spain gain a foothold in this part of the archipelago. In “Iba the Christian,” a Subanon convert looks for a horse so that he can warn the Spaniards in the nearby fort of a Moro pirate fleet approaching. Even while his own people deride him for being loyal to the Spaniards, Iba feels that it is his obligation as a Christian to warn other Christians about the incoming danger. In “Jainal the Pirate,” the eponymous hero tries to evade the Spanish fleet after he has raided the Visayan Islands for slaves and treasure. His fleet then gets trapped in Punta Pana. What occurs next is a vividly described naval battle between the Moro pirates and the Spanish fleet.

Parts of or themes from these stories recur in the novella The Voice from Sumisip. Professor Jose goes to Basilan in order to research on the Yakan. But he despises both the Muslim and the Yakan, both groups having participated in the Moro rebellion but now benefiting from the amnesty granted by the martial law government. Still, he continues to record the history and culture of the Yakan, believing that these will all vanish one day. Toward the end, he gives in to his own hypocrisy and greed when he pretends that he is important enough to carry the Yakan’s gift for the dictator when, all along, he has wanted it for himself. He pays a fatal price for it, his death foreshadowed by the constant burst of gunfire throughout his trip to Sumisip.

The collection shows the complicated issues surrounding Mindanao: the rebellion of the Muslims, who now occupy powerful posts, the disgruntlement of the Christian majority who find themselves being second-class citizens, the struggle of the indigenous peoples to survive in a conflict-ridden island, and the long arm of oppression and corruption brought about by martial law. The picture of the future is bleak: violence begets violence, and the people who are in the position to do something about it turn a blind eye. As shown by the very last scene of the novella, even the indigenous groups, who have been displaced the most, will eventually find their voices and decide to finally take back what was theirs from Muslims and Christians. The collection dramatizes deep-seated prejudices and centuries-old resentments, which seem to be nowhere near resolution.  Written by Jose Miguel Arguelles

article_title: The Week of the Whales and Other Stories
text:
Published 1994. Author, Leoncio P. Deriada. Quezon City: New Day Publishers.

In his third collection of short stories, Leoncio Deriada tackles, with uneven success, a variety of subjects. Here are stories of private sorrows, of seemingly quaint, yet persistent and potent, folk manners, of social inequity and exploitation. Here are boys on the brink of manhood, feeling the awakenings that are its heralds, parents reading announcements of their sons’ death, idealist teachers helpless in the face of ruthless realities, a Jesuit tremulous before the sight of man-flesh under the shower, an exiled First Lady listening dreamily to the illusionary sounds of a conch.

These diverse characters share an experience hinted at in his preface, where Deriada writes that 6 of the 14 stories were completed while his wife was furiously but fruitlessly fighting cancer. This experience is loss and its child, pain.

Both “The Hawk” and “The Slaughterhouse” depict a mother’s grief over the loss of her sons in “a war she could not understand.” The mothers in the stories, each in her own way, bravely confront their grief. In contrast, the father in the first story stays silent, “crying in the dark”; the father in the second shields himself from the awful truth of his son’s death behind trivial news about visiting “Russian ballerinas” and “RP beauties.”

There are other kinds of loss in the collection. Love lost and chance squandered are depicted in “Bus Ride.” “The Priest” is about a young man’s harrowing discovery of a priest’s errant sexuality. If the spiritual father fails, the stepfather in “For Death Is Dead in December” succeeds. Set in Christmas, this is Deriada’s most optimistic, if also most stylistically contrived, story.

These stories of private pains are balanced by stories with more sociopolitical content. “Chicks in the Snake’s Cage” shows a college student’s political initiation. “Imelda of the Islands” recounts a fictive life of Imelda Marcos before her rise to power and after her exile to Hawaii. The title story, “The Week of the Whales,” is about the encroachment of Japanese industrialists upon the pristine Punta Sungay.

While Deriada shows his political leanings in these stories, he does not sacrifice the personal drama altogether. “Chicks” is as much a boy’s rite of passage as it is an indictment of injustice. “Imelda” is a study of the mentality of the ambitious but (or because) deprived. “Whales” affirms the belief in personal consolations in the midst of social defeat. More overtly political is “Dam,” which recounts, with delicate detail à la Manuel Arguilla, how a native dams a river only to have Christian settlers hoard the fish.

The other stories in the collection are “Coming Home,” “Rabid,” and “Of Scissors and Saints.” In the first two, a young man returns from the city only to find that he has lost his “primal sympathy” with his boyhood haunts. Deriada is equivocal in this tension between the urban and the rural. “Of Scissors and Saints,” full of vivid and comic descriptions of barrio manners and magic, reads like an excerpt from an autobiography.   Written by Jonathan Chua

text:
Published 2003. Author, Ma. Romina M. Gonzalez. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

While pathos and humor are Gonzalez’s strongest suit—in powerful evidence in this collection’s titular and best-known piece—unmistakable social commentary also permeates the 10 stories. Whether it is on migration in “Metropole Valentine,” charity in “Sanded Soles,” class and social climbing in “Flood,” or workplace abuse in “Cockroach,” the author, a journalist, casts an unflinching eye on social realities with a cast of mostly female characters via modes that range from hard realism to the fantastic.

Addressing the beloved “you,” the protagonist in “Metropole Valentine” narrates the slow breakdown of her marriage with a childhood friend after they migrate to freezing Chicago. Her growing alienation in a foreign land—aggravated by seemingly harmless quibbles about food, language, and her inability to “outgrow” flicks starring Sharon Cuneta and Gabby Concepcion turns into full-blown animosity when he prods her into having a baby against her will. By the story’s end, there is triumph when she hears the beloved slip on the floor that she has, it is implied, purposely waxed.

Set in an unnamed ash-covered town in the aftermath of the Pinatubo eruption, “Sanded Soles” pokes fun at the relief efforts and the people involved, including government officials, patrons, religious pilgrims, and the media. The story’s points of view shift between a photographer who is tasked to document the event and a local girl who has lost her slippers. This technical innovation allows the reader to witness the harsh disconnect between the ways the victims and so-called sympathizers see the devastated landscape and lives.

Final, satisfying acts punctuate two stories, both fictively functioning as sound, if bizarre, repudiation of a harsh status quo. Whether it is the social-climbing ways of the child protagonist’s mother in “Flood” or a sexually abusive relationship with a boss in “Cockroach,” Gonzalez ends the narratives with clear turns of events, signaling decisive shifts in the characters’ consciousness.

It is in the middle-class love story “Welostit”—the collection’s rawest, most poignant piece—where Gonzalez’s talent as a fictionist is in abundant display. Like “Metropole Valentine,” “Welostit” is epistolary. It tracks the May-December affair from the point of view of the older woman, from its giddy beginnings to the death of their just-born baby, the “it” in the title. As in her other stories, the triumph of “Welostit” is the wealth of powerful details and compelling series of events, all told in the protagonist’s funny, unassuming voice, which freely makes use of humor to mask an intense pain.

Whether the sphere is social or private, the stories in this chronologically arranged debut collection reveal the trajectory of Gonzalez’s thematic and stylistic preoccupations, as well as the increasing deftness with which she handles her subjects. Her earliest stories, “Till There Was You” and “Offertory,” are highly playful and experimental, the former told in a hallucinogenic stream of consciousness and the latter being a modern twist on indigenous folklore. Her latter stories, like the “Elevator” and “Cockroach,” are succinct and tongue-in-cheek. By the collection’s end, Gonzalez’s fiction has achieved a stark and debilitating clarity, all without losing the dark humor that salvages her eternally grim narratives.

The following stories won prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: “Sanded Soles,” second prize, 1994; “Welostit,” third prize, 1997; and “Flood,” second prize, 1999.  Written by Glenn Diaz

Whether it is the social-climbing ways of the child protagonist’s mother in “Flood” or a sexually abusive relationship with a boss in “Cockroach,” Gonzalez ends the narratives with clear turns of events, signaling decisive shifts in the characters’ consciousness.

It is in the middle-class love story “Welostit”—the collection’s rawest, most poignant piece—where Gonzalez’s talent as a fictionist is in abundant display. Like “Metropole Valentine,” “Welostit” is epistolary. It tracks the May-December affair from the point of view of the older woman, from its giddy beginnings to the death of their just-born baby, the “it” in the title. As in her other stories, the triumph of “Welostit” is the wealth of powerful details and compelling series of events, all told in the protagonist’s funny, unassuming voice, which freely makes use of humor to mask an intense pain.

Whether the sphere is social or private, the stories in this chronologically arranged debut collection reveal the trajectory of Gonzalez’s thematic and stylistic preoccupations, as well as the increasing deftness with which she handles her subjects. Her earliest stories, “Till There Was You” and “Offertory,” are highly playful and experimental, the former told in a hallucinogenic stream of consciousness and the latter being a modern twist on indigenous folklore. Her latter stories, like the “Elevator” and “Cockroach,” are succinct and tongue-in-cheek. By the collection’s end, Gonzalez’s fiction has achieved a stark and debilitating clarity, all without losing the dark humor that salvages her eternally grim narratives.

The following stories won prizes at the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards for Literature: “Sanded Soles,” second prize, 1994; “Welostit,” third prize, 1997; and “Flood,” second prize, 1999.  Written by Glenn Diaz

Published 1994. Author, Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo. With an introduction by Ophelia Dimalanta. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

“Tales” are narratives episodic in structure, simple in language, often fanciful in matter. In this book, Hidalgo employs many of the techniques of the tale. In the manner of the anonymous tale-tellers of old, she assumes the voices of her characters and muffles her own. Several of the tales come to us in the guise of stories one character recounts to another. Other tales address the readers and unfold by flashback. Thus, Hidalgo creates an illusion of oral transmission and allows room for loose construction, digressions, and slight inconsistencies in tone—all hallmarks of the tale.

The effect of framing her tale can be teasing, as in “The Woman in the Lighthouse.” A chance meeting between the narrator and a woman leads to a date in which the woman tells a story of forbidden love. The folksy flavor of the tales is here and there spiced by a sprinkling of the supernatural. The eponymous character in “Sylvia” is a ghost; a lovestruck goddess is spurned by a mortal in “Goddess of the Mountain.” “The Princess in Disguise” casually infuses elements of the fairy tale into an otherwise realistic story. In these tales, the inclusion of folk wisdom adds to their quaint quality.

Among the nine tales, “How Bartolo Came to Be Called Bartolo”—titled like an etiological fable, told as a story the narrator had heard long ago—most closely adheres to the conventions of the tale. Behind the explanation for the name is the story of rival brothers, sworn enemies turned severed sweethearts, a babaylan with a magic potion, foreboding dreams, twilight meetings beneath flame trees in bloom—in a word, romance. The other stories in the collection are less romantic. The narrator in “The Mother” recounts her travails, living with an unfaithful husband and raising a “difficult” daughter, and finds that she has survived. In “The Boy in the White Shirt and the Khaki Pants Two Inches Too Short for Him,” Carlos, a country boy, enjoys initial success as a writer in the city but finds that he is “having trouble writing.” The last story in the collection, “The Warrior,” is about a dying agnostic’s last words. Ophelia Dimalanta, in her introduction to the book, praises the “philosophical overtones” of the story.

Here and there, Hidalgo dabs a dark shade of social realism on the bright romantic canvas of her tales. In “Sylvia,” the hospital hastily built (to satisfy the whim of a vice president’s wife) and haunted by the ghosts of its laborers left to die in quick-drying cement, Sylvia’s queer car accident that kills her—these obliquely resemble the eerie circumstances surrounding the construction of the Manila Film Center. In “Boy in the White Shirt,” the military witch-hunts of the martial law years are alluded to. Thus, Hidalgo enswathes the bareness of tales in a colorful robe of realistic details, meticulously evoking milieu.  Written by Jonathan Chua

Published 1973. Author, Gilda Cordero-Fernando. With a foreword by Alejandro Roces. Manila: Philippine International Publishers.

A Wilderness of Sweets is the second collection of short stories by Cordero-Fernando. The five pieces combine stylistic versatility, excellent craftsmanship, and psychological depth in exploring the domestic lives of urban Filipinos in the mid-20th century.

Frustrated desire is a common theme in the collection and is the main dilemma in three. In “The Secret Ageing,” an older and married man pines impossibly for the young daughter of his friend, who is herself hopelessly in love with a classmate. Their respective desires stem from middle-age discontent and adolescent idealism, but as Roces points out in his foreword, they are both merely two sides of the same coin: twin romanticisms. In “A Cake Left Out in the Rain,” an abandoned matron falls for an American adventurer and invites him to stay in her home. She showers him with gifts, which merely build resentment in his heart as he finds his vitality smothered and sapped by her longing. More lighthearted in tone but with an undercurrent of sadness is the wonder tale “The Dust Monster,” which follows a neglected housewife’s relationship with a man made of dust. The dust monster fills in for the absent husband, helping the protagonist gain confidence and stave away her loneliness.

Frustrated love also appears in the other two stories, where they are intertwined with overarching social conflicts. In “Early in Our World,” touches of fabulation and lyricism mitigate the grim, realistic detail with which the life of informal settlers is depicted. The young protagonist, Helen, must look after her crippled brother, while her widowed mother is routinely depressed. Living in a compound of discarded buses, the family relies on their friend, Simon Plaza, a magician and faith healer, to provide the occasional relief. Helen falls in love with him; but, as is the convention in a coming-of-age story, she must come to terms with its impossibility.

This same thematic development is seen in Fernando’s classic war novelette, A Wilderness of Sweets. The theme of loss of innocence is hinted at in the title itself, which is taken from a verse in Paradise Lost. The bildungsroman takes place during the Japanese occupation of Manila. Beginning as children concerned only with playing and fun, Joy, her siblings, and her friends are forced to grow up in the war, to learn to survive under the most brutal conditions, and to fight back against them by whatever means necessary. Central to the novelette is the love story between Joy and Badel Mercado, but the latter gets caught deeper and deeper in the violence and with the guerrillas, and farther and farther away from Joy.

A Wilderness of Sweets can be said to belong to the early post-World War II movement of Philippine literature in English, whose indoctrination into New Criticism was expanded by existentialist introspection. At the same time, however, these stories go beyond such narrow categories. The stark realism of “Early in Our World” and “A Wilderness of Sweets” contrasts wonderfully with the excellent tale of “The Dust Monster.” That both appear in this collection is a testament to the author’s skill and her indelible contribution to the literary tradition.  Written by Dominic Sy

Published 1937. Author, Arturo B. Rotor. Manila: Philippine Book Guild.

This was the first of a series of publications envisioned by the Philippine Book Guild as a response to the perceived lack of publications in the country of writings by Philippine authors. The stories in this collection were earlier published in various publications such as Graphic, Herald, and Tribune. They show the evolution of Rotor’s writing style from the middle of the 1920s, where there is a distinct attention to form and plot, and from 1930 onward, where the influences of Sherwood Anderson’s Winesburg, Ohio and Wilbur Daniel Steele’s “fifth-act method”—that is, beginning the story at the end of the chronology of events—can be seen. The earlier stories hew closely to articulations of the nature of the modern short story by Poe, Matthews, Canby, and other theorists, and the later stories reflect the innovations espoused by Steele and Anderson and other practitioners of the genre.

The early stories in the collection also show the author’s fascination with the new language to the point where the prose is heavy and turgid. The author recovers soon enough, and the later stories show restraint and sobriety of language as well as of material. Among the most anthologized stories in the collection are “Zita,” a girl’s initiation into love and heartache; “Flower Shop,” ostensibly a description of a day at a flower shop but actually an exposé of a socialite’s character; “At Last This Fragrance,” a detached intern’s reawakening to human feeling and company; and “Dahong Palay” (Rice Leaves), usually cited as an example of the use of local color, a development in the genre that came along with the emergence of Anderson, and others. “Convict’s Twilight” and “How They Transferred the Convicts to Davao” depict life in the penal colony and inmates sympathetically.

Rotor’s use of doctors as characters or narrators in a number of stories reflects his medical background and anticipates the stories in his second collection, The Men Who Play God, 1983.

Six of Rotor’s stories are reprinted in Selected Stories from “The Wound and the Scar,” 1973.  Written by Lolita R. Lacuesta

 

Source

Alegre, Edilberto, and Doreen G. Fernandez. 1984. The Writer and His Milieu: An Oral History of First Generation Writers in English. Manila: De La Salle University Press.

text:
Published 1955. Author, Bienvenido N. Santos. With an introduction by N. V. M. Gonzalez. Manila: Benipayo Press. Reprinted, Manila: Bookmark, 1966, 1991.

This collection of 19 stories reads like connected episodes and character sketches of a certain period in the persona’s life. Many of the stories revolve around the narrator’s alter ego and another first-person narrator named Pablo Icarangal, or Ambo for short.

“Scent of Apples” is the best known and most frequently anthologized of the stories. The narrator is on a lecture tour of the United States during the war. He is approached by Celestino Fabia, an old-timer who wants to show him off to his family as a “first-class Filipino.” Like many of this volume’s expatriates, he is married to an American woman. Although his wife Ruth may seem inferior to her Filipina counterpart, Fabia insists she is just as good because of her care and devotion. However, her love for him has not been sufficient to overcome the poignant feeling of loneliness that Fabia has endured for years. In the end, the narrator offers to visit Fabia’s family in the Philippines but the “much defeated, but brave” man desists, saying that nobody in his hometown would remember him. The words are chilling, and the narrator shares in the cruel pain of the exile’s suffering; and he rushes away to escape from the tension of the situation.

The plight of the Filipino exile in America, having to bear homelessness, disillusionment, and emotional and cultural deprivation, is a theme common to most of these stories. In “The Door,” “Ash Wednesday,” and “Woman Afraid,” both the Filipino men and their American wives are trapped in hopeless situations.

In this collection, Santos shows a keen sensitivity in delineating his characters, and employs sympathetic irony in depicting the lives of rootless Filipinos abroad. N. V. M. Gonzalez, in an interview, 1984, has remarked that “Scent of Apples” is the “best Philippine short story ever written.”  Written by Mita L. de Manuel

 

Sources

Bernad, Miguel, SJ. 1972. “The Stories of Bienvenido Santos.” In Philippine Fiction, ed. Joseph A. Galdon, 101-6. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Fernandez, Enrique Lumba. 1984. Hispanofilia Filipina: Premio Literario Enrique Zobel de 1954. Manila.

Galdon, Joseph, SJ, ed. 1979. Essays on the Philippine Novel in English. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.
